rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCarthy, Doris
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Short Stories; Fool's Paradise;
rdf:Description.dc:description: A short story written by Doris McCarthy in 2000 (?) about her experiences building Fool's Paradise. SHORT STORY BY DORIS MCCARTHY The well was dug by hand, three feet in diameter and lined with brick. In spite of a dowser's locating the right spot, the men had to go down fifty-two feet before they found water. Fifty-two feet is a long way, too far for a pump to pull. They had to build a platform down in the depths for the pump to sit where it could push the water up. There was a cover over the well where I could stand to work a handle up and down to activate the pump far below. I used the boulders that they dug out with the sand and clay to make a rock garden around the the top of the well and painted the pump handle blue to match the forget-me -nots. Happiness was being able to fill a pail with water from my own well instead of carrying it out from the city. But not for long. It turned out that the water was coming through a layer of such fine sand that the sand came with the water and finally choked the pump. I consulted the well- digger, a stocky little Glaswegian whose accent had to be heard to be believed. He advised that the only remedy would be a concrete collar inside the bricks through which the water could seep but not the sand. But his mate had gone off to do war work and it was a two man job. This turned out to mean being lowered on a foot sling down to the platform below to receive the buckets of concrete and shovelling the mucky stuff into the form which Bill had built and fixed in place. Bill stayed on top because mixing the cement and sand and winching the buckets down to me was the trickier job. I wore a saucepan on my head, handle turned to the back as a hard hat in case of spills. And down there, lit by the sky above the shaft, I worked. From time to time Bill's voice would echo down to me. "Doris , do you want to come up for a cigarette?".and I would step into the sling and be winched up to the surface where I became instantly "Miss McCarthy". Once as I sat smoking with Bill, complete with hard hat and all the splatters, a car came creeping over the bumps in the dirt road and out stepped my mother's cousin from Rosedale with my Westmount aunt from Montreal. It was not as they had envisaged a call on their neice to see her new home. There was no way I could offer tea and they did not linger. But the memory of that comic moment has stayed with me for sixty years. Good condition

rdf:Description.dc:title: Spontaneous Living How never to be tired
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCarthy, Doris, 1910 - 2010
rdf:Description.dc:subject: McCarthy, Doris, 1910-2010 - Short Stories
rdf:Description.dc:description: A short story written for a woman's magazine describing the daily routine of an atypical housewife. No date available. SPONTANEOUS LIYINB - OR HOW NEVER TO BE TIRED I've been reading your magazine for years. My living room is piled with back numbers and I think they're wonderful. But in all those years I've looked in vain for an article written by someone like me. I see a heading "I'm nit a Slave to my House" and I think "Here it is, at last." But when I read it I discover that the author is just like all the other housekeepers who write for magazines. She keeps an eight room house clean, does all her own canning, super-trains two children, makes their clothes, runs the local garden club and paints Swedish designs on old furniture in her spar© time. Now I'm not a bit like that. Even thinking about being like that exhausts mo so much that I go and lie down for a while and smoke a cigarette or have a little sleep. But I think its time somebody put down in print how the other half lives. I suppose, on analysis, my day has a routine. I've never felt that the routine was at all rigid. But the alarm clock goes off at 7.00 A.M. sharp. Jimmie is a very sound sleeper and so am I, so we wind it full to the limit every night and hang it from the top of the bed between our heads. It goes off less than a foot from my ear but I don't hear it. In all the three years I've been married I never have heard it. Neither has Jimmie. Nobody can understand why we still wind it up and set it. But I think that to stop trying shows a defeatist attitude to life. At 7.50 one of our friends telephones and somehow this does wake us up. Mother says its my social instinct operating even when I'm unconscious. We've tried different people for this telephone duty. Mother did it for a while after we were married. The girl who does it now is a school teacher and dependable but she has long holidays and sometimes she forgets to get up on Saturday morning. Neither Jimmie nor I feel that she is the perfect solution. But we've used her for the last two years because besides being quite reliable she is psychic almost. Sometimes if she feels that Jimmie has had a particularly hollow jauntiness in his "good morning" she telephones again half an hour later. The chances are that he did go back to bed and to sleep that morning. Paper is yellowing, but otherwise in good condition.

rdf:Description.dc:title: Spontaneous Living How never to be tired
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCarthy, Doris, 1910 - 2010
rdf:Description.dc:subject: McCarthy, Doris, 1910-2010 - Short Stories
rdf:Description.dc:description: A short story written for a woman's magazine describing the daily routine of an atypical housewife. No date available. page 2 SPONTANEOUS LIVING cont'd Most of this is hearsay to me. of course. I make Jimmy's breakfast and sometimes eat with him but I never really know how it all happens. I'm always surprised when Jimmie telephones about noon to tell me that he loves me and is sorry about the quarrel we had before he left. He's wonderful. I didn't even know we had quarrelled. I suppose I go back to sleep after breakfast. Yes of course I do. I can remember the feeling that comes over me when I start to make the bed. I always intend to make it and tidy up, but it hypnotizes me. I feel as if the pillows came up slowly and wrapped themselves around my neck. One friend of mine who is a psychologist and awfully clever, says that instead of the pillows coming up what really happens is that I go down to them. Sometimes the kitten wakes me. She's apt to practice diving from the foot board of the bed on to my chest. But often the first thing I hear is the telephone again. It's Ruth to ask me over for lunch. I'm shocked to hear that its lunch time. We discuss cur respective refrigerators and whichever one seemB to be best stocked wins. It its' Ruth's, I fly around in a hurry, make the bed, tidy the bedroom, do last nights* and this morning's dishes, empty yesterdays ash trays, pick up yesterday's magazines, rush around with a carpet sweeper, mop and duster, feed the kitten, put the washing to soak, dress and rush over to Ruth's with a dessert from last night in one hand, and two cold sausages wrapped in wax paper in the other. Ruth is a deliberate and thorough sort of person. By this time she has set the table and the kettle is boiling. We share a tremendous enthusiasm for food. Of course I don't think I could ever be fast friends with an indifferent eater. We agree that even cold sausages must be served graciously. We have flowers on the table, Susie Cooper China, gay place mats, and an exquisite sense of leisure. Luncheon gees on and on. We drift from the table to the chesterfield. That's one of the great advantages of a living room - dining room. We haven't half finished our review of current reading and the by paths of philosophy, manners and morals down which it leads us before the telephone interrupts. Someone wants us to go over for tea. Paper is yellowing, but otherwise in good condition.

VC 2 c page 5 SPONTANEOUS LIVING cont'd Ruth stacks the dishes while I sit down again for a while and make a list. I find making lists systematically of all the things I should do takes less time than doing them and I can smoke while I work. I put this list into my purse with all the other lists I have made, and set out for tea with an easier mind. It is late when I get home, I don't know why, but the really interesting things get said at the end of the afternoon. So I do the shopping in haste and dash into the apartment. Probably Jean, my human alarm clock, is already there. I usually find her stretched out on the chesterfield beside the remains of a sandwich' and a glass of milk, with my old magazines open on her chest and strewn about the floor beside her. She. i* clrt\tvtnc) kome. j>i«v*\$» S^s t$ alw&^jS d i"t\u)%i\a Wou%e pl<xr\"5. She 1b- alwavs drawing house plana-. I curl up beside her with a cigarette and inspect the latest version. We argue about kitchens. Finally she jumps up to go, assuring me that she can't possibly stay for dinner. She has work to do and she had a snack so she isn't hungry. Neither of us take this seriously. I coax her and she finally stays and gets dinner for me. I help and if we don't talk we're fine. Our usual team time for a good hot dinner is twenty-five minutes, but if Jimmie is late and we start discussing Life, things burn. I don't know why oysters stimulate discussion but I've given up buying them. The last two lots were charred beyond recognition. Dinner is a delightful hour isn't it? It means flowers, candles, good food, gaiety, being with the people you love best in the world. It's almost my favourite time. Jean and Jimmie argue and I change plates and ply them both with food. Dinner slides into after dinner without any break. Jean may carry her coffee to the chesterfield while Jimmie pushes his chair back and starts to play with the kitten. Soon he is on the floor with her, and then in his easy chair in the corner. It happens without anyone noticing. It is only when I hear his mournful little flute playing off key with the radio that I realize that evening has come. Jean looks up from her newest house plan and says it is time she went home. rdf:Description.dc:title: Spontaneous Living How never to be tired
rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCarthy, Doris, 1910 - 2010
rdf:Description.dc:subject: McCarthy, Doris, 1910-2010 - Short Stories
rdf:Description.dc:description: A short story written for a woman's magazine describing the daily routine of an atypical housewife. No date available. page 4 SPONTANEOUS LIVING cont'd has work to do. She removes the dishes on her way out. I have work to do too. Once in a while I do it, but it seems a shame to spoil a beautiful evening with work. I can lie on my back and watch Jimmie spreading tools all over the living room floor and enjoy his preoccupation with frame making while the kitten chases the shavings. I can read and think up new and devastating points with which to confront Ruth if she comes over for lunch tomorrow. I can dream about the dear little babies God seems so slow in sending me. I can waste my time in all sorts of delightful ways. Someone will probably drop in for a hot drink about eleven o'clock. Someone always does. It seems to be a comfortable place to come to, worth the effort of clearing bits of lumber off a chair if Jimmie is feeling creative. My list reminds me that the floors need polishing, that there are socks to darn, that I haven't seen the bottom of my clothes basket for six months, but the flowers cast a lovely shadow on the wall and the kitten has curled up again in my arms. I'm too comfortable to move. I will remember on our way to bed that I still have to iron a shirt for Jimmy to wear tomorrow but I'm used to that and it will be dry by morning. I go to bed content. Let the other housekeepers cherish their schedules. Let them wash every Monday and iron on Tuesdays. Let hundreds of worthy women rise at seven o'clock to finish their housework by noon or know the reason why. I like the way I live. Once upon a time when the shades of such good housekeepers gathered round to reproach me I asked Jimmie humbly why he loved me, and now I know. "Because", he said "YOu're so dopey". Paper is yellowing, but otherwise in good condition.

CHILDHOOD Daddy was the engineer in charge of railways and bridges. One pretty little bridge that he had designed as well as supervised, spanned a waterway at Centre Island, close to where the ferry docked. Perhaps that is why we began to celebrate family birthdays at the island. On one such dayf before Daddy had joined us, a child fell into the lagoon near our picnic table. He couldn't swim, but Ken saw his flailing and jumped in to the rescue. His reward for heroism was the ordeal of travelling home by ferry and street car wrapped in Mother's ankle length sweater to cover his nakedness. Mother had her embarrassing moment on the street car one day when my clear childish treble asked her if the Holy Ghost wore a white sheet. We three children all went to Sunday School, at Saint Aidan's Anglican church on Queen Street until at five years of age I suddenly became a Presbyterian. On an especially important festival morning at Saint Aidan's the Sunday school children were taken up into the church for part of their program. Lacking a hat, I was turned away at the door and sent home. Mother's reaction was to take me over to the nearest competition, Kew Beach Presbyterian Church where, she assumed, the standards would be less ridiculous. However, the time came when I returned to St. Aidan's. The janitor at Kew Beach caught me stealing a good

I was ashamed ever to face him again, and made my own move back to join my brothers. This is my first public confession of this crime. We had moved to the Beach the year after it had become part of Toronto. Most of its homes had begun as summer cottages. None of the side roads were paved, but urbanization was proceeding at a great pace. New houses were springing up, and Mother and Daddy were looking for one. Sunday afternoons we went exploring the half-finished homes, climbing ladders to the second floor, comparing the floor plans, checking out the number of rooms. I did my own gleaning from the rubbish piles outside, finding beautiful little ceramic insulators and small blocks of wood just right for furnishing the doll's house that Daddy had helped me make out of a wooden box. In 1917 he and Mother settled on a house to buy. We were all around the dining-room table at a meal, when Daddy told us about it. "It's in the back yard of the big white house at the corner of Balsam and Pine", said Mother. "In the back yard?" I was appalled. I took my napkin ring to represent the yard, and put a crumb of bread in it. "You mean like that?" "Not quite", said Daddy. Indeed not quite like that, I discovered. Our back yard was deep enough for a pleasant lawn with a big family garden swing, and beyond that a vegetable plot for our victory garden. We were still at war. Across the fence the neighbours on the north had a lot that ran into the woods and down at the back all the way to the fourth pond. Up in the great oaks behind their house the twins had a tree loft, with a ladder up to it. And the twins were my age. What more could anyone want? Mother was a capable woman, well able to run a home smoothly, (still with wonderful Florrie) and fling herself into all kinds of outside war work. She was organizing tag days, singing with the Mendelssohn Choir in benefit concerts, knitting "comforts for the Boys", and moving steadily up in the hierarchy of the "Daughters of the Empire", or IODE as everyone called it. She was handsome, straight, somewhat heavy, ("Am I as fat as that woman, George?"), with presence. When she walked across the room it was like watching a ship in full sail. She had a strong sense of drama. After my morning cuddle in bed with both my parents, when Daddy had vanished to the bathroom, she would tell me a fairy story, and I would be there in the big bed, watching her dress. Her long hair, after its brushing, was divided into hanks, each one tied with a shoe lace, before being twisted up into the fashionable pile on the top of her head. On warm afternoons Polly was in the screened porch close to the street. Each man hurrying up Balsam Avenue after work was greeted with her raucus "Want a good dinner? Want a good dinner?" I liked best her self-taught imitation of Mother on the telephone. First the ring, two or three times, then "Hello?" then "Oh, Hel-lo!, rub-a-gub, rub-a-gub,rub-a-gub," long pause, then the very timbre of Mother's laughter, another pause, more rub-a-gub and eventually "Well Good-bye", in Mother's own lilt. Mother had been a professional singer in Montreal, soprano soloist in a big church on Sherbrooke Street, when Dad fell in love with her. She had won a scholarship to study opera in England, but her parents wouldn't or couldn't let her use it. A pity. Her voice was glorious, clear, true and strong. When I was playing with the Hoods down on McLean Avenue at supper time, Mother could walk to the top of the path through the woods to call me, and her voice carried the length of a city block. Besides, she had the temperament. My regret for her is tempered by the realization that her loss was my gain. I am very glad to have been born, and to have had such a father. The memory of the frustration she suffered at losing her chance for a career in music made her completely supportive of anything that had to do with my ambition to be an artist. good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-8 5 Mother's family had its roots in Quebec city where Great-Grandmother Hunter had landed from Ireland, eighteen years old, a "ward in Chancery" and, so the story goes, had arrived alone and terrified at the door of a lawyer's office and had fainted into the arms of the lawyer's clerk, John Hunter. Her photograph at age eighty shows a strong Irish face, direct, confident. Of her twenty-one pregnancies only three children survived to maturity. Her one daughter, Mother's mother, married Grandpa Moffatt and moved eventually to Montreal, followed by the Hunter sons, so that by this time most of Mother's relatives were living there. The year I was seven Mother took me to visit them all. Grandma's flat was a Victorian stage set, with antimacassars, upholstered chairs with silk swags and tassels and fringes, lace doilies, wonderful arrangements of waxen flowers inside oval glass domes. On her dressing table was a pair of little silver horses pulling a carriage made of mother-of-pearl with silver wheels. On my dining-room table seventy years later, is a silver butter dish with a silver cow lying on its lid, that I first saw on her table in Montreal. Grandfather had a stereoscope, a marvellous peep-show which you held up to look through. There was a lens for each eye offering its own version of a scene, taken from fractionally different angles. I remember best Niagara Falls, incredibly three-dimensional, and interesting to me because I knew that Mother and Daddy has started married life good

One of Mother's favourite stories was of the day Daddy took her in a bucket down the big shaft where the water would fall eventually, water that would generate power to make electricity for all southern Ontario. He had been assistant chief engineer for that first hydro-electic development. Ken was born there, and Mother used to shop across the bridge in the States and come home with her purchases hidden under Ken's baby clothes. Daddy would have stopped that in a hurry if he had known. Uncle Charlie Moffatt, Mother's important doctor-brother, and Aunt Mabel, his wife, were both overseas in the war. It must have been later that I visited them in a very splendid house, with a maid in a black dress and frilly white apron who served lunch, which Aunt Mabel called "luncheon". Grandpa took Mother and me on a steamship down the Saint Lawrence River to Quebec City. There was a big flat island in the middle of the river and it had a lot of cows on it. Then we took another big boat across the river to Levis, and walked with Grandpa up a steep hill to a house that had its kitchen and its dining room in the basement underneath the parlor. Aunt Tilly and Aunt Pussy lived there with two other ladies who were their daughters, and were said to be some kind of cousins of mine. The time came when that Levis house was my stop-over on the way to the Gaspe painting ground, with one of the dear old aunties still there to welcome me, and the cousins full of interest in showing me historic Quebec. good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-8 7 Sometime that next winter Florrie had to leave us. She had "taken service" to help her sister and brother tide over the years while they were all waiting for their apple orchard in the Okanagan Valley to reach maturity and start bearing apples. That time had come, and she was needed out west. We never forgot her. Every Christmas she sent us a loving letter full of news of the orchard and a big box of home-made chocolates. On my bedroom wall I had her photograph in a little silver frame. When I visited her twenty years later on my first trip west/ she looked just like that photograph, but instead of the tall woman I remembered, I found a little person who came hardly above my shoulder. I don't know which of us was happier to see the other. In the fall of 1918 there was the Sunday of the false alarm, when all the bells in Toronto rang for the end of the war, and then we found that it was not yet true. But the armistice came soon after, and I was taken uptown to the front porch of a house on University Avenue to see the Victory Parade, with broad ranks of men in khaki marching down the wide street, and everyone on the sidewalk waving flags and shouting and crying. The incident that underlined for me the return of peace was the Sunday morning that I went in to the kitchen where Mother was getting dinner. There was a pot on the stove, tightly covered. FIRST LIGHT Chicks - running about on the ground - their bright yellow feathers sticking up in all directions - or are those the toy chicks that appeared in the shops at Easter, with wire legs that you could bend to make them stand up? Was it the toy chicks later on that reminded me of my first real fluffy chicks that ran around on the ground? Mother said the real ones must have been at Mr. Cousins1 farm outside Vancouver where we were living the summer I turned two. The gulls I remember, hanging motionless in the air as they floated behind the ferry, but turning their heads from side to side as they watched for the bits of bread someone was throwing. That could have been Vancouver, or Berkeley, California. Before we got to California we stayed for weeks in a hotel in Boise, Idaho. We were there for Christmas and for my first remembered experience of inconsolable sorrow. It was brand new. Santa Claus had brought it just that morning, a doll made of blue cloth with a celluloid head - and the little girl who lived down the hall broke it. I am still running screaming up the corridor to Mother. It is a frozen clamorous moment. Similarly frozen, but without emotion, is my pause on the cellar stairs in the Berkeley house, conscious that it was my third birthday. Why the cellar stairs? Why do I remember that I was on my way down? What had a three-year old to do with the good

Sometime that summer my father's employers went bankrupt, ending the California interlude, and Grandfather McCarthy back in Moncton was so gravely ill that Dad took us all east to the old family home to see him. The simple two-story frame house was familiar, just like its photograph that hung on the wall wherever we went. But the big poplars at the gate had been cut off at shoulder height. While we were visiting, someone took a snapshot of one of them with Dougie and me perched on top, squinting into the sun, and Kenneth, our eleven year old brother standing behind us. I suspect that we three lived, not at the old King Street home behind the poplar stumps, but at Aunt Adelaide's big house on the hill. Uncle Matthew Lodge, her husband, was a big bluff, expansive sort of uncle, whose later visits to us in Toronto were notable for the doll he always brought for me, and the pervasive smell of cigar smoke that lingered the next day. Twenty years later, after my father's death, when Mother sent me back to Moncton to meet his people, it was again in the big house on the hill that I stayed. Three of his sisters were together in it. She had been a young teacher, engaged to be married to an equally young clergyman, when Grandmother McCarthy became an invalid after my father's birth. She gave up her marriage to look after her mother and the smaller children. It was she who encouraged Dad to get an education and the first university degree in the family. She and her young clergyman wrote regularly to each other for the rest of their lives and neither married. Dad had for her a fierce loyalty, and had taught me to look on her as his real mother. She sent me Christmas and birthday presents which, I was brought up to realize, demanded a thank-you letter. Through the years we had corresponded, but even so I was unprepared for the diminutive and dynamic old lady who was at that time following avidly the radio broadcasts of the Allan Cup series. Moncton was in the hockey finals, and she knew every player by name. The third sister, "Aunt Fon" lived with the disgrace of her daughter's un-married pregnancy twenty years before, which was as palpably present as was poor Aunt Fon herself. She took me to meet the disgraced daughter and the seducer who had been compelled to marry her. We all put on a gallant show, but it was not an exhilarating occasion. Roy's belly overhung his pants. His vulgarity was as evident as his curly red hair. Privately I thought him a fat boor, and my heart ached for both the women. The illegitimate child, a fine promising lad I was told, had been killed by a gun accident at sixteen. good

By Christmas of 1914 Dad was a city engineer with the works department of Toronto and we were in a house on Sherbourne Street. One cold dark morning in November, Eaton's delivery man brought a doll's sleigh to the front door, to my delight but to Mother's dismay. I accepted her hasty explanation that it had come to our house by mistake, and I have forgotten what I thought when it re-appeared on Christmas morning. Each of Eaton's red and blue wagons was pulled by a pair of beautiful matched dappled grey and white horses. The delivery man who drove them became a friend, calling two or three times a week, bringing in the parcels without waiting to be admitted, knowing everyone's name. The morning parade of Eaton's wagons leaving the Bay street stables was one of the sights of Toronto. The beasutiful grey teams trotted up Bay Street in smooth sequence, until the ones bound east and west turned off and went their own ways. Daddy teased Mother by telling her that he took his cheque at the City Hall on pay day and walked across the street to put it in his Eatons Deposit Account. No McCarthy bought anything on credit. Summer of 1914 saw us in a cottage at Long Branch. Now the memories crowd. Before breakfast Daddy would be over in the dewy grass of the bowling green across the road, picking mushrooms which were cooked with the bacon for breakfast. I was a fairy at the masquerade that was held by the summer residents, dressed in pink tarlatan with wings that were stiffened with a wire frame. Helen Halford was a matching blue fairy. When the families were visiting together he would make faces, indescribably grotesque and funny, which sent us into gales of laughter. When summer was over and both families were back in Toronto, I was allowed to make my first-ever telephone call to him. We were friends. Florrie was with us. She was Mother's "help" who had become part of the family as far back as Vancouver, and was a second mother to us. It was she who filled the big galvanized iron tub with water for the Saturday night bath that I shared with Dougie. She read us the "Uncle Wiggley" stories that appeared every night in the "Evening Telegram" which Daddy carried home with him on the train. Was it Daddy or "Uncle Wiggley" that I was waiting for, the day that I disappeared from the house and was found sitting on the railway track? There was a spectacular thunder storm one night, with lightning snaking down over the lake and cracks of thunder to shake the cottage. Daddy took me in his arms out on to the verandah and showed it to me, holding me tight and secure. I have not been afraid of storms since that day. And it was that summer that I recall interrupting Mother's tea party to have her pull my panties back up after I had, successfully, gone to the toilet all by myself. When we had played there long enough, we went down to the table beside the lake where Mother and Florrie were getting supper ready for Daddy's arrival after work. MARJORIE One Saturday in August of 1918 a new family moved in to the big white house next door to us. We saw the furniture being unloaded and carried up the walk, and later there was a small boy running around, and two girls. But it was not until Sunday afternoon that I had a chance to speak to one of them. A Salvation Army band had paused in front of their house on the corner of Pine Avenue and Balsam. Two "Sally Anns" in their trim navy uniforms and bonnets, and three men with instruments were giving a rousing concert of hymns, lively enough to set toes tapping and tempt you to sing along. But some rowdy boys, whom I had never seen before, were across the road, jeering and yelling at them rudely. A fair, pretty girl who seemed to be about Doug's age, came out of the big white house, and stood watching. I seized my opportunity. "Aren't they awful?" I ventured. "They're terrible", she agreed, and told me that her name was Eleanor Beer. While we were still exchanging tentative introductions, her younger sister joined us rather shyly. Marjorie and I have often regretted that neither of us could remember what we said to one another. I suspect that our deathless words were "Hello". "Hello". Years afterwards we worked out the exact date, and from then on celebrated the anniversary of our meeting as an annual thanksgiving day in our good

At eight and nine we were still children, pleased to find someone who liked the same books, mutually in love with Anne of Green Gables and still with secret loyalty to our out-grown dolls. We were in the same grade at school but, alas, in different schools. This made Saturdays even more precious. We had picnics together on the little side porch of the big house. Marjorie's bedroom window faced mine, and we contrived a private wake-up signal to give us some time together before breakfast. We had a string, long enough to stretch from window to window, and each of us tied an end to her big toe. The first to waken after daylight gave a tug. We went to the window to acknowledge the signal, and the morning was ours! My parents were pleased with the friendship. Perhaps I would stay home instead of always running off to McLean Avenue. Marjorie's father was a doctor who had been with the army in England and France, and Mother admired doctors, especially one who had been in the war. Dr. Beer was still in active service, but stationed in Toronto. He was called for every morning by a uniformed driver in an automobile. This was a matter of some pride, for motor cars were still so uncommon that whenever one came up Balsam Avenue everyone's head turned to watch. The Beers found us to be good neighbours, and encouraged our growing intimacy. We discovered an entrance to the crawl space under the verandah that ran on two sides of the big house, and we used to creep in there on our hands and knees and sit in the dark corner nearest my house, smoking dry oak leaves in acorn pipes, being tough characters called Jake and Bill. It was from that refuge that we overheard our mothers agreeing that we would both benefit from taking ballet lessons and that we should be enrolled in a Saturday morning class up at "Margaret Eaton". Our mirth at the idea of our trying to be ballet-dancers was matched by our delight at the prospect of travelling to town together every week. We went west on the Queen Street car, and transferred to the "Belt Line" which took us up to Bloor. The cars were closed, each with a coal stove down at one end to keep it warm in winter. The conductor sat on a high perch in the centre, collecting fares. The trip was endlessly interesting, passing our own Beaches library and Kew Gardens with the real skating rink that was better than the pond, taking us past the race track where you could sometimes see horses running, past the big brick house with the wonderful garden where the Ashbridge family still lived. We took the five or six dollars we earned up to the "Home for Incurable Children" and were taken through the hospital. I am still haunted by the image of those tots with heads enlarged to monstrous size. In March, Daddy and Mother were called into conference with the school principal and my teacher. "Doris was idling, not being sufficiently challenged". It was recommended that I be advanced to entrance class. Once again we were separated during school hours, but together so happily at all other times that Marjorie-and-Doris became almost one word to our schoolmates. We were both instinctive actors, and loved to tease, and once that spring, we thought it would be a great joke on everyone to pretend that we had had a "fight" and were not speaking to each other. Such tiffs were a commonplace in our age group, but we knew that one between us would be an astonishment and an embarrassment to our circle. What fun! We talked it over, giggling, imagining what we would say, how we should act, and then knew that we would do no such thing. Our friendship was sacred and we could not desecrate it. That would be the sin against the Holy Spirit for which there was no forgiveness. My advance to high school was momentous in some ways but it hardly rippled the surface of our life together. We both intended to become great authors, and each of us had in the works several short stories and at least one full length novel. Two weeks after I had won the Junior Oratorical contest at Malvern Collegiate, Marjorie won the Senior Oratorical at Williamson Road. We published regularly (for each other) a newspaper called Passe Don Veul, a name without meaning but with a French ring to our ears. On New Year's Day, 1922 each of us began to keep a diary. SILVER ISLAND Eden to me is the ten acre island in Muskoka with the cottage that we first rented for the first time in the summer of 1922. Doug and I were involved in that rental, because Mr. Ferrier, who owned the island and spent his own summer in the other cottage there, was understood to be very particular about whom he rented it to, and was coming all the way from Mimico on the other side of Toronto, to the Beach, to look us over. Mr. Ferrier was known to be the superintendant of the Mimico Industrial School (for bad boys), a formidable person. Doug and I were instructed to call him "Sir". It is the only time in my whole childhood that I can recall being briefed about "company manners". We were careful to be very polite to the tall stout stranger. He had brought a snap-shot showing the little cottage almost hidden by trees. And he told Mother and Daddy about the safe sandy beach and the good drinking water that you got from the well by lowering a bucket on a rope. He explained that the Supply Boat called once a week to sell fresh fruit and vegetables, and that you could get milk from the farmer who lived on the mainland when you rowed to Mortimer's Point for the mail. Eddie Mortimer had the cows, and he also had the launch that would bring us from the station. We were accepted! The best of all was that Marjorie was coming too. Dr. Beer wanted to take Mrs. Beer to England and show her all the good

We could hardly believe in such bliss. The two mothers employed Mrs. Bennett, the enormously stout dressmaker who lived down on Spruce Hill Road with her two little white poodles, to make us "play suits". These consisted of knee-length black sateen bloomers and short black sateen tunics as shapeless as-the two little girls wearing them. They had square necklines bordered with a two inch band of coloured cretonne, pink for Marjorie, blue for me. No bride looks at her trousseau with more pride than we felt in these creations. Dr. Beer drove Mother and Marjorie and me to the Don Station. Daddy and Doug had gone with the canoe and the trunk in Mr. Oliphant's truck, and were already there on the platform standing guard over the luggage. Daddy's two weeks of holidays were not due until August, but he was taking a weekend to see us settled and then coming back to Toronto. My most vivid memory of the trip itself is green plush upholstery in the coach and the smell of dust and coal smoke mingled with the pungency of the sardine sandwitches and oranges that Mother had packed for our lunch. I remember also that Daddy got off the train at every stop and walked along the platform to the baggage car to be sure that the canoe was still safe. Our summer's supply of groceries had arrived from Eatons. Now, if only Eddie Mortimer would come too! It was hot. We were tired and sticky after the long train trip. And there was no sign of anyone looking for us. But the wait was not without drama. There was a lady, (dare I call her that?) sitting on one of the posts on the dock, and she was SMOKING. I was too embarrassed to stare, but there was no doubt about it. I had never before seen such a thing. An open launch rounded the point and came towards us, with a tall lean man in the front, tanned and wind-blown. Daddy had taught me to paddle, and I was used to a canoe and a row-boat, but this was my first time in a motorboat. We watched Eddie start the engine with a crank, just like a car, and suddenly we were moving, faster and faster. Marjorie and I sat side by side squeezing each other's hand, speechless with excitement. Half an hour later we could see ahead of us broken shapes that meant islands. "That's her", shouted Eddie above the noise of the water and the engine. He was pointing to the largest island, the one with one tall pine tree towering above all the wooded shoreline. When we were not around it we were on the porch that fronted the livingroom, or in the lake. Or exploring the island. Marjorie and I discovered the big pine that we had seen from the launch. We named it "Spy Glass" and buried at its foot a bottle in which we secreted a letter to be opened by the finder in 1937, an unimaginably distant future. The trail to the tennis court which Irene had cleared in the centre of the island, was lined with hemlock undergrowth, fragrant. Marjorie said the smell reminded her of muffins, so it became the "Muffin Path". Beyond the tennis court the trail led to the other side of the island, and to the Other Cottage. We came to realize that Mr. Ferrier regretted ever having sold even one lot, but Marjorie and I found the widow who lived there with her teen-age son very cordial. She invited the whole family over one evening to hear our very first "tube" radio. It had a loud speaker, and we could all listen to it without earphones. Behind the Ferrier cottage was another bay with a dock much larger that the one in front. The water was very deep around it, and Mother soon discovered that it was the place to fish. It was not as large as the Sagamo or the Ahmic, but it was as big inside as a shop, and we would carry baskets of vegetables and fruit back to the cottage after each visit. Marjorie had been named by Mother "Queen of the Pantry", so she was in charge of stowing it all. We had a cooler, a room that had been built into the side of the slope below the cottage. It was as cold as any cave, and kept things fresh without ice. Milk we stored on the front porch, in a granite milk tin wrapped in a cloth that was kept wet by sitting it in water. Shade and wind chilled it constantly. That was the summer that we learned to dive, spending hours in and out of the lake, groping along the sandy bottom after the metal ring we used as a lure, dumping the canoe and climbing back into it. We felt like fish. At the beginning of the summer we rowed for the milk and the mail, but by August, if the evening was calm, we were allowed to go by canoe. We came home as the sun was low, paddling towards the great early star in the south west which I still think of as "Goldie". Doug's friend, Laurie Bullen, was up for a few weeks. The two boys, emboldened by mutual support, began paying court to "Miss Harriman", a pretty American university student who was a guest at Dunbarton, the island opposite us. And then there were family games, all the pencil games we knew, and "Hearts", that poor relation of Bridge. Mother once offered a chocolate bar as a prize for the winner, but quickly withdrew the offer as she wondered if it might teach us to "gamble". The little cottage rocked with laughter. There were evenings when Mother feared that our hilarity might carry as far as the Ferrier cottage. Marjorie and I were used to slipping into many roles with each other. One of us would assume a voice, and the other pick up the cue. Sometimes we were Bill and Jake, ruffians who lived in the mountains. Often she was "Teddy", Edward Prince of Wales, and I was a lady of the court. We were avid collectors of photographs and clippings about royalty. We played our future Us, in which we were famous authors, exchanging gossip about our latest novels and what we imagined about the world of publishing. That was the summer after our play that had been produced, had been printed in the I.O.D.E. magazine, due undoubtedly to my mother's inside track. We read together. Marjorie had been given Anne's House of Dreams for her birthday and we read David Copperfield that summer, not aloud, but keeping up with each other so that we could "discuss" each incident and character. I remember doing Marjorie's chores for her one morning to give her a chance to "catch up". good

There were famous names up and down the mainland near us, Endicott, Moore, Rogers. But since there was only one little church in the whole district and that Anglican, every Sunday evening one of the cottages became the gathering point for a "Song Service". People came in all manner of craft. Most of them left their boats at the dock and carried cushions up to the verandah, but some stayed on the water, adding what Marjorie and I considered a romantic dimension to the scene. There were hymn books enough for everyone. Irene Ferrier played an auto-harp when there was no piano or parlor pump-organ. Mother loved it, and her golden voice poured like honey over the water. As we left for home in the deepening dark, the lake was dotted with lights from the small craft going their separate ways, and Mother was still humming "Now God be with you till we meet again". Our hopes for a second summer at Silver Island hung all spring on Ken's results. He had come home from his university exams in despair, and if he had to write a "supp" in the fall there would be no cottage for us. On Friday, June 1, 1923, I wrote in my diary. "M. and I came home from school today and, each having a lilac bloom, decided to tie it to our little bush to fool Mother. "What part of Bala Park?', she asked and he answered, 'Silver Island' . "The Ferriers were in another carriage, and our reunion with them made the trip go quickly. Marjorie and I were ecstatic. Her grandparents came up for a visit and Daddy was with us for his holidays. I note. "We went in swimming shortly after, and Daddy was surprised to see us dive. Two of my paintings of it have survived. 111 painted a number of pictures of Dunbarten and they are a great improvement on last years", I wrote in 1923. We had four summers there before Dad found a cottage to buy, in a different part of Muskoka. During the third summer Mother was struggling with ill health. She sent Marjorie and me, Doug and his friend Harvey Graham, up with a chaperone, our beloved music teacher and friend, Eleanor Baskerville. "Aunt Nell" was a tiny hunch-backed woman who had been Marjorie's homeroom teacher in her last year at public school. She was full of play, and gave us a merry fortnight before Mother came up to take over. The last summer at Silver Island, I had to be content with someone else as my special companion. Marjorie was out west experiencing for the first time the joys of a girls' camp. Life changed. There were new worlds. It was almost fifteen years later that Mrs Beer, now widowed, rented a cottage near the one Dad had bought, and the two families shared a summer in a different part of Muskoka. GROWING One Sunday afternoon when I was eleven, Daddy invited me to come with him for a paddle on Lake Ontario, and to pack a supper so that we could go a bit further than if we had to be home for tea. I leapt at the chance - my first time with the full responsibility of being his bow paddler, and the full privilege of his companionship. The canoe was kept in a boathouse at the foot of Fernwood Park Avenue, but we had to bring the paddles and cushions from home as well as the basket that Mother had packed for our picnic. I was proud to be lifting my end of the canoe down from the rack and helping to carry it across to the water's edge to launch it. There was very little wind, hardly enough for the one or two sail boats that were out in the lake beyond us. We paddled east, with the sun behind us, past the Balmy Beach Canoe Club, past the Fallingbrook area which was still all wooded, past the Hunt Club which had for us such glamorous memories of Christmases past. Daddy and Mother and Kenneth used to be invited to a big family Christmas dinner there every year. Grandma Moffatt's cousin was married to Captain Trowell who was the Secretary, and who had the privilege of using the club house and staff for his own Christmas party. For the last two years before he retired, Doug and I had been considered old enough, and had been included. good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-10 2 There had been a baronial dining room, a table to seat thirty, silver shining, glassware sparkling, a huge fire blazing on a hearth at one end of the room. For me, the two most exciting features had been the row of waiters in uniform, standing behind us, and ginger ale to drink, as common as milk. The first year that I was invited, I drank the ginger ale so eagerly that I had room for nothing else. The next time saw me wiser, and I was able to last even to the marvel of the Baked Alaska, an undreamed-of sophistication. Daddy danced with me after dinner, and Ken once, and big Harry Trowell, and there was a Paul Jones to mix everyone up, and the older ladies and gentlemen were in another room playing cards. Afterwards, for the McCarthys, there was a long walk home in the snowy cold, upheld by the excitement of the whole wonderful Christmas that lay behind us. Beyond the Hunt Club, Scarborough Bluffs became bare and sculptural, eroded into sharp peaks, and cut with ravines. In those days there was no Bluffers' Park, no marina, no land except the narrow strip of beach, and we paddled close to the shore, watching for birds. We came at last to the remains of the old lake freighter, the "Alexandra", that had foundered at the end of the war in a violent autumn storm. Rumour claimed that she was worn out and heavily insured. She ran aground and broke up, and her cargo of canned goods, minus their labels, was washed up and strewn for most of a mile along the shore. Gulls flew from it as we paddled towards it. We circled it curiously, then agreed to land on the beach near it, where a deep ravine came down to the shore. We had our picnic there on the sand, building a little fire just for the fun of it. When the sun had dropped behind the top of the bluffs, and the air grew cooler, we packed up and took to the water again, far enough out from shore to feel the sun's warmth as we paddled home. It was the first time I had known my father as a friend. This was the fall that I entered high school. Doug was already at Malvern, and although Ken was now at university in Pre-Meds, he was well remembered there. When he was in third form, Mother had been out on the front lawn sweeping up leaves one afternoon when Mr. Graham, the chemistry teacher, came down the street on his way home. "Good afternoon, Mrs. McCarthy. Would you like to know where your son is?" "Well, where is he then?" "He is in the chemistry lab, down on his hands and knees scrubbing the floor. I wish I could hang him from the ceiling too." "Whatever happened?" asked Mother. Mr. Graham laughed. "He tried an independent experiment with some chemicals in his ink-well, and he's cleaning up the results of the explosion". good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-10 4 The blue splotch was still on the ceiling when Doug and I graduated, but poor Mr. Graham was killed by an automobile as he was crossing the street towards the school, the year that he was my home form master. It was my first personal contact with death. He was old (probably in his fifties), with silvery hair, but we had respected and liked him and we were all shocked. It was his wife who had directed our play at St. Aidan's, and his son Harvey was Doug's friend. Mother moved down into the Graham house to help Mrs. Graham through the days before the funeral. It was still the custom to set up the open casket in the living room, marking the front door with a wreath hung with purple or black ribbon, and to receive friends and neighbours at home. On one of those days Mother asked me to bring something down to her. I have forgotten what it was, but I have never forgotten my cold horror when she asked me if I would like to come in and "see Mr. Graham?" I couldn't speak. I shook my head and turned back up the hill, blinded with tears, not of grief but of terror at the thought of looking at a dead person. Less dreadful than death to me, but more mysterious, was birth. Mother had prepared me for menstruation by a little talk one day when I was home from school and in bed with a cold. She explained that when a woman was married, God planted a seed in her which grew to be a baby, and that the womb had to be kept ready for this great event by a monthly house-cleaning. Marjorie was thrilled. When I talked to Mother about it, she said she thought it was "disgusting!" "But Mother", I protested, "You said you couldn't help it if you were married". "You can help it if you want to", said Mother stiffly. Marjorie and I spent many hours that autumn, wondering to each other how it all happened, and how the baby got out. Eventually her doctor-father put into her hands "Men, Women and God", a book that told us the facts at long last, and convinced us that life was even more wonderful and beautiful that we could have imagined. Poor Mother. It is a great pity that she didn't have such a book when she was young. Poor Daddy too. It must have been rough being married to a beautiful, spirited girl with twisted Victorian ideas about sex. Kenneth was a clever cartoonist who drew for me, in an exercise book, silly pictures of such topical subjects as "Doris practising the piano", himself executing a whirl-about on skates, a golfer all twisted up in his clubs. I then painted them. He was studying medicine, but spending too much of his time being art editor of "The Goblin", a magazine published by the students. He was also in the thick of "Daffydill Night", an annual evening of skits put on by the Faculty of Medicine. We attended as a family, proud of his prominence if somewhat doubtful of the quality of the undergraduate humour. By this time he was "getting serious" with Bettyf whom he had taken out all through high school and kept in the field even while he took out other girls in college. Betty Caswell was a neighbour, and had become a librarian at the Beaches Library. We all loved her, and found her easier to know than Ken. But we didn't betray him on the day that Betty came with us across to Niagara on the Cayuga, while Ken was a deck steward on it and had one of his other girls on board. He managed to keep the two girls on different decks and do his job too. He did some fancy footwork that day. Betty gave me my first paid job, a session after school sorting books and replacing them on shelves, rewarded with an envelope containing my wages, twenty-five cents. I kept that coin for a long time. It was too precious to spend. Much the same feeling must have moved Dad to ask for his first pay in gold, and then to have it made into Mother's wedding ring. While I was at Malvern, Dad took me one night to hear Jack Miner and see slides of the refuge for Canada geese that he had established at his home in Kingsville. Dad was one of the early conservationists. He belonged to an organization called "Men of the Trees", dedicated to planting rather than cutting. The McCarthys never had a Christmas tree. A row of stockings along the fireplace was our substitute. More surprising, in retrospect, was the night that he invited me, at the last minute, to the Royal Alec to see Walter Hampden in Hamlet. What a performance! The audience was spellbound, and I felt that I had discovered a new dimension of my father. Doug and Eleanor were ahead of us at Malvern and part of a group of young people that gave grown-up parties to which Marjorie and I, as younger sisters, were sometimes invited. This group became very good friends and began pairing off by the time they were in Fourth Form. When the school dances were held they were already in couples. Not so with Marjorie and me. In our crowd there was tremendous ferment for weeks ahead, with speculation as to who would invite whom, and much secret anxiety. No self-respecting girl made the advances, at least according to Mother. If an invitation was proffered, awkwardly during some chance encounter as the classes passed each other in the hall between periods, or at noon hour during the brief lunch break, the level of anxiety stepped up sharply. What to wear? How to dance without falling all over his feet? What to talk about? The conventions demanded that the boy call for his girl and walk her to the dance. Once there, he was responsible for filling her programme. These programmes were folders decorated with ribbons of the Malvern colours, red and black, and printed inside with twenty numbered lines, one labelled "supper dance". Of course they traded. "You give me one and I'll take one of yours". If he returned to me before the first dance still with many blanks on the program, I wanted to die. Instead, I kept the bright smile on my face and with body as tense as my emotions, held out my arms to receive him. We danced with my hand on his shoulder, his around my back to guide me, and our other two hands clasped and held stiffly out to the side. "I'm sorry", as one of us stepped on the other's foot. "Oh, that was my fault". I suppose we did sometimes have other things to say to each other. I made a tremendous investment in a school dance. My hair would be "marcelled" for the occasion, and I would be in my very best sleeveless silk dress, belted fashionably around the hips, bust as flat as binding could make it. By the time I was in third form, and being invited, the short skirts of the early twenties were lengthening. At least I was spared the former agony of wondering if the tops of my stockings and my garters were showing at the back when I raised my arms. This was long before panty-hose. There was a brief-lived fashion that year of wearing a bright little silk handkerchief held by a ribbon tied around the ankle. What a relief when my partner was Laurie. The walk home was better because it was apt to be in gaggles of couples whose ways lay together. And there was no thought of good-night kisses or of inviting him in to prolong the ordeal. We had both "had a lot of fun, thanks very much". Sometimes Mother had been there as a chaperone among the row of adults parked on chairs along the edge of the dance floor. When I came in, she was predictably critical of the music, of the way the boys danced these days and of my hair. School dances are among the few nightmares of my youth. The first year we took holidays in the old cottage Dad had bought, he and I re-shingled the roof. It was much later that we learned that we had been a sensation to the boys at the mill. I think they expected to see us afloat, each clinging to a bundle of shingles. We were up there by nine in the morning. Mother would come out in to the sunshine and hang up a washing, with a word of praise for our progress, and some consultation about lunch. She used to buy fresh stewing lamb from the local farmer, and throw in with it onions, carrots, potatoes, whatever, until she had a fine big potfull which she hoped would last for a couple of days. Dad and I would come down ravenous and polish it off. By four in the afternoon I had had it, and climbed down for a swim and a leisurely removal of slivers from my poor legs and seat. How those shingles splintered! Dad stayed up until he was called for supper, and sometimes put in another hour or two before dark. I used to marvel at his will to stay with it. Now I know, myself, the pull of a job like that. When I built my own house on Scarborough Bluffs I would be still working when I could no longer see what I was doing. We promised ourselves a holiday together when we had made the cottage habitable, a week's canoe trip with a tent somewhere, perhaps down the Moon River to Georgian Bay. I think it is the only promise that Dad broke in his whole life. good

Even now, sixty years later, I am not sure how objectively I can look back on the teens. Rapture was commonplace, and although I seldom experience the same intensity of joy now, nothing in my life since then denies the reality of the emotions of those days, or the truth of the insights we learned. Marjorie came back from her camp in the Okanagan with stars in her eyes and a vision of girls around the world joining hands in a fellowship of love and understanding. She was in love with the leader who had shown her this dream and with the teen-agers who had shared it with her. She had became part of the Canadian Girls in Training, CGIT. This was a Canada-wide experiment that the churches were making in the belief that a small group of girls with an adult leader, who would study the Bible together on Sunday, and work and play together during the week, could find out what Christianity was all about, and how to live it. Marjorie's home church was Beech Avenue Methodist Church, and she was soon deeply involved in its CGIT. I was on the edge, getting to know the other members of her group and painting scenery for their production of a Christmas play. Normandale, on a cliff above Lake Erie, was a big field rising to a long hill that held the wooden dining pavilion, known as the "shack". Further along the hillside was "Round Top", the treed knoll where we sat on the grass for worship services and study groups. On the other side of the dining hall was a tall flag-pole, with space around it for all sixty of us to stand in a circle for the morning ceremonial of flag-raising and saying together the Salutation to the Dawn.

The sun shone more brilliantly at Normandale than anywhere else in the world. God was among us. We separated after flag-raising and each of us went by herself to some special spot she had chosen for "Morning Watch", the twenty minutes of solitude with a little book that helped you to find ways to think about God and say "thank You" for the love and beauty surrounding you. Through all the fun, the meals punctuated by song, the shared interests and delights of the day, you knew that you were united in loyalty to the best and highest that you could imagine. And the daily Bible study was a chance to stretch your imagination to glimpse what Jesus meant when he talked about the Kingdom of Heaven. For ten days we tasted the sweetness of the Presence of God. This period between the two great world wars was in some ways unique. We sincerely believed that the 1914-18 horror had been a "war to end war", and that the League of Nations was the new way for the world to settle all disputes. Just as the nineteenth century had abolished slavery forever, so the twentieth had ended war. Mother's generation had achieved the vote for women, so that universal suffrage was taken for granted. Canada was a peaceful country where men, women and even children could walk safely in the day and at night. We had grown up in "Prohibition", and alcohol was not a factor in our lives. I prayed sincerely to be delivered from them. Jealousy, which I recognized as a sin, was probably my greatest temptation. Marjorie's world was expanding daily, bringing her close to national and provincial leaders, young women of god-like glamour to us all. Marjorie loved them at sight, and was able to express her love with such spontaneous simplicity that they in turn welcomed her into their personal lives as well as into their work. There were times when I felt that she had left me far behind. We both complained that "we never saw each other". Early in the spring we had planned an "Adventure" for after camp, a week together in the country, reading, walking, catching up. I look back on those first three years of our group life as a hectic time in which Tuesday evening came rushing along with unnatural frequency. It was always Tuesday evening! As the years went by the older girls graduated into leadership and formed groups of their own of the younger teenagers at the church. The weekend camp in May became an annual event, including the younger groups, growing until there were over fifty girls and four or five leaders. We did our share in inter-church activities, and many of us went on to provincial leadership camps, Beausoleil Island in Georgian Bay or Beau Rivage among the islands in the St. Lawrence. What a pleasure to wake up in a bedding roll under the trees, to sit up and see across the grass the tousled heads of Edie and Madeline, two of my "own children", emerging from their bedding rolls, ready for another day of the shared heights. But by far the most important cross-fertilization was an influence that came from the university down into CGIT. Dr. Henry Burton Sharman was a radical and inspiring teacher from the States who shook up the thinking of a generation of students. He introduced a method of Bible study based on the same kind of close textual examination that was becoming common in literary criticism. He asked the young people to leave their theological ideas at the door, and read the gospel stories with an open mind. He had published a study guide which offered searching questions and provided no answers. This was used in the camp study groups. We had to find our answers in the texts, to compare the accounts of the life of Jesus in the four gospels, and to ask why they were sometimes the same and sometimes different. I began to realize how it was that the disciples, ordinary, rough, working men, Jews, who had met Jesus and got to know him as a man, came to believe that he was more than that, unlike what they had expected and yet the true fulfillment of all their hopes. For the first time in my life I understood how the disciples and the early church had struggled to find language to say what they had come to feel about Jesus. I remember the liberation I experienced the day Jessie Mac, "Big Chief", discussing the feeding of the five thousand, admitted to us that she thought it quite possible that after the young lad offered his loaves of bread and five small fishes, everyone dug into his pocket and pulled out the bit of cheese, the fruit, the leg of chicken or whatever was buried there, and that the real miracle was the joyful sharing that Jesus inspired. Just as when he said to the sea of Galilee "Peace, be still", it was the panic of the disciples that subsided, and that they remembered afterwards as a sudden stillness of the waves. The great gift of those camps was being able to sing the emotion, to ritualize the love that we felt in the camp circle. One ceremony that was used very often was a torchlight service, with fire as a symbol of God's holy spirit. On the last night, after the sing-song, the games, the final announcements or whatever, each camper was given a bullrush torch. The first one was lit from the central campfire, and carried back to the circle to light the next, and the light passed from torch to torch, while we sang the first verses of the hymn "0 Love that wilt not let me go". ART SCHOOL When I was in my last year at Malvern I went every Saturday morning to the Ontario College of Art to what they called the Junior Course, a sort of introductory experience for high school students. I don't think anyone at the college tried to teach us anything. They were talent-spotting. We were encouraged, rather than taught, which I found disappointing. The only light I gained from those Saturday mornings was the difference between warm and cool colour. Miss Coombs, who was left in charge of the class after Mr. Lismer had given us the pep talk of the day, suggested to me that the grey I had used was "too cool". I looked my bewilderment, and she explained that first fragment of professional vocabulary. At the end of the term, early in May, the College held an assembly for all the students and their parents and friends, at which time the walls would be hung with the best work of the year, and the "results" would be announced. I was hoping to be one of the Juniors chosen to take a second year of Saturday morning classes. Mother and Dad came with me, and were pleased to find that two of my paintings were up on the wall. George Reid, the Principal, welcomed the guests with a rather prosy speech. Then Arthur Lismer, who was vice-principal, talked about the Saturday morning classes, and made characteristic sly jokes about young people becoming artists, and went on to announce that the one full-time day scholarship had been won by Miss Doris McCarthy. I sat there stunned. I don't know what was done or said for the rest of the evening. Mother and Dad were pleased but somewhat taken aback. They accepted me as talented, but we had all expected that I would go on to university and teach English in a high school, perhaps writing eventually. Since I was still just fifteen, too young for entering that stream, next year had been a big question mark. By the end of the long streetcar ride home to the Beach the decision had been made. "0 God! How wonderful!" There was an older woman in the first year with us, Edna Breithaupt, from Kitchener. She offered her cottage on the Grand River near Kitchener as a headquarters for a sketching house-party at the end of term. About twelve of us were able to go, and we engaged Yvonne McKague to be our resident teacher. She was Arthur Lismer's assistant at the College, and one of those rare people whose presence turns the lights on. They formed themselves into the "Toronto Art Students League", rented the small house that stood in the corner of Grange Park, and began a regime of self-run classes. I longed to be with them. I had won further scholarships, complete tuition for the following year, but my heart was with the League. Dad and I talked it over. He left me to make the decision, but helped me to realize that if I ever wanted to teach art in the school system, my degree from the college would be important. I went back to go on with my course, although feeling that the life had gone out of my old world. But I had not known that Ethel Curry would be appearing at the college after an interval away, and entering the second year. She was a wisp of a girl from Haliburton, eight years older than I, quiet, self-contained, a "lass with a delicate air", beautiful. The McCarthys had once spent a holiday at Robertson's boarding house on Lake Kashagawigamog, near Haliburton, and Ethel knew the Robertsons, and immediately shared for me the glamour of that wonderful fortnight. We became friends. She had a room on St. George Street and a talent for homemaking. A fire in the old Victorian fireplace, the rented furniture transformed with coloured throws and cushions, candles and flowers, made it a gathering place for the serious students. And we talked long over Curry's coffee and sandwiches. The next year Ethel invited me to spend the Christmas holidays painting with her at Haliburton, and with Mother's and Dad's co-operation it was decided that I should take the train up the day after Christmas. What an experience! I changed at Lindsay to a "mixed" train, one passenger coach and a couple of freight cars, which ambled up the track, stopping for leisurely unloading at funny little stations and even at cross-roads. Although I had left the Danforth station before nine, by noon we were only at Kinmount. The Conductor-cum-trainman-cum-baggage-man advised me where I could get some lunch in the village, and while I was still eating my boiled egg there, sent a youngster to tell me that the train was ready to leave "whenever you have finished, Miss." It was dark when we reached Haliburton. I emerged from the smelly green plush coach with its dim oil lamps into a snowy world of sharp cold and brilliant stars. Waiting for me was a horse and sleigh, with Curry's mother, a round bundle of shabby fur coat below a woollen bonnet, perched on the driver's seat. good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-14 7 It was like stepping back fifty years. The Curry house had electric light, but water was gravity fed from a cistern upstairs which had to be filled by a hand pump in the kitchen. Too enthusiastic an attack at the pump brought water pouring down the kitchen wall from above. Hung up in the back shed was the frozen carcass of a buck, shot in hunting season, ready for butchering piece by piece as needed. Down in the cellar was the wood furnace, and the long wall of cut wood to keep it fed. Curry and I made a work space there, with our backs kept warm by the furnace, and a strong blue bulb hung from the ceiling to give us "daylight" for finishing the oil panels that we brought home every morning and afternoon. Besides the wood in the cellar was an incredible collection of boots, rubber boots, overshoes, old coats and sweaters, mittens, hoods, scarves, snowshoes etc. If you needed something, just look for it. It was there. Curry's father, Mr. W.R., was a man of parts, owner of the only garage in town, closed, like the roads, until spring, reeve of the village, local undertaker, district inspector of roads, owner manager of the livery stable that had horses for the doctor and for anyone else who needed winter transportation, and above all a gentle man, at home in the woods, in the kitchen, at the hockey rink, and at the dance at the town hall on New Year's Eve. Curry gave me her world, the winter woods full of animal tracks, the snow fanning from the stump fences in drifts of sculptural purity, the log homes and the tar-paper shacks with blue wood smoke in curls above them. We painted every day all day, usually within walking distance of home, finding material in the village itself, along the river, down at the sawmill or out on the frozen lake looking back at the hills. But not always. "Dec. 29. The end of a perfect day. It began fairly early with the words 'sleigh ride' that woke me with a jump. Ethel and I giggled, dressed, and ate hastily, and then packed into the cutter, too stuffed amd bundled for action of any kind. I loved the motion of the horses, the crispness and tingle of the air - and the sideways skidding of the sleigh, up slowly - along smartly, bells jingling - nose running - mind happy -playing with thoughts of Marjorie and Jessie. "We saw some lovely bits of colour - a blue door - and a pink and grey one - and some gay washings hung out to dry. The last few miles were through a wild bit of wood - rough uneven trail - hardly a road - twining black birches and elms tangled up in saplings and underbrush. There were three patches where the road was sunk in black bog and the horses would hardly take the jump across. I thought that the sleigh would break and deposit us in the mud or else that it would stick there forever. good

We sat down at one of the big long tables and ate gustily from tin plates, drinking out of big tin bowls. But the climax, more thrilling even than the cutter part, was the walk over the lake, dazzling in sunlight, Ethel and the men ahead, picturesque in breeches and windbreakers, casting vivid shadows, and the hills around the lake. I loved the keen wind, the feel of the snow under my feet, and especially the sense of high adventure. "Then for the drive home I cuddled low against Ethel -casting a submerged eye over the rugs at the heavenly colour -bright mauve sunlight on hills, a wonderful afterglow - Venus, and later Mars and Jupiter - golden light on trees, a barn with the bright sky shining through." It was 25 below zero, so cold that my nose twitched and was stiff, and our breath froze in white frost on our hair. The stars were bright and the smoke rose quietly straight up, meeting as it slowly spread into one smoky pall that caught the light from the lamps and gave a solemn cold look to the village - and the snow squeaked and crackled underneath us. "I love Mr. and Mrs. Curry. To me they are the fulfillment of everything I think marriage can be. They are beautiful lovable people and it seemed symbolic of them and their union to see them as I saw them tonight, one on either side of the bed, kneeling in their prayers. Dear simple, loving, kindly people. I wish I knew more like them." On our last day we abandoned our sketch boxes, and with a parcel of turkey sandwiches and a handful of raisins in our pockets, walked "the Block", a long hike over snowy country roads that took us past the farms around back of the big hill that overlooks Haliburton. It was a bitter windy five miles that ended on top of the hill when we came to the cutting through the trees and slid straight down it on our seats into the village. And so back to school in Toronto to start 1929. J.W.Beatty was the instructor in "Life", both drawing and painting. This meant working from the nude model. Marjorie and I were so modest even with each other, that when we had "skinny dips" in those days we crept to the water under cover of darkness, wrapped in raincoats, and didn't look. But by the time I was in third year, ready for life classes, we had all become so used to seeing the drawings and paintings up on the wall that there was little sensation. Mr. Beatty was a chain smoker, with a wheeze that made talking sometimes difficult. His fingers were yellow-brown from nicotine, and shook so that you wondered if he could aim at the page when he sat beside you to give a criticism. But once on the paper, his hand was in control, and his line confident and true. He was a remarkable man who had been a fireman, and who had taught himself to draw from plaster casts in the fire station while the other boys were playing their eternal bridge or poker. Later he studied in Paris and became a competant academic painter, well respected in the community. But his heart was full of bitterness towards those artists who received more recognition than he, and he hated, it is not too strong a word, the men who were challenging the academic standards of the nineteenth century, and especially he hated the Group of Seven in Canada. However, he ran the Port Hope Summer School, a resident hostel for art students, close to the old mill and dam in Port Hope. It was an experience something like camp, where the informal comradeship of your fellow artists, the men as well as the women, cemented bonds. Technically, Mr. Beatty had much to teach us, although I share the conviction that I heard more than one student express, that it took years to free yourself from Beatty colour. There was a characteristic look to the work of his students. He invented and popularized a light wooden sketch box in which the floor of the box was the palette and the lid a sketching panel held by the grooves in the sides. It held nine-by-twelve panels, which I found rather small, but Dad made me a similar box a bit larger, which I used for many years. It was a great satisfaction to me that Dad took that kind of interest in my school work, and was prepared to come to the Friday night suppers with me on occasion and meet my friends there. Our "gang" included a couple of Chinese lads, and a French Canadian, big Ted Drover from Newfoundland, Oscar, with a strong Russian accent, as well as a few more familiar Ontario types. Mother looked on them with deep suspicion, but Dad met them graciously, and enjoyed the students as well as the guest speakers at the gatherings. good

While part of me was an art student, working hard, learning to see and to draw, part of me was a teen-ager exploring the meaning of life and what it meant to be a Christian. I went from my second Normandale camp to a student conference at Elgin House in Muskoka. This was the big yellow frame hotel that we used to see from the Sagamo when we took our annual boat trip up the lakes from Silver Island. It was memorable to us for Mother's comment, "That Elgin House, there's no smoking or playing cards, but they're full all the time". We chose to pretend that she meant that the guests lay around in a drunken stupor. Actually, she was remarking on its strongly Methodist character, perhaps the reason for it being made available for the annual conferences of the Student Christian Movement. There I was plunged into a more adult version of camp, with students from all across Canada, and leaders from around the world. I felt very young, but I watched, and I listened. Back in Toronto I was invited to Sunday evening study groups with the same leaders. One of the men guiding us was the notorious Professor Hooke, target of some very critical complaints that had been aired around the University. He was accused of "poisoning the student mind", a phrase which inspired a popular song in celebration of his reputation. "Wednesday, March 27. I'm happy tonight with a queer incredulous thrill - Such a bombshell has been thrown into my static world. This afternoon walking through Queen's Park with Jessie - "I wish you were two years older - Oh I guess I don't either - but if you were two years older I could leave you my job' . "I laughed at her - of all the stupendous and absurd ideas. Poor Ontario if I were. 'Don't be funny, Jessie!' "I'm not being funny. I mean it. I'd be quite willing to trust you with it'. "And she asked me, as Miss Allison had half asked me before, if I would consider Girls' Work at all. Wish I could answer that question to myself. Which must I do - and can I do both? I'm being haunted by a nasty suspicion that compromise will never satisfy - and yet I cannot see clearly which is most vital to me. I can't imagine life without either. Jessie says of course I can't decide in the abstract - that I shouldn't try". good
