There's no way to write about it. Quite the most powerfully moving music I've ever heard - and more tremendous of course because of the story it was portraying. Bach! I marvelled." My diary is full of the tensions between my three worlds, college, home and CGIT. Mother was not well, She was having a wretched menopause, labelled "nerves" by the doctors, enduring back aches, nausea and insomnia. I would listen for her voice in the morning, because its tone told me the kind of day it was going to be for everybody. All the fun had gone out of her. I had never been able to discuss ideas with her, and had long since stopped trying, but now there was no pleasing her on any level, and I was both helpless and guilty. Mother's religious convictions were summed up in "Honour thy father and thy mother". She resented my new loyalties. In the spring of that year I was offered a job at one of the all-summer private camps. These were well established, well run, expensive, attracting girls from affluent families, and able to pay their leaders. But they were secular. "I've been weighing the pros and cons with M and Mother, and I'll see Jessie perhaps tomorrow and ask her what she thinks about it. "More complications, and still more golden dreams. Jessie offered me the directorship of county camps (CGIT camps organized locally but directed provincially). My heart instantly says yes. Dad says if you would rather, by all means. Mother says a good deal more - with much emphasis and disgust. To her eyes I am throwing away a wonderful opportunity to make good contacts -fair money - and some experience - all for nothing. But my heart sings loudly." After several days of dithering, torn between my own wishes and Mother's arguments, which had some merit, I offered to take the all-summer position if the salary were raised to $150. There followed two weeks of suspense, in which I wondered at my temerity at accepting a job teaching crafts, all of which I should have to first learn myself. But my bluff was not called. It was decided that the budget did not allow for such a high salary. "Monday - Praise be! It's county camps - and I'm thrilled!" This was the same spring that Doug sold his savings bond and bought a ring for Audrey, whom we hardly knew, but who was on the other end of the line when Doug was closetted upstairs with the telephone in Mother's bedroom, for an hour at a time. Curry was to live through a dozen more years at the mercy of her love for this same man. He turned up in her life, enjoyed her forgiveness, raised her hopes, dashed them again, not once but over and over. He had charm, good looks, talent and no conscience. I'm sure that he found Ethel's generosity flattering. I wish he could have known what her friends thought of him. While love raged around me in one form or another, I remained unscathed, interested in an academic way, but waiting until I met the right man. Those at the College were friends, and I enjoyed playing and working with them, but there was nothing romantic between us. 1930 The first county camp took me further north than I had ever been before, all the way up to New Liskeard. Considering that I was to be in charge of fifty girls and their ten leaders, it did seem a bit ridiculous that Mother worried about my making the train trip all by myself. I was all eagerness. "July 17, 1929, After a very wonderful night - the old half-forgotten happiness of the motion of the train - bells clanging away into silence as we passed - the moon shining on my head - little lights that work for me when I want - a letter to Margaret (Stevenson, who had been at Port Hope School with me the week before) - and a curious inability to realize that this miraculous camping experience has really begun. I woke early this morning, shocked to see that daylight had brought the north, with tar-covered shacks, many telegraph poles and rocks and spruce." I was met by a pleasant woman who was to be "Camp Mother", and stayed with her until the next day when we were all to be driven the twenty miles or so to the camp site. My hostess was hanging out a washing that afternoon, fighting the wind that was whipping the sheets up and over the line in a mad dance. It was a blue sparkling exuberant day. "Don't you love a wind like this?' I asked. "No", she said. "It frightens me. It was a day just like this that the forest fire swept over Haileybury", and I good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-12 2 remembered the terrible disaster to that nearby town, that had driven people into the lake to escape the flames, and filled the air with dense smoke from which many could not escape. The wind was still blowing two days later, when we were settled in to camp. It was so strong the first morning that the corn flakes blew right out of the bowls, and we ended up using mugs, with one hand across the top as a lid. The cook had never been away from her husband before, and wept quietly but steadily for three days. My tent-mates were a treat. Mrs. Patterson, of the broad Scottish brogue, as she unwound herself from her bedding roll in the morning would exhort us, "Brothers, let us groan", and we would respond in unison. We were not always in such agreement. When I found myself with a discipline problem, with three of the girls leading in noisy nonsense after lights out, it was she who thought the solution was to put a leader in each tent. But this was against my principles. The only discipline I wanted for the camp was self-discipline. I called a council hour, and the camp as a whole met the issue, and agreed that they needed rules, and that they would respect them. The campers asked, and got, from each of the three rebels a promise to cooperate. What is more, the promises were kept. What had threatened to be a disaster turned into a triumph. For several years afterwards, Katie Frew, the conspicuous ring-leader, used to write to me at Christmas. I can still see her mischievous eyes, and her fly-away black hair. good

This was dramatically beautiful country that I had glimpsed from the train going up. I spent a happy afternoon sketching near the edge of the lake. It was the next morning when I woke to find one eye swollen shut and my face so lop-sided that I could hardly speak, that I learned that the rather bothersome little midges that had been all around me while I was working, were black flies. Now I know! But it was not the flies that went into my diary. "I did a sketch this afternoon from the general store at Timagami and feel terribly thrilled about it - but even more thrilled at the interest shown in it by a young chap, and his tentative approach for purchase. If I could only sell a sketch - my future would be made! I could feel justified in the expense this trip is being". "Sunday morning, August 4. In the midst of another funny adventure and scared green. I'm to take the adult class at the Sunday School - on Daniel - boys and girls, and have neither convictions about Daniel nor courage to face the class. I'll probably be the youngest of them. It's a ghastly feeling. And add to that the prospect of speaking to the S.S. at the close of the lesson. Whew! "Yesterday was an unexpected adventure. We had a very good

Waves fifteen feet high, fifty feet between the crests. I revelled. Each mountainous bank of water would send the little ship almost on its side, and people turned pea-green around me. Such fun! But for all its fun I was lonely. Goodness how I wanted David (Marjorie) or Jessie or Ethel or someone to exult with me. Joy alone is only half joy...Why do my wonderful adventures of gladness and travel always come apart from David, and why does her life run away from mine? Specially when we're doing almost the same sort of things." Between the Manitoulin Summer School and my next camp I had barely an hour in Toronto, just time to change trains. "A beautiful singing joy was being met by Mother and Dad and having a blessed hour with them before it was time to dash off again. I can never sufficiently be glad for the new appreciation of them that this year has brought. Dad is my friend now, my dear, understanding, understood friend. Today he said that this summer I had been trying my wings, and looked better than he had ever before seen me look.... "Dad's life has been given to us in some ways, and it is for us to give to the world some fruits of the fine steady honourable quiet life he has lived". And Marjorie managed to get there for a few days. We were both desperate for a reunion, and a chance to share the experiences we had been having separately. She was just back from two months at Camp Tanamakoon in Algonquin Park, and was full of its beauty, and the very different atmosphere she had found there. Most of the other leaders were students or graduates of the "Margaret Eaton School of Expression", the very organization that had tried in vain to teach us to be ballet dancers in our youth. It was a camp that stressed sports and physical perfection, and Marjorie's function there had been to add a spiritual dimension to the life. She helped the campers to build an outdoor chapel, and led them in worship. October plunged me back into college. "Another year, the last. Ethel and I look at each other and smile a little, and wonder a little when we say 'last'. Incredible. Such a little while ago I was looking forward to four whole years, marvelling, and now I marvel more that they are gone. Will all of life be like this?" "Noon brought an interview with Dr. MacMillan (not yet Sir Ernest), most gracious of men, who made us feel instantly at ease, and chatted away about our sketches as if he had nothing on earth to do but entertain us." We framed up and hung about twenty small oils in the lunch room and corridors of the conservatory. No sales, of course, but the satisfaction of seeing the work properly presented and feeling that it looked professional. We were working and playing hard. My diary is full of parties in Ethel's room, of serious discussions about art and life, about the possibility of getting a job at the new technical school that was due to open in north Toronto in the next year. But in the meantime the family were looking forward to big doings at Christmas. Ken and Betty were coming home from Toledo with the new baby, and Doug and Audrey were to be married at our house on New Year's eve. Christmas was like all family Christmases with new babies, exciting, hectic, and emotional. And the wedding preparations were even more so. Audrey was staying with us, although Mother and Audrey were temperamentally incompatible, and as Audrey became more tense and uncomfortable, Mother became more critical and irritated. Two things happened today that seem to be hustling me out of the irresponsibility and freedom of my life so far, and into the workaday world of grown up. Mother made my appointment for me with Mr. Saunders, possibly my future principal, and A L (Arthur Lismer) offered me a Saturday morning teaching job. I don't want to be teaching so soon! I cling to my last happy independent year - but truly such is life". "Tuesday The world moves, an 'interview' with A L tonight, also Helen Sanderson (neighbour, Malvern friend and fellow-student), apparently all is set to start this Saturday". Arthur Lismer had been taken on by the Toronto Art Gallery as director of education, with a Carnegie grant to introduce a new concept in art for children. Curry was taken on the staff, along with three or four others, and Curry and I were the team responsible for all the eleven-year-olds, boys and girls. We had sixty of them between us. It is the perfect age. They have lost none of their openness and energy, and have not yet become self-critical or inhibited. Usually we would have a get-together with Lismer and the other teachers, perhaps over coffee, to plan a theme for next week, or contrive some new medium to excite the kids. After that we were on our own, organizing the materials, presenting the challenge, and ducking out of the way to avoid the stampede as our eleven-year-olds rushed to get started. They spread their work on the floor and knelt over it. We provided big brushes, big pots of colour, as much paper as they could use. We encouraged, praised, suggested further development, but made no attempt to impose our ideas on them. They were bursting with ideas of their own. At the end of the morning we gathered an armful of imaginative drawings and paintings, collected the materials, and carried everything back to Grange house for storage, and to show to the others. There we would find Lismer, already off on a new tack, three jumps ahead of us. All of the students in fourth year at the college were working under pressure, with exams looming and projects to be finished. But at the end of March, Marjorie and I achieved a weekend together. CENTRAL TECHNICAL SCHOOL Norah McCullough, who was Lismer's full time assistant at the art gallery, alerted me late in 1931, that her friend Edith Manning, who was a teacher in the art department of Central Technical School, was to be married at Christmas. In those days, for a woman teacher to get married was to get fired, so her job would be open. I had already tried to be taken on to the staff of the new Northern Vocational School, and been turned down as "too young". But Charles Goldhamer was at Central, and he had taught me at the College and had been very friendly and interested in my progress when our paths had crossed since. I telephoned him to ask how I should go about applying, and he set up an appointment for me with the Art Director, Peter Haworth. Mr. Haworth didn't commit himself to anything at that first interview, but he did ask me if I thought I could teach a group of librarians how to make posters. When I assured him that I could, he told me to be at the school before nine o'clock on January 4, the first day after the Christmas holidays, prepared to do just that. Peter kept his face straight with some difficulty, and explained to me later as we climbed the steps, that the heroic figure was Major Simpson-Ray, the chief caretaker, and not the principal, as I had assumed. At that time, Peter Haworth was a young, good-looking, curly-headed autocrat, who was gradually transforming a mediocre art department in a secondary school into a dynamic powerhouse. He was given unusual freedom in choosing his staff, and instead of hiring teachers who had taken courses in art, he hired artists, and hoped that they could teach. He encouraged them to go on being artists, and fought a stand-up battle at the Board of Education on the issue. Some one down at College St. wanted to forbid him to practise as a stained glass designer while he was holding down a full-time teaching job. This was during the depression, and the stained glass trade was feeling the competition. But he won, not just for himself but for all the artists and craftsmen in the system. When I reported to his office, as instructed, after my class with the librarians, he said to me only, "You can take PG1GH in EM3 this afternoon". I found someone, I have forgotten whom, to translate. The first was a code for pre-vocational girls, first year, sections G and H. EM3 turned out to be the room up in the tower, How could I guess that? And so the days went. "Tuesday. In a state of headache, weariness, worry and hoarseness, I think I won't be a teacher after all. I don't honestly see any fun in trying to get twenty bored twelve-year-olds to draw a silly coal scuttle that they can't draw anyhow. Damn them. I wish I were home cursing the rolling hills of Haliburton for not rolling themselves into a good composition for me, and my headaches." For that first nightmare week, I lived from hand to mouth, with no timetable in advance, and no briefing on what I was expected to teach. "I feel that I should be recording first impressions but they are still too hectic to be very easily expressed. I'm dead sick of waiting around to see Mr. Haworth, and still lost when I wander away from the art department, and I wish heartily that I had a locker to call my own, and every hour I get dizzier and dizzier like Saturday mornings, in spite of which I begin to feel a little exhilaration at having a JOB and enjoy telling people. If only my head would stop aching, and my cold clear up I think I could recover my mental balance." good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-12 4 Once the first week was over, and I had not been fired, I began to realize that I had inherited Edith Manning's timetable as well as her job. My classes were not art students. In most cases they were "vocationals" or worse still, "prevocationals", youngsters unable to make it in the academic stream, who were given watered-down courses in English and mathematics, and allowed to concentrate on cooking and sewing, with PT and art to round out the week. They were toughies, and ready to walk all over an inexperienced teacher. These kids were the bottom of the totem pole, but I also was at the bottom of the totem pole, and grateful to have a place on it at all. The other side of the coin was that nobody in the art department cared about them, and I was free to do anything with them that would keep them out of trouble. If, by dint of using all my native wit and my CGIT experience, I could find projects that they liked, and show them how to produce presentable work, we were even allowed a small stretch of wall to exhibit the results. This was when I discovered the magic of cut paper as a medium, easier than drawing, faster than painting, spectacular and fun. With sheets of coloured paper, chosen for colour harmony and tone contrast, they could hardly go wrong. One afternoon when I was teaching, not in the art department up on the fourth floor, but down on B floor in a regular classroom, I was startled by a roar from a man standing in the open doorway. "Who is in charge of this class?" "I am," meekly. good

I laugh about it now, but at the time it was not funny to Mother. She took it as a criticism of Dad, who, now that he was gone, could do no wrong. Grandpa had a saving sense of humour, and a gentle irony which I enjoyed, but which neither of his other women shared. Grandmother's face would tighten, and she would look at him in reproof. "Archie!" At school, I was beginning to enjoy the other young artists on the staff. The form-fitting silver satin gown that she appeared in at the Teachers' Federation dance caused a sensation. Irene Doole (who was a perfect lady) approached me in the staff room the next day. Had I been at the ball? Well, no, actually I hadn't. (I had, however, seen the dress and Nory in it). The paintings filled all four sides above the bookcases. The walls were coarse-textured plaster, agreeable to paint on, and I didn't mind the height and all the climbing up and down. The caretaker considered the weeks I put in on the job excessive, since he had seen a man paint a whole billboard in a single day. He was my only negative critic. When the work was finished, the Library Board gave me a one-man show in the adult room, a party at the opening, and best of all, a surprise cheque for two hundred dollars. Jimmie Dean, who was the young head of the Mathematics department, and courting an Oshawa teacher with whom I had become good friends when I directed the Oshawa CGIT camp, was into drama in a big way. That spring he put on Mr. Pim Passes By, with Nory and him playing the juvenile leads, and me having the lovely fat part of Olivia. "May 15. It's Sunday. Mother and I are in Gabriel, cosy in a pale spitty sort of drizzle, on the road above the Rouge (River). NORTH LAKE 1932 Ethel's father said we could use his hunting shack to live in for the summer if we wanted to. It was on a little lake about eighteen miles from Haliburton, very isolated, hard to get at, but Curry was keen, and I was thrilled at the thought of a whole summer to paint, with no other responsibilities. Ronald prophesied that we'd be frightened to death when we were left in there by ourselves, good for about two nights, but we refused to be put off. Mother almost had a fit, and was sure that we would be attacked by a bear, lost in the woods, dead of appendicitis, or raped and murdered, probably all four. Curry's Uncle Andy and his wife, Jenny, came with us to help carry our gear and see us settled. Andy's car was a Model T Ford, with a high frame that could clear the rock outcroppings and deep ruts on the backwoods lumber road that led to the first lake. It was advanced in age, so when we came to a hill, we all piled out to lighten the load, and sometimes to push the car up. Once at the lake, Andy unloaded the outboard motor he had brought, and then hauled a skiff out of the underbrush where it lay hidden. It was a five mile trip along Pine Lake, five miles of woods and more woods, with only a lily-clogged bay or a bare rocky promontory as landmarks. Andy had a woodsman's eyes. He could see the entrance to the portage where we saw unbroken forest. He safe-stored the good

For a long mile and a half we trudged through the bush and over a height of land to North Lake. "The portage was hard. The hills were persistent things up which we struggled doggedly, each step a fight against the weight of the pack on our shoulders pulling us back, and Andy would come to the resting spot, half a grin on his strong lean face, and let himself down with his blue eyes merry and a joke at one of us." There was a rowboat hidden in the trees at the end of the portage. We crossed North Lake to the far side where the cabin was, on a little point of land, a low building in a thick stand of red pines, with some shelving rocks that made a natural dock. It was a two-room hunting shack, a kitchen with a wood stove, a rough plank table and one bunk, the second room with bunkplaces down each side. We left Andy and Jenny the privacy of the kitchen, and chose for ourselves two bunks in the big room with windows looking out to the lake. The next day I wrote: "Tin plates are laid out on the table, potatoes are boiling in the big pot and beans in the frying pan. Jenny is just about to plunge into the Outline of History (one item in our library for the summer) on the bunk behind. Andy has vanished into parts unknown, and outside is our lake! Thirty slim red pine trunks are outside the window and through the other I can see the spired spruce and birch of the good

It has been heavenly fun. Curry is cutting bread with the red bandana hanging from her dark blue jeans and her green hat on top. This morning Andy took us down the north shore, and in the reeds ahead we saw a moving red spot which became a deer, and we got close enough to watch her shaking the flies away, moving about feeding on the lily pads, then when we were close, she raised her head, looked long at us, and turned and in great graceful plunges, cleared the weeded spot, and turned for another look before she disappeared into the woods". Andy and Jenny stayed with us for two days, taking us through the short portage to Beaver Lake, on into Otter Lake where the herons had their colony, beyond that again to Kelly's Pond and by another portage into beautiful East Lake. In every lake or pond Mr. Curry had stowed a canoe or rowboat to serve the hunting parties he guided for in the fall. He had given us a big world to live in that summer. Curry told me then, that when she was a very small girl, her mother and father had moved from Irondale to Haliburton, travelling down river by raft. The family and all the household goods were piled on it, including the cow. Mr. Curry had worked before that as a cook in a lumber camp. He was a marvellous example of first-generation capitalism, from rags to Leading Citizen of Haliburton by imagination and hard work. good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-12 4 "July 7. Days have been so full! Just after I finished writing on Tuesday Mr. and Mrs. Curry arrived. I looked up when I heard a wild hoot and howl in the distance and asked Andy what it was, and both he and Ethel knew it was her father's call, so he jumped into the boat and came back with them. Ethel gave her mother a hand to help her out, and the first thing we knew she had toppled over and was knee deep in the lake, while Mr. Curry had sat right in and was practically drowned. Jenny and Andy and I were helpless with laughter. Then I had the fun of seeing Mrs. Curry running around in my blue shorts and giggling about it. "As soon as they left we went across through Beaver Lake, Otter Lake, Kelly's Pond to East Lake, and there in a clearing we found the perfect log camp, fashioned from big pine and cedar logs, and facing a marvellously beautiful bit of shore. East Lake is wonderful.... the lake goes up sheer rock to heights of birch. We walked through the portage thrilled by the great cool green of the trees far up, the damp rich, reedy grass at our feet, the one huge pine twenty feet around, and the bird singing like a canary. It felt almost tropical, growth was so dense and so rich. In Otter Lake we found a heron's nest in the top of a beautiful pine, and three herons right at the tip. I loved the adventurous feeling of it, Andy ahead, his pack moving and his gun held loosely but in readiness, Ethel's light walk, hat perched perilously on the side, and her red handkerchief hanging." good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-12 5 "Andy has a delightful sense of mischief. We shellacked boards last night (to paint on), and he told us stories, of the wolf with the knot in his tail, and later of the war - buried three times at Vimy, marked permanently disabled, stealing grapes in the south of France - with a drunken khaki girl in London, leave in Edinburgh etc. Suddenly there was a bump, pad, pad, bump - bump - and Ethel's head shot up and her eyes opened -'What's that?' Andy's big ho ho ho. It was a potato he had tied to a string and rolled along the floor. Then came stories of scares in camps, with potatoes and phosphorescent hands, and strings and tin cans tied to 'Fritzies' barbed wire', to be pulled by the boys when they wanted to make a false alarm - and the mules that kicked, that they could send greenhorns to feed -ho ho ho." "July 8. I had a good birthday. We ferried Andy and Jenny across early, and left them at the portage, exulting muchly that now we are alone in our own lake. Then round the shore we loafed, discovering big things, a loon's nest with one egg, a new warbler, a pitcher plant, a glorious rocky height, the creek's mouth, and home. "Then as we were working away at the big table in the afternoon Ethel heard a bit of a splash, and up we jumped to see a whole f amily of ducks, marshalled by the mother. They sailed past, diving, aeroplaning, swimming, and she herded them out on to the little rock where they all shook and preened and shook and good

"And my party was such fun with candles and muffins and coffee and a sense of high occasion." For the first two days that we were on our own, we made sure that we had done all our chores before dark, including our last visit to the extraordinary privy. This consisted of two slim saplings nailed between trees to make a seat that was suspended over a natural crevice in the floor of the woods. Privy was the wrong word for it, but it was an airy, leafy retreat in fine weather. Before dark fell, we were safe indoors, with a lamp lit. By our third day there, we were at home, far too comfortable with our woods, our shore, our sylvan perch out back, to be uneasy when night came. Our delight was to take the boat and creep in it along the shore at dusk, seeing how close we could get to the loons that shared the lake with us, and hoping our deer would be feeding again. We painted and drew, and drew and painted. And learned! "There was a quiet blue in the hills all morning. We painted on big boards, and noon brought moving soft clouds. Light was incredible. The clouds were reflected exquisitely in the water good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-12 7 and the water strengthened from pale mauve to deepest cobalt. Even at our feet it was strongly blue. The clouds were those tantalizing beautiful torn things, all wisps and movement and light shadows. Then night brought a sky velvet dark and powdered with stars behind feathery beautiful pine needles. I did a good sketch of the camp while Curry drew me in the late afternoon and we went to bed before dark. Yesterday I found myself comfortably settled beside a very yellow and green serpent with a bright vermilion tongue. It gave me an uncomfortable morning." "July 10. This morning, eating porridge by our lovely out-of-doors fire on our log stools, we tried to trace my (lost) hatchet, and discovered that instead of Saturday, it was Sunday, and we had skipped a day. Such a shock! Tomorrow we shall have been here a week - impossible as it seems. Already home seems very remote, and Tech just doesn't exist. It's been a stormy noon. Rain and wild wind came just after dinner and we abandoned the dishes to draw the lake." "Yesterday was good. We woke up to bright sunshine and trekked over to Beaver Pond for a morning's work in the lily pads, then dinner, cooked dirtily but blissfully among the ants on a nice rocky point and wonderful clouds to tantalize us, till they alarmed us by thundering and sprinkling. Home we dashed, hysterical with laughter, and dragged our bedding indoors and then danced in the rain, and swam, and laughed and rejoiced in this perfect adventure." good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-12 8 "Thursday, July 21. Heavens how the days are flitting! I feel as if I'd skipped a whole day, for last night we were at East Lake, land of mystery and delight. Before dark we paddled all around it, and the big woods were black with depth and silent. Into one maple fastness a deer bounded, otherwise all was hush, and even the fantastic snags were things of strange quiet. We dared scarcely whisper, and when we left that awesome bay we swung towards the sunlight again and found ourselves indeed in Solemn Land, the hills three times their real size and still as mountains. I can't realize that a lake of such big mood is really a little lake. It has none of the intimacy of North Lake. At the far end is a tiny cabin, so surrounded by huge trees that I felt as it the woods were ready to snatch it up." "We were funny sights en route. I staggered under the pack, with my glasses around my neck and my gun in my hands. Curry, far more picturesque, was burdened with the red blanket, rolled, then two rubber boots tied to that, then two canvasses hanging, and below that the sketch box, under her arm her huge portfolio, and then two paddles." Looking back on that summer, I think its greatest gift was silence. Curry is a person of few words. She has never just chattered. In time, we came to read through meals, eating at the table outdoors, our books propped against the trees that supported the table. We had no radio. If a leaf fell, we heard it, and looked to see why. Every sound meant something. good

For me, it was usually painful. Mother had little sympathy with my retreat into the wilderness. "I do understand how she feels but I wish she had some imagination. For all she loves, she can never understand, and, with Virgil, 'one grows tired of everything except understanding'. I think I'll just try to forget her in between mails. We've just chased a HUGE mouse down his hole. A porcupine is sawing up the barn, and far out on the glimmering moonlit lake a loon is crying". "M writes from London this time, and says we must come (to England) together, and my heart says yes, we must! Surely if we will we can. But my mind says, next time it will be with her family and you know it. Tonight we went back to our point, and there in the dying light, painted. And small fluffy song-sparrows flitted around us and a gloriously clear white-throat sang goodnight in the dying light. And 'our duck' sped clucking and peeping across the lake as we rowed noisily home in water that was wonderfully and strangely patterned." "Last night was a black night. The lake was heard, angrily, but not a thing could I see. I felt as if the blackness were a real thing slapping my face. It almost hurt my eyes. Tonight is a true star night. 'The sky has a thousand eyes', but we are tired and beds are too inviting to be ignored". good

rdf:Description.dc:subject: McCarthy, Doris, 1910 - 2010 - Autobiography; Curry, Ethel, 1902-2000; North Lake (Ont.)
rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-12 10 "Impossible to go to bed tonight without writing, although I'm so tired! ..We went to East Lake last night, and there spent an hour in excited curiosity and nervousness watching a MOOSE, and actually making sketches of the creature. We stayed until it was just too dark to see him, and trembling with delight, went home to our funny little island to make camp in the dark, and get ourselves a much-needed supper. Such a falling over, such a spilling, such a losing of knives and dropping of butter and choking on pine smoke, and crying of damns, and intense enjoyment, all in one meal. Then we paddled down the shore, and it was eerie. The flash would make the nearby snags startlingly bright and the shore .secretive and black. The big dead spruce hanging over the water was a magically beautiful feathery vision, as unreal as a dream and as isolated...tonight we saw the moose again and Curry took a whole roll of snaps of him. Sometimes we were within ten feet of him. Gollies!" The duck-and-her-duckling that had been so shy when they first used to circle the lake, skittering quickly past our point, had become accustomed to us, and swam past without concern. The baby was a teen-ager in a panic the first time that his mother left him alone on the lake. He spent all day skimming up and down calling to her. We saw her in the sky, returning, and watched him aeroplane towards her crying, as she glided down beside him. The next day he was less upset, and after a few days he would fish happily by himself while she was away. good

The calendar was saying the same thing, but the end came too suddenly. " A bomb came today in Mother's handwriting, marked IMPORTANT, and suddenly my heaven's peace was shattered and I was left all shaken and needing very much the rocks and the quiet of the portage point, and the feel of the moss under my head, and a little weep. Mother wanted me to come home at once to see Dr. Kirkland and Mr. Haworth re. some impossible scheme of doing part-time commercial and part-time heaven knows what, Hamilton or teaching I gather." "Today brought two youngsters as well as Andy and Jenny, and how I am bored. Gollies how I covet the quietness of our solitude. I am anti-gregarious, but the selfish solitude of this place was one of its most healing qualities. My darling wrote me today, after at last getting my letters, and her understanding has made me so happy. She, at least, appreciates my need of this beautiful blissful place." "Night of the 25th. It has been such a queer day. The morning woke me early, silently, to memories of the specialness of the day (fourteenth anniversary of Marjorie-and-Doris), to thoughts of David in London, and her Valiant here, yesterday's painting, the beauty of Pine Lake, idle morning thoughts, interrupted by the Cadi-duck, and I watched him swimming along in his young lovely pride, looking lonely. He stands up in the water and flaps his small wings, and then splashes about after little fish, and this morning he caught one just by the rock, and at that, I heard Andy go out, and I watched with fresh pride as he wasn't startled, and I was glad he trusted us so, and I wondered where his mother was, all before lying down again. A few minutes later I heard the 22 pop, and I decided that if the porky were being cornered I should be on deck, so out I hustled in my bathing suit, and Andy, to my horror, was shooting at our dear little duck, and even before I spoke he shot, and I saw the poor lovely little thing turn over, and then choking with tears and dismay I climbed over the rock to him, and he was a poor little dead thing in my hands". The return from North Lake was like dropping from paradise into hell. Noise! Everyone talking at once! Confusion. Chaos. Doug and Audrey and the baby had come south on holiday from Kapuskasing, and Ken and Betty and Brian were in Toronto for the Exhibition, staying down the street at Caswells, and there were constant family gatherings, and trips to the CNE, and although I loved them all, I couldn't stand to be in the middle of it. Even the return to school was a relief. good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-13 1 HAMILTON The Ontario Training College for Technical Teachers, (quite a mouthful), was a typically government-style red brick building next door to the Hamilton Technical School. In it were gathered the would-be teachers of printing, sheet metal work, carpentry, motor mechanics and so on, about twenty men, and a half dozen young women who were, most of them, being trained to teach domestic science, a euphemism for cooking and dressmaking. Two of us were qualifying to teach art. We were a good group, getting along well together, doing our best to support the poor victim whose turn it was to teach us a practice lesson, and spending our spare time in riotous games of badminton in the big room upstairs. John Byers and I, both graduates of the Ontario College of Art, were at the same boarding house a few blocks from the school, being thoroughly spoiled. Our landlady, Mrs. Jones, was not only a good cook, she had an eye, and every dish was as attractive to see as to taste. Three times a day we sat down to a small feast. The lectures were elementary to anyone who had done much reading or thinking about education, and I had done both at leadership camps and for my own CGIT group. We liked each other, and she gave me her theories of design to teach, with the flattering comment that she would not usually trust anyone else to handle them. Her analyses of the principles of design were far ahead of anything that I had been offered at the College of Art. There, although one man offered us a nodding acquaintance with Dynamic Symmetry, we had been taught little theory. Usually we were given a job to do, a lamp shade to design, a repeating pattern to make up, and praised or criticized on the details as we worked them out. We had far too little experience to arrive at our own generalizations. I was hungry for more intellectual content, and Mrs. Gordon provided it. She taught that the basic principal of rhythm was orderly sequential change: of direction, of size, of shape, of tone, colour and texture, and that any two elements in a design could be brought into harmony by creating a step between them. To me, this was light shining into darkness. Her husband was the Director of the art department of the technical school where she taught and supervised my practice teaching. I believe that he was a heavy drinker. It is the kindest explanation of the rudeness with which he treated her in public. He would burst into the classroom without knocking and ridicule her or scold her about some trifle. Poor Mrs. Gordon maintained her customary little smile and made no protest, implying to the class and to me that John was just being facetious. But the pulse in her throat throbbed more noticeably. good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-13 3 Back in Toronto, change was not so orderly. When Doug and Audrey had returned to Kapuskasing after their holiday at home, they were greeted by a dismissal notice. The company was laying off staff, and Doug had been there only two years. They had allowed him to come south and buy major house-furnishings with no warning of what lay ahead. It was a blow. Mother rose to the occasion with characteristic generosity and invited them to move back home until Doug could find a new job. Equally characteristic was Mother's inability to carry her generosity into her relations with them. She was critical and difficult, keeping Audrey on the defensive, and the mounting tensions between them naturally involved Doug. Mercifully, eight-months-old Dale was too young to be considered naughty whatever he did, but he was a lively restless baby, and inevitably disruptive. I would arrive home from Hamilton on Friday night, too late for the family meal. Mother would keep my dinner in the oven, and bring it to me to the dining room table, where she would season it with her tale of the woes of the week. I remember held-over white fish, held-over white potatoes and cauliflower or creamed onions, with an obligato of Grandmother's unreasonableness, Grandfather's stubbornness, Dale's being spoilt by Audrey who spent all her time fussing over him instead of helping with the house, and Doug's futile approach to job-hunting by sending off applications instead of chasing around and seeing good

She had no way of imagining what it was like for them, and no generous tolerance of their differences of temperament. I was her safety valve, and she blew off steam to me all through my miserable meal. The pay-off came at Christmas, when Doug's gift to his young wife was black lace lingerie. Mother exploded! I thought it was rather touching that the poor lad had not had all the romance knocked out of him yet, but Mother was furious. Driving back to Hamilton after the winter holiday was pure pleasure. The office secretary at the Training School had offered me a blind date for the dance that closed the fall term, and so I met Walt. We are still friends and occasional dancing partners sixty-five years later. He was eight years older that I and serious about finding himself a wife, and although I wanted marriage too, I was in no hurry. Mother had been told by a plausible fortune-teller that I was to marry a university professor when I was twenty-six, which gave me still four years to play around. But I liked Walt, and enjoyed his attentions, even while I doubted that he was for me the ultimate answer. Marjorie was teaching at the Ontario Ladies' College at Whitby, and we saw each other on weekends, and talked long hours about love, and what it meant, and what it did not mean. Thursday night the exhibit down at St. Aidan's opened, and people said so many nice things about my Snow Drift that a perfect fever of excitement and ambition and dreaming laid hold on me and I was thrilled and yet embarrassed by every compliment. I think they are very bad for me, but I have such an appetite for appreciation. M and I dined yesterday lovingly, if such an adverb isn't ridiculous, and it was, as it always is, completely natural and easy to be with her again. Later, in her room, she talked about Roy to me, and as she sat at her table, hand nervously scribbling on some paper, her eyes on the wall in front, she was a woman, no little girl left at all, and I felt as if I were watching her step truly into grown-up land. It was all a bit like ' our future "us"es' and it pressed home the truth of our growth. We are women now. I'm so glad Roy has come as he did. Funny how I used to dread the time a man would 'come between us', and funny how little like that it has seemed. Perhaps if or when M has become 'sure' it may be more so, but I doubt it". Much of my year in Hamilton was spent in an emotional confusion, trying to sort out my own feelings about Walt, agonizing if a week went by without a telephone call, in highest heaven when he was in attendance, doubting him, doubting myself, dreading Mother's critical appraisal, trying to see him with Marjorie's eyes, being very young and inexperienced, and very much obsessed with sex. Walt was the first person to stimulate that. My diary makes painful reading. good

Mother makes so many mistakes in handling people that I am cheered to the point of believing that, after all, I won't ever be just like her. I think I must have a share of Daddy." "Wed. March 1. Gollies but it's swell news! What a nice weekend to look forward to. Hope Curry had at least one taken. I'd feel pretty sick if she didn't." This was the first year that I entertained myself by drawing house plans. It was a way of making my day-dreams concrete. Then a little later I woke again to find snow outside, drifted up around little Quebec houses like so many A.Y.Jackson canvases....Still later I began to look some more, and the loveliest of all the sights for me was the broad blue-green St. Lawrence, broken by floating ice, brooding in colour under the grey sky, with a ghost hill on the other side, faintly lighter than the water in its snowy patches, faintly darker where the woods made patterns on it. This is the best winter I've had this year....A nice man has just told me that the glorious line of hills that I've been trying to capture in very soft pencil is the Gaspe coast, and that the lake in front of it is the Restigouche River. How he must have loved it....We've been passing villages with intriguing little houses that are gone before I can get them down, but at least I'm accumulating a lot of useful scribbles". But Mother is the loveliest surprise of all. She was beautiful, smooth of contour, and smooth of skin, and looking blooming somehow, as if she were healthy and happy. I felt envy of Daddy for his lovely young wife, and his adorable family. How we were sweet! And then I feel sick at heart when I remember Mother's resentment when I was born. I suppose I was to blame for much of the friction between Mother and Dad. Wonder how much there was. Mother has forgotten its very existence." But Mother had told me many times of Dad's delay in getting to the hospital after my birth. She waited all day for him, and was probably too angry to speak when he came in "after work". She also told me that I was born with a lot of dark hair, which the nurse did up in little braids all over my head, and tied with candy ribbon bows. Mother declared that she suspected me of being an Indian baby, switched in the crib. "How sweet is Aunt Fon. It was then we began to plan a summer that would give Roy and me a chance to get to know each other. I had regretfully parted with "Gabriel", and bought myself a full-sized Chev, strong enough to pull the little trailer I fell for. This was a punt, complete with oars, that could be packed full of gear, and pulled behind the car on its own carriage. Roy would sleep in the car, and Curry and Marjorie and I would share the little square tent that could be rolled up and put into the trailer for travelling. It was certainly an educational summer. Roy was an experienced camper, good at fires, at packing, at all the man's jobs that Curry and I were used to doing for ourselves. What we learned was to contain our impatience at the time it took Roy to do those things. His pace was deliberate, and both of us were quick workers. We bit our tongues (usually), and got out the sketch books to make use of the minutes. What we all learned was not to leave Marjorie alone with practical problems. The morning that Curry and I were off painting, and Roy had taken the car into town for servicing, we left Marjorie, reasonably enough, to get lunch - menu agreed, no worries. But Marjorie had grown up with an older sister, and a Mother who liked cooking, in a doctor's household that always included a maid, and was an innocent in a kitchen, and even worse at a camp fire. For Curry and me it was a great opportunity to work from diferent material than the woods and water of North Lake. We drove east to Ottawa and turned north there up into the Gatineau hills. Quebec villages were organized differently than our familiar Haliburton, and the architecture of the houses interested us both. On the way down from Mont Laurier, which was our most northerly point, we saw a frame house of such charm, that I stopped the car, backed up for a better look, and then ventured through the gate and up to the door to express our interest and pleasure. We were graciously received. Our French was equal to the occasion, and we were given a tour of the interior of "Ensoleilee". It was the memory of their old church window, set in the end wall of the livingroom, that dominated my house plans from then on, and inspired the vertical picture window which is the most important feature of the home that I eventually built for myself. Roy let his beard grow that summer, in a time when beards were rare. Curry and I walked ten paces behind Marjorie and Roy as we promenaded on Dufferin Terrace above the river in Quebec, for the fun of seeing the on-comers collapse in mirth as soon as they had passed Roy's beard. Our happiest week was in camp at Petite Riviere, a tiny village squeezed between a mountain and the north shore of the St. Lawrence River well below Quebec. A group of young people took us to themselves, including us in the sing-songs that were their favourite form of party. They were all members of the church choir, used to singing the mass, and their voices were lovely together. Two of the young men took me back up the mountain through the woods on a partridge hunt. For that one week we became part of the village. Mrs. Beer was not willing to let Marjorie travel overnight with Roy on the train, unchaperoned, so we drove them back to Montreal to catch a day train home. Then Curry and I, having stashed the little boat trailer in my cousin's yard, took off along the south shore towards the Gaspe peninsula. The car was winged after dropping its load. We tented where we could find a little stream and a good view, often on private property, but always with the owner's permission. We would knock at the house and ask to have our water pot filled, and if we liked the person who came to the door, we would then ask to be allowed to camp there. Curry was great at spying out fresh vegetables in the garden, and inspiring small boys to go catch brook trout for our breakfast. I remember one day when the heavens had opened and the rain was coming down in torrents, and from the driver's seat I watched little Curry, in rubber boots and her voluminous yellow slicker, her rain hat dripping all around, holding up her fire-blackened pot and asking, "Avez-vous un peu de l"eau?" 1934 Among other things accomplished by the summer was the recovery from my storm of romance, I had other problems. "Sept. 23, I've had a week of increased turmoil. At first I blamed my indifference to school on not enough holiday - then I thought I was tired, and now I'm in such a mood of disgust with teaching as a life for me that I am praying for courage to get out before it has got me and sapped all the creative energy I have and left me dry like the rest of the teachers here. Kathie and I talked about it on Friday, helpless to fight it and furious with the grip of it. If I can keep this restless discontent, perhaps I really will get out sometime. If, after teaching three years or two, I could have enough capital to get to New York and get work if I can find it, and to study if I can't - and then if I can get work I'll stay out of teaching altogether. At the moment I feel as if I'm selling my soul for two thousand a year and some holidays. I could live on less, on heaps less if I had to, and I'll never feel sure of myself till I have earned my bread by work and not by teaching. We had heard so much about Peggy's Cove that we made it our objective. But the area around Peggy's is impossible tenting country. There isn't a bush on the landscape! We drove as far south as Lunenburg looking for something as good to paint and as hospitable for tenting as the coast of the Gaspe, but we looked in vain. We turned around, and headed back to the country we had discovered last year. It was even better than our memory of it. We pitched the little tent on a ledge of rough red rock ten feet above the beach that shelved down past the tide wrack to the salt Atlantic. Away off to the right we could see Perce Rock jutting out beyond the high rugged cliffs of the headland. Behind us, sloping gently up to the road, our big field was a garden of daisies and slender blue iris. A tactful grove of spruce near the tent gave us the essential privacy. The family who owned the field included Maurice, a young man who took one look at Nory, and became our host, friend, escort, encyclopedia and personal lobster-poacher. With his help, we located the owner of the empty house a few hundred yards down the road, and succeeded in renting it for five dollars for the season. Between our field and Perce, miles across the water, was a deep bay, closed by a sand bar five miles long, behind which lay the tidal flats, the estuary of the Barachois River, enclosed by a backdrop of mountainous hills, blue, blue-black, milky grey, depending on the weather and the light. We did most of our painting at Barachois, the fishing village just inside the sand bar. The river flowed down through the mountains, spreading wide in the shallows behind the bar, but cutting a channel to the ocean at our end of the beach. The one daily train ambled along the sand bar, and climbed over a bridge across this channel, which was high enough to let the two-masted fishing boats pass under into the harbour. Perching on the edge of this railway bridge gave a perfect view of the little boats tethered in the channel or tied to the "stages" along the shore, with a grouping of fish shacks on one side, and on the other, a meandering pattern of mud flats at low tide, with the hills and the clouds to complete the composition. When the cod had been hauled up and all the bait was gone, the fishermen headed for home, this time under sail. From early afternoon until five or six o'clock, the little ships, leaning before the strong afternoon breeze, sails sparkling in the sunlight, came dancing in on the white-capped blue waves. As they drew close to the bridge, down would tumble the sails, and the little two-masters would be brought smoothly to their moorings at the stages, for unloading. There were tables on the stages, for gutting the cod, and a big barrel into which the livers were thrown. The gutted fish were carried in hods to the sheds for salting or, later, for freezing or packing in ice. Heads and the innards were tossed into the water among the screaming gulls. The men worked in teams of two or three, wearing black oilcloth aprons, and a big mitten on the hand that held the fish. Their movements were economical, repetitive, rhythmic. LONDON Grandmother had died while we were still exploring the Maritimes, actually on my birthday. By the time Mother's letter reached me the funeral was over, and her death would have remained very distant and unreal to me except for Grandpa's letter. Grandmother had been increasingly difficult during her last year. Hardening of the arteries was the answer Dr.Beer gave to explain her irrational spells. Sometimes she disappeared from the house and went up to Mrs. Trowell with stories of the cruelties practised on her by Mother and Grandpa. They were devastated by her inventions. I imagined that her death would be a relief to Grandpa. How young and wrong I was! "My Dearest Doris, Thank you dear for your kind and sympathetic letter of the 22. I have been so prostrated with grief that I have been hardly able to concentrate my mind on anything much less write to anyone since I came home from Levis where I received a most cordial and sympathetic welcome and tender and loving care from my dear sister, now the last of my own blood. Even now when I call up in my mind that dreadful and tragic hour between six and seven on Friday the 7th when I held my dear little woman in my arms trying to soften her cruel pains, I feel the same helpless despair and horror as I did then waiting alone for the doctor to come with morphia so as to ease her agony. That fall my CGIT group, in celebration of our six years of growing together, had a great weekend up at the Cabin in Muskoka. It held all the pleasures of the place, swimming and canoeing, hikes through the woods, good food and good talk. But for me, the triumph of the camp was what happened on our way home. We had once again hired a truck to take us there and back. Its body was an open box behind the driver's cab, and we were cushioned on bed-rolls, laughing at the bumps and swaying on the rough roads. Part way up a steep hill, a few miles from the cottage, the truck engine laboured and stopped, and we began to slide back down the hill, gaining momentum as we went. We saw the deep ditch coming, and knew that the truck was slipping into it. Nobody spoke. Nobody screamed. The truck sagged on to its side as it came to a stop, throwing us into a heap. And only then did we break the silence. "Are you OK? Anyone hurt?" Nobody was. Except the driver. Poor man. He had lived through the nightmare of having his brakes fail, feeling the truck start its downward run, and either choosing the ditch or being unable to prevent our plunge into it. He was beside himself, walking up and down the road wringing his hands, sobbing. I had never before seen a man so hysterical. All of us turned our attention to him, and worked together to help him back to calm and a constructive plan of good

Peter had said yes and I was engulfed by waves of appreciation and enthusiasm. He was sweet about it. While we stood twisting our hats and nudging each other to say something he grinned as if he knew what was up, and tried to sell us life insurance. "Thursday night, we felt, demanded some recognition of the event, even though I was celebrating London and Nory, New York, but we went in gala attire to the Royal York and loved it. The music was perfect. Oz and George looked grand and danced divinely. Nory was stunning in her brand new grey satin, and I felt all glowing and lovely in my precious velvet." A week later, Nory had the inspiration for a compromise, four months in New York, to England at Christmas for study in London for six months and then a tour of England in a three-wheeler. We redoubled our discipline of saving every cent we could scrape together. And I painted bouquets of flowers and found a ready market for them among Mother's friends. I could go away with an easier mind. The summer gave me my first experience of painting the rocks and islands of Georgian Bay. After directing CGIT camps in July, I joined Marjorie and Roy as staff at a lodge on an island in Baie Fine in the La Cloche mountains. Roy was in charge of "programme", keeping the guests stimulated and amused. I took anyone sketching who was interested, and was free to paint myself. Marjorie's job was to M with the Gs, as we nick-named it. "Mingling with the Guests" meant being herself, interested in everybody, merry or sympathetic or comfortably companionable as needed. Mother came with a friend for a successful holiday, with plenty of attention from all of us, and excellent fishing! One little point half a mile down the bay from the camp is still known locally as "Jennie's Rock". September saw Nory and me off to New York. After a day and a night on the bus, we were landed in the big city in the silent dawn. We left for the boat in a feverish rush, barely taking time to pin our gardenias in place, and getting unpacked was rather hectic in such a wee stateroom in steaming heat, but from the moment the boat moved away from the dock it was sheer joy. The skyline was just as thrilling as the pictures of it, and the day was one of quiet greys that made it majestic instead of garish. Even Liberty was glorified by lovely tones. The breeze was life-giving. All day I had despaired of ever being cool again.... Then the bath steward turned up all warm smiles and beams, and assurance that "we two little girls" could have our baths any time we jolly well liked. It was like living through a replay of novels I had read about the early days of the first world war. Had we learned nothing? "When the Major came and sat down I asked him, 'How are you feeling tonight?' and his 'bloody!' was the perfect answer. We were. Why - why - why?" The seriousness of the situation flung us into an intimacy that was very different from the playing we had been enjoying. "His fourth campaign, and he says that life has already been so glorious and he has known such happiness and also such unhappiness that the war comes as an escape, a way out without any 'housemaid stuff', and to hear a grand person like him saying that makes it all more unbearable than ever. Thank God for him to talk to, only why must he say that he's glad his last week has been such fun, and that leaving out today, we must make the memories fit to last four years. Damn him. Why must he say things like that? But it's true. We must. If only we could make these days worth keeping." After a shocked exploration of Soho, a stone's throw from Piccadilly Circus with its constant crowds, in the heart of the noisiest concentration of shoddy little sex shops and cheap cafes, that dream dissipated, and we remembered the Major's advice and turned towards Chelsea. "This afternoon was distinctly better. We had fun walking down the funny little streets and seeing always lovely little squares of green. The first place we saw was absolutely beautiful, colourful, comfortable, perfect - the look of character and personality that made it seem like home immediately - but just a bit more that we should stretch" It was over a chemist's shop on Kings Road, a fine big front room, with a fireplace (gas to be sure), day beds, good walnut furniture, drapes and accessories chosen with taste, even sterling silver flatware! After we had looked further, and seen the rooms in our price range, we agreed the it would be cheaper in the long run to love home, and spend time there happily, than to need refuge from it. He's been to the war office and apparently they have promised him the job he wants, but he's not being sent yet and he'll be here again Friday. He was tearing to the station to catch a train. I'm only afraid he may not have (caught it), and we watched him off from the door, his black hat jammed on, his raincoat swinging, and us feeling almost like real people because of having seen him and touched him again". "Sept 9,1935. Today was rather a weary one. We were late getting up and went directly to the Royal College after breakfast, to be advised that the Central School of Arts and Crafts was really the best place for our purpose. Coming back through Kensington Gardens was a great thrill. It was thick with prams. Children like leaves, just as colourful and beautiful and restless, and their nursemaids looking like English nursemaids should. We said that it took a childhood of romping in parks to produce people like the Major. There were nice Englishmen in trench coats in the park too, with big dogs. Coming through the gardens the trees were high, leafy and branching, dull in colour and the grass was a singing green. It was a dull, damp day, just wet enough to suggest that rain might be on the way". We were given a cordial welcome at the Central School, charmed by the principal, who allowed us to choose a good range of classes. Down to the bridge, across it, with a thrill when I saw the river, tide going out, little grey and white boats stranded on the sloping, muddy, rivulet-riddled banks, and the river swift and streaky in the centre. Down past Battersea Park, which was a great beautiful garden, and down and down past funny rows of square stone-fronted houses till, via a bus, I reached a department store down there that did have a hairdresser. Here, they dry your hair for you too, which is hard on the wave but very pleasant". "Sept. 11, Such a beautiful evening, so sweet and good and comfortable and friendly and lovely-to-look-at! We dashed home from school and I did some feverish shopping while Nory got things ready for salad. I had just time to do my hair and wash when the Major came. We made tea for him, and told him of our wanderings and were thrilled that he had worried about us, and glad that he liked our room, proud that he approved of our address, and every once in a while went into a perfect ecstasy of joy that he was here! "Saturday, Much of today was made up of pinching myself or squeezing Nory's arm to be sure that it's real. It's been a day of rare deep joy, that has been made up of nothing but the gladness of being here, and appreciation of its beauty and loveliness. I left Nory ironing this morning and went to Canada House by myself. The first lions I met looked like Trafalgar Square, so off I hopped, and thanks to the map, I realized that suddenly here I was at Westminster Abbey. I didn't go in, keeping it for a ceremonial first view, but I walked on winged feet up Whitehall. It was part of the magic of the day that I should pass just as the guard was being changed. I stood on tiptoe peeping through the fence over the top of the shoulders and thrilled by the flashing silver helmets, white-plumed, the scarlet tunics, resplendent with braid, and the swords, and more than all, with the black lambskin fur saddle robes and the restless horses. "Seeing Canada House touched me suddenly with unexpected poignancy. It would be too desolate if I had to go alone. The dear Major. Miss Busbridge asked Nory all about him this morning incidental to cleaning the room". Miss Busbridge, soon affectionately shortened to "The Buzz", was a sharp-nosed and sharp-voiced landlady, who soon taught us to leave the beds, the cleaning and the breakfast dishes to her. Nobody else could meet her standard. For a week, we came home to find that she had also re-arranged our groceries and dishes. After we had given up trying to maintain our own kind of order, she said to us, "I wondered how long it would take you to adapt yourselves to my better way of doing things". We stopped struggling, and got along with her famously from then on. "Sunday, Sept.12, We walked miles this morning, all around beside Rotten Row, jeering at the ones who couldn't ride and marvelling at the grace of carriage of those who could, and me thinking, as I have so often thought, that horsemanship is one of our birthrights, and must be claimed early or it is lost. "Oct. 15, Our first lesson in book illustration today, with Nory hearing with secret amusement her own teaching points flung back to her in even her own words. First letter from M tonight, forwarded from Canada House, just a newsy bit of gossip really. She sounds busy and happy". "Wed. Oct 16. Zoo all morning, with a fierce pain in the middle but with JOY at the end of it. When I protested that I wasn't careless but I just couldn't draw slowly, he made a little allegory of the child learning to draw his alphabet ABC slowly and carefully first, so that eventually he could write them right off. George and Nory working in moody silence next door, where the gas has failed. We spent the afternoon at the exhibition of the London Group, a sufficiently interesting show, but to George at least, deeply distressing. I rather enjoyed it, and I was even thrilled to discover that three of the things at which I exclaimed in genuine approval were by Mr. Farleigh and Mr. Porter. Porter paints in a way of which I thoroughly approve, and seeing that he will be teaching me painting, that pleased me. Yesterday Nory and I went downstairs to see the painting class, and found an elegant nude model, a roly-poly negress, which thrilled us sufficiently to send us all over London, down streets with entrancing names, and through crowded ways after canvas & stretchers. Last night I wrastled with them all evening and fell into bed weary and disgruntled. I was up early, ironing, setting breakfast, painting canvases, chaos, and then came mail, great heaps of it, two long letter from Mother, a fat one from Anne Marjorie, and a letter from Curry! We suspended operations and were deep into reading mail when the doorbell rang and I heard Nory coming with a visitor who turned out to be Mrs. Acheson, whom we both liked at sight. She's a darling! I didn't even mind our state of chaos. It was amusing and rather nice to hear her slow American voice over here and her "Do you have?". The last straw was when Miss Busbridge breezed in, all wild hair and mops and dusters in hand. good

It specially pleases me to think of being on the "Downs" of Surrey, after soaking in poetry about Downs and uplands. I've been reading more poetry today. Both our new books have lovely things in them. Tonight I did some conte scribbles of George's room, the window with the washing hanging in front of it, the litter on the table, and the stove corner. They were fun to do, and like most drawings done for fun, look better than the laboured ones". "Nov.11. It has been a Day. Then the music began and we were thrilled to hear it, with the tones as rich and vibrant as a symphony orchestra, and the pipers high, shrill and piercing, yet terribly beautiful. I wish I had known the words to the Flowers of the Forest. I wondered if the Major was anywhere within earshot. Chopin's Funeral March was the one I loved best, and God Save the King. I heard a rushing, rustling rattle, and looked up to find that it was the leaves of a little plane tree near. November was a sombre month at Jubilee Place. Nory was having back-ache and depression, not helped by the doctor's advice that her back ached because she was so "tall and thin". George was spending more than he could afford, and we considered moving closer to the school to cut the cost of the bus travel. I was discouraged about my work. The bright spot was our introduction to the Major's American friends, Ted and Elizabeth Acheson, young, sophisticated, travelled, and prepared to "keep an eye on us" for his sake. They lived in one of the charming renovated old houses that gave Chelsea its character. And Daphne and Gunther lived with them, two schnauzers, who, while obviously dogs, shared so many of the Acheson's social graces that they seemed more like people. Daphne spoke French, and Gunther English, with or without an American accent, and knew by the language used which of them was being addressed. Nevertheless, dark days, fog, and cold that clutched at the ankles and crept up through your clothes, kept us miserable, until we assessed the situation and took to vitamins as a substitute for sunshine. A test of stamina was provided by the bathroom down the hall. Ted's brother, Dean, was Secretary of State in Washington, and Elizabeth's father had been a prominent Episcopal bishop there. They knew everyone, and had good stories to tell about them. "I found Elizabeth upstairs, sitting at her window doing her nails, and enjoyed the sight of her. She's a beautiful person and a delightful one. Ted was shut up with his typewriter, but we interrupted him finally, and his welcome warmed me as always. It shocks me to realize how much I appreciate Ted's occasional way of saying, 'Doris would like this story' or some trivial thing like that. They came out with me, children (Daphne and Gunther) in tow, and we went down to the river, and I loved feeding the gulls. Ted is the most amusing companion. He talks happily, the greatest string of nonsense, and I am glad just to listen to it. I loved his idea of throwing Belle Anse, or whatever the indigestion tablets are called, alternately with the hard crusts. They were hard. Mickey and Kitty, who had lived briefly next door to us in the big white house on Balsam Ave, were back in England, welcoming me to their home a few miles out from London. Mickey, who was struggling back from a nervous breakdown, seemed eager to show me the England he knew, the old, the picturesque. Kitty was grateful to see him roused from his apathy, and glad to send us off by bus to explore a village a dozen miles away or even further. I let him talk. He was jittery, but knew these fascinating corners of historic England, and seemed to shake off his depression as he guided me round them. After his ten years in the States and Canada, he was maddened by the conservatism of British business and its inefficiency, blaming much of it on the rigidity of the class structure in England. "Tuesday - started terribly early with a dash to dress and meet Mickey at the coach station, and then we were off for the day, a grand day in many ways. The sun shone till afternoon, not bad for an English sun, and after we had passed all the suburbs, we came through some thrilling bits of English country-side, the trees mossy and ivy-twined, the hayricks top-heavy and thatched, and some marvellous old 'beamy' houses, as Mickey would put it. Bits I liked best were the Georgian house where Burne-Jones or someone lived, and the three beautiful flint houses in Rottingdean, the one with the smugglers' cave, and all the beautiful tiled roofs and lovely little gables and windows. "Thursday, Dec.5. Today has a rather grey look, with a patch of chocolate-brown depression about 3.30pm. I woke up this morning as usual, and remembered with a nasty sag the thing Nory said last night that hurt badly at the time and has been leering at me ever since. 'You're the most complacent person I have ever met'. It's all the things I hate in people, and it was like a slap in the face to be told that I am it. She was thoroughly in earnest too, and thought I was deliberately lying when I said that I didn't feel satisfied inside. Miss B. said the same thing, but I didn't mind that because she doesn't know me well enough to make a very searching judgement, but Nory ought to know me, and if she thinks so, it certainly must be the way I look on the surface. I'm so damned aware of the great areas in which I'm absolutely inadequate, and I've spent such a lot of this year already acutely aware of my deficiencies - all the times when Nory drew, and I just stood around beside her and felt grateful that when people came to her they automatically passed me. And that Ted and Elizabeth ask for me pleases me absurdly just because it's a constant surprise. I wonder if she doesn't guess how uncertain and inferior I have felt inside because of all that....It has upset me all the way in. "Sunday, Dec.8, It was fine when I propped open the first eye this morning, so I dressed in haste and made for Hampstead. When I came out of the underground the air seemed clearer, the sky brighter and the country heaps higher than in Chelsea. And up at the top of the hill, just before the little pond where the children were sailing their boats, was a Punch and Judy show, and I leapt to it, thrilled that my blighted youth should know fulfillment at this late date. It was grand fun. When Punch and the men were chasing each other and Punch kept popping out of the side or the back or anywhere except where the man was, the children jumped and shrieked in excitement. 'There he is! There he is!' And then when he cracked Punch over the head and turned to tell the children he was dead, they screamed at him, 'He moved. He's alive. There he is!' I was almost shrieking with them. They were lovely children, rosy-cheeked, alive - and their mummies and daddies and nurses were so amused that the whole group felt very friendly. I walked away on air. And then Doris B's sister produced a threepenny bit for Nory, and the party grew gayer and gayer and we all felt marvellous". We listened together to the "Empire Broadcast", on radio of course. "The best fun was that every solitary person who spoke in any of the ten centres seemed to have relations in Canada, and sent greetings to Aunt Ella and Uncle Willie and the cousins. It became quite absurd. Our whole ten millions must be cousins or aunts or uncles. The King sounded distressingly husky, as if each word was an effort, either physically or emotionally, and then we stood at attention while God Save the King was sung, and I watched the flame of the fire and followed the voices from England to Scotland to Wales to Ireland, and we sat down, still thinking of Mother and Grandfather listening at home, Marjorie and Roy, the Beers, all the hosts of them". Mrs. Wheeler asked us at one point in the afternoon, if we three all came from the same village. Suddenly we realized how blank was her picture of Canada. I explained that we all came from the same place, but that it was big, seven miles from home to work. "How do you get there?" NEW FIELDS Early in January I took off for a weekend in Paris with Kathleen Hilken, an English girl who had been with me at the Ontario College of Art, and now lived in London. "Jan 11. Very early. In the railway carriage at Dieppe. In one corner K across from me. In the other corner a strange woman, who is English but can understand a very voluble French porter, and in my corner with me, that awful thick, light feeling of having been wakened in the best part of one's first deep sleep. (There are sounds of departure occurring outside, doors slamming, gentle arguments in French, a squeaking luggage cart being pushed up the platform, the dead echo that is part of railway stations at night). K and I met promptly at 7:45 under the big clock at Victoria, fairly incoherent with excitement, and got our little ticket folders with the tricolour stripe and were actually off, in a corridor train, with the moon outside the window, swept by madly tearing clouds. In an incredibly short time we were at New Haven on the dock, charmed by the tiers of lighted windows and the quiet hill-shapes dark against the sky, and there was our boat, 'The Paris[', and soon we were on it, and oh, the dear sweet feel of a deck again, the thrill of seeing the moonlight on the wind-patterned bay, the two harbour lights, green points in a green moonlit darkness. We walked down street after street, skirting groups of ashcans, and feeling the rain come on. First I changed into my heavy shoes, a bit later into my beret, and then on we walked. The Madeleine was a beautiful dusky pile in the darkness. We walked all around it, looking for K's old hotel, but in vain, then on down past l'Opera, and eventually, wetter and wetter, to the huge desert of the Place de la Concorde. There we walked miles over puddles, into puddles, our arms aching with our bags, discovering L'Orangerie, discovering the Seine, trying to find someone in that great wet, lamplit blank to ask directions of. At last, hours later, we arrived at Hotel du Rhone, damp, tired, but still pleased with life, and oh the comfort of that awful little room with the violent roses on the wall paper, and the violent yellow bedspreads.
