Without it, all I could see in front of me was bowler hats. It was a very sober crowd. Heaps of the men were in black ties. All the women who were on the balconies of the buildings opposite were in black, and the city has worn a subdued air that is the result of real affection and sincere grief. There was no badinage and little conversation in the crowd. It was all difficult to see, but there was much arriving of be-tasselled coaches with coachmen in silk hats, and beautiful men in red uniforms with great cascades of white feathers in the helmet, and the horse guards resplendent in shining silver and red and white, and heralds in little gold caps, gold tunics with braid right across their tummies, blowing a flourish of trumpets on long silver horns. I could see the judges or whoever they were, in white silk wigs and dark robes. And I could hear someone calling a loud challenge 'Who's there?' to the procession as it approached the boundary of the old 'City'. Then it passed, and in a few minutes, far away and hard to understand, after another double flourish of trumpets, came the proclamation itself. I could distinctly hear his name, 'Edward - Albert - Christian -George - Andrew - Patrick - David'. I thought of Marjorie, and how we used to string off those names. And then there was cheering and God Save the King, played very slowly, and with people singing softly but in such numbers that it sounded like the moaning of wind, all around, deep and very powerful. And the trumpets again, and the horse guards moved away". good

And the street was lined with bobbies almost shoulder to shoulder, and the mounted men rode up and down the edge of Hart Street, pressing back the crowd. When they stopped cross-traffic and let the people fill Hart Street, the line of bobbies was almost carried off its feet and had to fight them back with their shoulders. Then taxis and lorries filled the road and people swarmed all over them. It was a dark crowd, in black, and a very quiet one. The actual procession came with extraordinarily little announcement and in silence, half a dozen mounted men, the line of mounts drawing the gun carriage with the bier, covered with the gold flag and the red lion, with a small crown and a single cross of flowers. That was all. Behind it came the prince, King Edward Vlll, walking in a distressed sort of way as if his feet hurt, and beside him Lord Harewood and the Duke of York. After them, the cabinet, all bare-headed, all dressed in black and very quiet. Another set of mounted guards and the palace guard in busbies and grey overcoats on either side, and that was all". My memories of those months are grateful, full of tenderness and pain, knowing always that this was for now, and not for the rest of my life. Mickey rationalized our "affair" as good for me, because it enlarged my experience as a woman and therefore as an artist. I rationalized it as good for both Kitty and Mick because it brought him out of a long period of apathy and depression which had threatened their marriage more than I did. Nory and I talked it out, and she forgave me, the more easily that she was still carrying in her heart the girlhood idol with whom she had been travelling when he was arrested, and who was still serving a term for bank robbery in America. The Major and the Achesons raised no eyebrows, and kept their thoughts to themselves, perhaps understanding my need better than I did myself. HOME AGAIN We bought a car, a red "Humber" for one hundred dollars. It's hard to believe. For six weeks we explored England and Scotland, using H.V.Morton's In Search of Britain as our Bible along the way, our only mechanical trouble a windshield wiper blade that needed replacement. Our passage home was booked on a ship that left from Manchester, and the day before we embarked George negotiated a sale of the car for seventy-five dollars. Our ship was another freighter, but carrying only ten passengers, and with very little deck space. The tiny lounge doubled as the dining room. One of our fellow-passengers was Helen Crichton, head of the Domestic Art department at Central Tech, whom we already knew well and liked. Four others were Barker Fairley who was on his way to take over the German department at the University of Toronto, and his wife and teen-aged family. Barker was already interested in art, but had not yet begun his second career as a distinguished Canadian painter. The company was congenial, but provided none of the high drama and excitement of our passage to England. "Monotonous days at sea" was my description of our voyage until the pattern was broken by the sight of land, icebergs, porpoises and whales all in a single morning. We tore to see it, and watched it grow from a light speck to a lovely fairy creation of white and green shadows. We were still at breakfast when someone shouted 'Land' and we ran up the corridor and out all the doors at once, and passed the glass from one to another and shook hands on it, and were very gay. And while we were still congratulating each other on seeing land, someone noticed porpoises popping in and out of the water too quickly for me to see anything but the splashes - and then someone, young Bill, called out 'Whales' and there on the other side of the ship, port, was a whole school of them, lazily showing their great dark slippery bodies with the pointed tails, and blowing and spouting. "And lastly there was Newfoundland, an irregular low blue shape in the distance. And it's sunny! And the ship has stopped heaving! And the Fairley family have recovered! And I'm going home. I haven't dared to think about it too much. Since Sunday we have had day after day much the same, strong head winds the whole time, the ship pitching and tossing, pitching and tossing, hours on the deck wrapped up tight but cold in spite of it, reading, watching the waves rolling past, grey or green or blue or black, dozing perhaps, thinking long hours about whether Mickey will meet me in Montreal and deciding 'no', playing bridge in the cabin and going to bed at 9.30. I can't believe two passages could be so different". good

Reaching Toronto meant Marjorie, who had come in from Brampton to welcome me, very pregnant, very happy, and being everything that it meant to me to be home. And probably Mother feels the same, and yet is inevitably alone much more than I am. It's only when I'm with people that I can forget it even for a few minutes. Poor Mother. I think if she knew how miserable and how helpless I feel every time I think of her, she might be a little revenged. I'd rather suffer the hurt than be the cause of it to someone else. On weekends, town visitors and tourists moved freely across us and up into the tower. The rest of the time we were left in peace, with a daily call from the warden of the park to bring us mail and supplies and drink the good coffee we brewed. Our duty was to watch for fires and report them. One night, just at dusk, we saw one start on the edge of one of the mountains, and even while we watched we could see the orange flame spread and grow. The nearest telephone was at eight-mile cabin, a long way down. We ran. It was all downhill, and in not more than five or six minutes we were there and able to get the warden on the telephone. It took us much longer to climb back up, with big grins on our red faces. The warden had assured us that our forest fire was the rising full moon. My diary is full of moans about the bad sketches I was making, but it later reports a quite successful exhibition of them and the canvases based on them. I am still learning that my paintings are always disasters while I am doing them. It isn't until I see them later, and someone else likes them, that I can see their virtues. Bad news from home cut short our summer. Betty McCarthy died very suddenly of heart exhaustion in one of her recurrent attacks of asthma. Ken's letter made me decide to reroute my return trip through Toledo. He wanted to see me. That was the year of the terrible epidemic of poliomyelitis in Ontario. True, we were both there, but not together. She was part of the group of beautiful, assured, senior councillors, all old friends from last year. I was a new assistant craft teacher, doing what I was told, directed by a woman who knew her basket-work and leather-craft, but was no artist. I was responsible for half a dozen fourteen-year-olds, with whom I sat at table, and whose cabin life I supervised. "Tanamakoon, July 4. Chilluns all here, camp serene, me alone in bed, David patrolling, still a queer feeling that it's a purposeless sort of camp, and wondering what on earth is the soul of camp for them. For so long camp to me has been fellowship, intensely, with God and my friends, and then the joy of little intimate customs and occasions. Here my cabin assure me that they never talked about religion. "Marge is hither and yon, and I'm busy with duties and confabs, and life is very full without visiting her, but I'm wondering if she'll come to say goodnight. Only three days of my teens left". "July 5. With a horrible inferiority complex and a feeling of most complete uselessness - in the way if I'm with 12 (my cabin) and guilty if I'm enjoying life alone or with any other councillors. Haven't seen M today, except across the dining room. I love Dot Jackson. But this is no more camp!" good

rdf:Description.dc:description: Draft of an autobiography of Doris McCarthy's early life leading up to purchase of and move into her own home "Fool's Paradise", Pages 1-11 2 The news from home was disturbing. Dad's illness had been diagnosed as stomach ulcer, and I had left for the summer, confident that he was on the mend. But Mother wrote that "spinach and motoring are off Dad's list", and that alarmed me. Why should he not be adding foods and activities? Camp improved with the weeks, or I began to appreciate it more. I still felt excluded from the inner circle of old councillors who surrounded Marjorie, but I found kindred souls on the fringe, and shared some memorable canoe trips with them on our precious "half days", when we were free to leave the camp after lunch, and to be out until after breakfast the next morning. That meant a chance to take a canoe across several portages into Canoe Lake, visit the Taylor Statten camps there, where Gordon Webber was art councillor, and sleep on the home side of the last portage, within reach of the deadline. Gordon was a friend from public school days, where he was notable for receiving more valentines than anyone else in the class. He lived on McLean Ave. and was part of that gang. He was one of the College of Art students who had pulled out when Mr. Lismer left, and gone with the Art Students' League. And recently he had come with his family to live in the big house to the north of us, and to drop in often for a yatter about our mutual world of art. We were friends on many different levels. good

We talked late around our little fire, and when we came to paddle him back to his camp, a heavy evening mist had blotted out the edges of the lake. It was utterly still. We dropped our voices to listen to the silence, and as we felt our way through the mist, Gordon told us in hushed tones the story that was gaining credence in the park, that Tom Thomson, whose cairn on the hill we had passed that afternoon, had actually been murdered. We let Gordon out at the dock, and he vanished into the night. We turned away and crept along close to the edge of the lake, swerving to avoid the deadheads that loomed at us out of the fog, poking into every little bay looking for the beginning of the portage. We were very quiet. "The bay that had seemed to promise us a portage would end in a tangle of snags. We paddled hard, with a rhythm that made the canoe bounce on the water, but there was an eeriness in the night that rather affected me. The Canoe Lake portage was all right, by the light of the flash, and Smoke Lake came, big, beautiful, a little clearer. Again I felt the hostility of old deserted Nominigan, and shivered a little at the flashes of lightning and the thought of being forced to take shelter there. "Never shall I forget the exhaustion of that dreadful portage. I felt that I couldn't bear it for another step - yet still we stumbled on to Koochie, and there I lay, numb with weariness, and the hopelessness of ever being able to move, I would try to sit up, and fall again on to our bedding rolls, knowing that Koochie was too marshy for a camping spot, but lacking energy to struggle on. "Margot, fortunately, was a little less done out, so we crossed the pond, and were pulling the canoe out when we missed our pack. In again jumped Margot, and for a bad fifteen minutes we were separated, cut off completely by darkness and too sensitive to the stillness and mystery of the place to call to each other. I sat drunkenly on the moss, and tried to read the sounds, the knock of her paddle on the gunwale, the occasional drip or splash, pauses - while I imagined her in the channel - a long pause - again a knock - than a huge splash and silence. Had she fallen in?" I wondered if I could get to her in my condition, and if perhaps cold water would revive me. "Margot", I quavered. "Margot, are you all right?" No answer, but at last the knock, knock again, and the canoe sliding towards me out of the darkness. "It was a beaver", said Margot. "It scared me too". We left the canoe where it was. Later there was the day that Mother had to bring home the papers from the safety deposit box, and have them all explained to her. And no words. I wouldn't have known what words to use, even if I had been allowed to speak. My diary is so tear-spotted that much of it is illegible. But at least I could write my grief. Every day Mother helped Dad to dress, and he sat downstairs, not even reading, but rousing when someone called, and many did. The September night that Laurie and Dorothy were married, Mother and I went to the church, remembering how we had all been together for Doug's wedding less than a year ago. In Malvern days Laurie had been like another son around our place, and the boys had gone together into engineering. Later that night Laurie's mother came to the house, still in her gold lame finery, bringing Dad the bride's bouquet, with Dorothy's special love. Dr. Cotton dropped by often, casually, as a neighbour and a friend. We were all doggedly cheerful. I have often wondered if Dad would like to have talked with us about what we were all facing. Mother had moved Dad into the big north bedroom with the sunroom off it. A day came in November when she couldn't rouse him, and his breathing was harsh. Mother called Mrs. Trowell, Grandmother's cousin, and she came down for moral support. He's left us a heritage of dependability if only we were able to accept it....I'm so glad I went to the cemetery. It wasn't bad at all except for Jim's chatter (cousin by marriage). Mother retreated into black widowhood, with a heavy crepe veil falling from her hat. It had some point. People knew enough not to ask her about her husband, and everyone was kind and considerate in shops and on the street car. After her long, faithful ordeal of nursing him, I didn't begrudge her the drama. My concern now was to start to earn a living. We were a year into the Great Depression. Commercial art firms were laying off staff. I took my portfolio to Brigden's, nursery of so many of Canada's artists, and was told that I might work for them if I wanted, but they could not pay me. I decided to go on freelancing. The Saturday morning at the art gallery was a small but steady income. Moulton College, a private school for girls, gave me a little part-time teaching. Leadership of a CGIT group at one of the inner-city churches paid a small honorarium. In the back of my diary I kept track of all my free-lance jobs, and what they brought in. rdf:Description.dc:title: Congratulatory letter from Reg Stackhouse
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Stackhouse, Reginald, 1925 -
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Order of Canada; Stackhouse, Reginald, 1925 -
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Congratulatory letter to Doris McCarthy on her membership in the Order of Canada, from Reg Stackhouse, M.P. Scarborough West, sent on June 4, 1987 from Ottawa, ON.
HOUSE OF COMMONS CHAMBRE DES COMMUNES CANADA
REGINALD STACKHOUSE, M.P. K1A 0A6 TELEPHONE Scarborough West Ottawa (613) 992-2062 Scarborough (416) 261-8613
OTTAWA June 4th, 1987
Miss Doris J. McCarthy Scarborough, Ontario
Dear Miss McCarthy:
Please accept my warmest congratulations on your being named a Member of the Order of Canada.
You have added to the cultural strength of our country through several decades in the art community.
You have served your country in so many ways; among them, founding instructor with Arthur Lismer's Children's classes at the Art Gallery of Toronto; full time teacher at Central Technical School; summer school teacher for the Ontario Department of Education; president of the Ontario Society of Artists; president of the Canadian Society of Painters in Water Colour. As well, you were elected an Associate of the Royal Canadian Academy.
Colleagues have used the words "lively" and "going-concern" to describe you. I am told that you are a few courses away from earning a specialist degree in English. Frankly, you have much of which to be proud.
Canada is a better country because of people such as you, and I am glad to offer you the best wishes of the Government of Canada.
With kindest regards,
Yours sincerely,
Reg Stackhouse, M.P. Scarborough West

A letter from the Secretary General of the Order of Canada, Leopold H. Amyot regarding "The Chancellery" a new name, new administrators, new policies, constitutional revisions and organizational activities. An updated list of members is included. The letter was sent on October 11, 1988 from Rideau Hall, Ottawa, ON, to all members including Doris McCarthy. RIDEAU HALL OTTAWA K1A 0A1
LA CHANCELLERIE THE CHANCELLERY
October 11, 1988
Dear Member:
Enclosed is a recently-updated list of the members of the Order of Canada as wall as a copy of the speech delivered by the Governor General, Her Excellency the Right Honourable Jeanne Sauve, at the last Investiture. Over the past few months, our time has been spent defining our policy regarding communications and publications, creating the databases required to take full advantage of our new computer system and reorganizing and staffing new positions in the greatly-expanded Chancellery. Regarding the last development, I am pleased to announce a number of changes. First, the advent of the Canadian Heraldic Authority and the increasing emphasis on honours required changes in the structure and nomenclature of the Chancellery. Having long ago outstripped its name and being unequipped for the specialized expertise required in heraldry, the "Chancellery of Canadian Orders and Decorations" no longer exists. To incorporate the added responsibility for heraldry and raise the profile of honours in general, a Branch has been created, called simply "The Chancellery" and placed in the hands of an Assistant Secretary, Lieutenant-General Francois Richard, C.M.M., C.D., recently Canada's Military Representative to NATO. His Branch comprises two Directorates: Honours, which administers national Orders, Decorations, Medals and the Governor General's Academic Medal program and Heraldry, which has implemented a program concerning all matters related to arms, flags, badges and other heraldic emblems. The new Director of Heraldry and Chief Herald of Canada is Mr. Robert Watt, M.A., FHSC, who joins us from duties as Director of the Vancouver Municipal Museum. He will be assisted by two other officers, Mr. Auguste Vachon, M.A., FHSC, and Mr. Charles Maier, M.A. The Acting Director, Honours is Mr. W. David John, C.D., M.A., who is probably familiar to you as the former Deputy Director of the Chancellery. He is supported by Mrs. Diane Mayer who has primary responsibility for improving the nomination processes for national Orders and Decorations and by Miss Madeleine Proulx, the Chief, Orders, and Mrs. Danielle Dougall, the Chief, Decorations and Medals.

We would also like to inform you that the policy concerning the use of post-nominal letters has changed. All honours from the Queen of Canada will continue to be listed, but we will limit other post-nominals to those for the highest earned degree, one fellowship in a learned society and one professional qualification. A member's complete entitlement, of course, will be kept on record and used for formal, official correspondence. Any comments or corrections to your post-nominals used in this letter would be appreciated and we will attempt to accommodate everyone's preference within the above guidelines. Please note that the above-mentioned guidelines have been applied to the Membership List which we will send to you once a year.
Of particular interest to members will be the news that recent developments in honours necessitate the revision of the Constitution of the Order. Major changes will include the deletion of the paragraphs enabling the honorary appointment of foreigners and the inclusion of a section permitting the augmentation of the personal arms of members who hold them. Questions frequently asked such as how to dispose of the insignia of the Order upon the death of a member and the new statutes will be covered in a document which will be published in the near future.
Yours sincerely,
Leopold H. Amyot Secretary General of the Order of Canada and Herald Chancellor

Men (White Tie)
The miniature badges of orders, decorations and medals should be worn suspended from a medal bar attached to the left lapel of the coat.
Only one full-size neck badge should be worn, suspended from a miniature-width ribbon. The ribbon is worn under the band of the tie so that the badge hangs one inch below the bow. A miniature of this badge should be included in those worn from the medal bar.

If decorations are to be worn, invitations should read: "White tie — Decorations".

Full-size insignia suspended from a medal bar are worn attached to the left side of the coat.
Only one full-size neck badge should be worn, suspended from a full-width ribbon. The ribbon is worn under the shirt collar so that the badge rests on the tie immediately below the knot.

Women (Afternoon Dress)
Full-size insignia suspended from a medal bar are worn attached to the left side of the dress. If there is only one such award, it may be worn on a bow.

At functions where morning dress may be worn, the host should indicate on the invitation whether decorations should also be worn.
Lounge Suit 5
Men
Those full-size insignia that are suspended from a medal bar are worn attached to the left side of the coat.
Only one neck badge should be worn, suspended from a full-width ribbon. The ribbon is worn under the shirt collar so that the badge rests on the tie immediately below the knot.
The stars of orders should not be worn with lounge suits.
Women
When attending a day-time function at which men are wearing lounge suits, women should wear their full-size insignia, which are worn from a medal bar. If the function is in the evening the miniatures may be worn.
Only one full-size badge, that would be worn at the neck by a man, should be worn. This badge is worn on a bow attached to the dress immediately above those worn from the medal bar.
The stars of orders should not be worn on these occasions.
On daytime occasions, such as Remembrance Day, Legion or Regimental gatherings, guests may wear full-size medals with lounge suits or blazers. However, miniatures may be worn at similar evening functions. The host should indicate on the invitation whether decorations should be worn. pencil writing

Male and female members of uniformed organizations, such as the Armed Forces, Police Forces, the St. John Ambulance Brigade or the Corps of Commissionaires, should wear their insignia as set out in their respective dress regulations.
Below are suggestions to guide those who wear decorations with military uniforms not subject to other regulations.
High-Neck Tunic
Those full-size insignia mounted on a medal bar should be worn attached to the tunic over the left breast pocket.
As many as three neck badges may be worn. The senior badge suspended from its ribbon is worn inside the collar of the tunic in such a way that the badge hangs outside with about one inch of the ribbon emerging from the opening of the collar. The second and third badges are worn with the ribbons emerging from the second and third buttonholes.
As many as four stars of orders may be worn on the left side of the tunic.
Open-Neck Tunic
Those full-size insignia mounted on a medal bar should be worn attached to the tunic over the left breast pocket.
8
Two neck badges may be worn. The senior badge suspended from the full-width ribbon is worn under the collar of the shirt so that the badge rests on the tie immediately below the knot. The second badge is worn with its ribbon emerging from the top buttonhole.
As many as four stars of orders may be worn on the left side of the tunic.
Formal Evening Dress
When members of uniformed organizations wear formal military style evening dress (mess dress), they should wear their decorations in the same manner as for civilian evening dress (white tie).
When not wearing insignia with a military style uniform, it is customary to wear the ribbon alone. The "undress ribbon" is worn around a one-half inch wide strip of stiffening material and sewn immediately above the left breast pocket of the tunic. If more than one ribbon is worn, it should be worn without interval with the senior one closest to the centre of the chest.
Overcoats
Only those full-size insignia mounted on a medal bar may be worn on a civilian overcoat at outdoor functions. Neither neck badges nor stars of orders may be worn.
Lapel Badges
Included in the insignia of some orders and decorations is a lapel badge. This badge may be worn on the left lapel of the coat with any order of dress at any time when the full size or miniature insignia or the undress ribbons are not being worn. Women wear this badge in a similar position on the dress or jacket. pencil writing

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Newman, Peter Charles 1929-
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Order of Canada; Newman, Peter Charles, 1929 -
rdf:Description.dc:description:
A statement by Peter C. Newman about how Order of Canada members can help promote a unified Canadian identity through an advertisement in the Globe and Mail, in order to carry this out, Order of Canada members may make a financial contribution to the Council for Canadian Unity.
ORDER OF CANADA — STATEMENT A COMMUNITY OF DREAMS
"The mind supplies the idea of a nation," mused Andre Malraux, the French philosopher. "But what gives this idea its sentimental force is a community of dreams." That image of Canada as "a community of dreams" is particularly relevant at this time in our history when the nation's continued existence seems threatened. Those of us fortunate enough to have been recognized by our peers and honoured by having received an Order of Canada feel duty-bound to speak out at this perilous moment. Without in any way endorsing the many and shifting political positions that are in play, we wish to reaffirm our faith and belief in this great country of ours. The Order's motto, after all, is "they desire a better country." We do — and we believe that a better country will emerge and can be perpetuated if every citizen rededicates him or herself to the ideals that allowed us originally to forge a nation across this huge chunk of geography. We may be a loose federation of wildly diverse regions, but there is a quiver of common intent that has held us together for 125 years — and will continue to do so, if we allow ourselves to seize the future that can and will be ours. staple holes, corner folds, pencil

If you would be willing to endorse this general statement of intent that would be published as a full page advertisement, including your name as one of its supporters, please let me know. It is my hope that we can generate enough interest and raise the necessary funds, to run this ad in The Globe and Le Devoir, at a time when the national debate on Canada's future might most benefit from such a declaration. Should you be willing to make a financial contribution, please send along a cheque payable to the Council for Canadian Unity, which will allow for tax deductibility. I do hope to hear from you.
Peter C. Newman
P.S. Please write. There is no simpler or more direct way for you to endorse the feeling that you "desire a better country". staple holes, corner folds, pencil

rdf:Description.dc:subject: Order of Canada; Sauvé (née Benoît), Jeanne Mathilde, 1922 - 1993
rdf:Description.dc:description:
A letter from Jeanne Sauvé, Chancellor of the Order of Canada, encouraging Doris McCarthy to raise the profile of the Order of Canada within the Educational & Arts communities, to promote the recognition of excellence. Letter written on September 23, 1988 and sent f from Rideau Hall, Ottawa, ON to Doris McCarthy.
RIDEAU HALL OTTAWA
LE GOUVERNEUR GENERAL THE GOVERNOR GENERAL
September 23, 1988
Dear Miss McCarthy:
As Chancellor of the Order of Canada, it has been my privilege to preside over nine Investitures. It is always with a deep sense of pride that I have the honour of recognizing Canadians who serve their country well.
This is a particularly exciting time for everyone associated with the Order of Canada. You may be aware that 1992 is the 25th anniversary of the Order, which was established on July 1st, 1967. We at Rideau Hall, as well as the members of the Advisory Council, will be involved in planning activities to ensure the success of the anniversary year of this distinguished honour.
To this end, I feel it is important that we work together to attract the attention of all Canadians, particularly the youth of our country, to help them discover the value of striving for excellence, of being the best they can be in their chosen field. We must collaborate to ensure that every Canadian recognizes the example set by lives characterized by courage and perseverance, by commitment and sharing.
I urge you, as an exemplary citizen of Canada and a leader in your field, to assist in this important task. I encourage you, as one of the builders of our nation, to be an "Ambassador of the Order of Canada", to wear your insignia proudly and to promote the importance of recognizing excellence.
Miss Doris Jean McCarthy, C. M. , R C. A. 1 Meadowcliff Drive Scarborough, Ontario M1M 2X8

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Letter from Doris McCarthy to M. Leopold H. Amyot, Secretary General of the Order of Canada, nominating Joy MacFadyan for membership in the Order of Canada M. Leopold H. Amyot, Secretary General of the Order of Canada, Rideau Hall, Ottawa, K1A 0A1
Dear M. Aymot,
It is with great pleasure that I nominate Joy MacFadyen (Mrs, H. MacFadyen of 62 Rossander Drive, Scarborough, M1J 2B7) to membership in the Order of Canada.
Mrs MacFadyen has, almost single-handedly, created in Scarborough a climate of participation in and support for the arts. In 1968 she sought out as many active visual artists as she could find in what was then the Borough of Scarborough and invited them to a meeting to consider forming an organization which could become for them a voice and an opportunity for interaction. From this modest beginning she has been able to develop an umbrella organization which involves all the arts, literary, musical, and dramatic as well as visual. The recent issues of the newspaper published by "Arts Scarborough", which I enclose with this letter, bear eloquent testimony to the variety and energy of the present membership.
This has not been an easy achievement. Scarborough was an arid world when I moved here in 1940 . It deserved its contemptuous nick-name, "Scarberia". I have watched the change with appreciative amazement, and seen that Joy MacFadyen has been the catalyst. She would be the first to praise the many workers who have rallied to her. She is a modest, unassuming woman, a quiet but indefatigable worker. Already she is setting new goals. While her eyes are fixed on far horizons, her hands are busy with the details of the jobs that must be done to reach them.
The Order of Canada is an appropriate way to honour such a person, and so demonstrate Canada's committment to a creative life for its citizens.
Some of the people who have worked with her, and can witness to her worth are:
Naomi Lightbourn, Community Arts Development Officer, 151 Bloor St. West, Suite 500, Toronto, M5S 1T6
David Masters, at present treasurer of Arts Scarborough, long time worker in that organization, c/o Price Waterhouse, 1200 Markham Road, Scarborough, M1H 3C3
Bruce Fleury, Commissioner of Parks and Recreation, City of Scarborough, 150 Borough Drive, Scarborough, M1P 4N7 large folds & large tears at two folds, top & bottom edges uneven, pencil

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Seniw, Thomas, 1942 -
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Order of Canada; Seniw, Thomas, 1942 -
rdf:Description.dc:description:
A congratulatory letter for the Order of Canada in which, the artist Thomas Seniw, also discusses religious influences on his art as well as Doris McCarthy's work "Iceberg Fantasy", this letter was sent on April 30, 1987, from McCill University, Faculty of Religious Studies, Montreal. Que. McGill University
Faculty of Religious Studies William and Henry Birks Building (514) 392-4828
Miss Doris McCarthy, April 30th., 1987 1 Meadowcliff Drive, Scarborough, Ontario.
Dear Miss McCarthy:
I would like to take this opportunity to extend to you my most sincere congratulations on your appointment as a Member of the Order of Canada.
While being named to the Order of Canada does indeed recognize your achievements as a Canadian artist, I would submit that this honor is testimony to your lifelong commitment to pedagogics and to the students you have served during your most distinguished career as Teacher in the Visual Arts.
Thank you for your note acknowledging my exhibition here at McGill. The works shown were a practical visual expression of the more discursive approach taken up in my M.A. Thesis Dissertation on the religious implications of Martin Heidegger's philosophy of art and aesthetics.
Your comments on the liturgical aspects of your art interested me very much. I share your interest in what may be described as the religious component in the artistic ritual process inherent to the creation of the Work of Art.
For some time now I have understood my own artistic producing process to be a type of religious activity analogous to sacred ritual. As a matter of record, after having obtained my B.A. in Art History, it was from this intuitive cognition that I chose to continue my Post-Graduate Studies in the Faculty of Religious Studies.
Though not commited to any one specific religious orthodoxy I have undertaken a comprehensive study of the relationship between Religion and The Arts, more particularly those religious phenomena related to the Creative Process in Art.
Of special interest is the Byzantine aesthetic in the Tao of Painting and the border territory between Religion, Art and Psychology being explored by the Jungian school of analytic psychology.
Your painting, Iceberg Fantacy. that served as cover design for the Wynick/Tuck Gallery invitation, announcing your March, 1987, exhibition, is an especially fine example of what Rudolf Otto has described as those most fundamental elements of the Numinous or the Holy — the Mysterium and the Tremendum.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: Proulx, Madeleine

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Response from Madeline Proulx, Chief, Orders Chancellery of Canadian Orders and Decorations, to Doris McCarthy's letter nominating Joy McFadyen to the Order of Canada, sent on November 13, 1987 from Rideau Hall, Ottawa, ON. Order of Canada Ordre du Canada Rideau Hall Ottawa K1A 0A1
HONOURS IN CONFIDENCE
November 13th, 1987
Mrs. McCarthy:
I acknowledge receipt of your letter dated October 25th, concerning the nomination of Mrs. Joy McFadyen for possible appointment to the Order of Canada. Thank you for drawing my attention to the correct spelling of her name.
In answer to your query, we will contact the references you suggested and there is no need for you to do so. I should mention, also, that it is unnecessary to mount a write-in campaign for a nominee; the result might quite likely be the opposite of that anticipated.
Because of the number of people involved in the nomination process and the high volume of submissions we receive, and given our limited resources, we find it difficult to inform nominators that their nominations have been successful or not. In addition, a non-appointment at the first review does not eliminate consideration at future sessions of the Advisory Council. Therefore, if you have not heard anything from the media about an appointment in two years, you may wish to contact us regarding the status of your submission.
I trust this will be useful and appreciate your interest in this matter.
Yours sincerely,
Madeleine Proulx Chief, Orders Chancellery of Canadian Orders and Decorations
Mrs. Doris McCarthy, C.M., A.O.C.A., O.S.A., C.S.P.W.C., R.C.A. 1 Meadowcliff Drive Scarborough, Ontario M1M 2X8

Follow-up etter from Doris McCarthy to Madeline Proulx, Chief Orders Chancellery of Canadian Orders and Decorations, regarding the nomination two years ago of Joy McFadyen to the Order of Canada, sent on March 30, 1989 from Scarborough ON. 1
1 Meadowcliff Drive, Scarborough, Ontario, M1M 2X8, March 30,1989
M. Proulx, Chief, Orders Chancellery of Canadian Orders and Decorations, or Successor.
Dear Ms. Proulx,
It is now close to two years since I nominated Mrs. Joy MacFadyen for possible appointment to the Order of Canada, and I am beginning to fear that my nomination has been forgotten.
I should be sorry if you missed this outstanding woman by neglecting to make the enquiries which would confirm my estimate of her character and achievements. Mr. Gus Harris who was mayor of Scarborough during the most dramatic period of the development of Arts Scarborough, the umbrella organization which owes its existance to her vision, has retired from public life. He has been replaced by Mrs. Joyce Trimmer who was on council for several years and will be familiar with Mrs. MacFadyen's work.
I am enclosing a copy of the latest number of the Arts Scarborough newspaper to allow you to judge from it the vitality and breadth of the movement that she initiated, and the amount of public and corporate participation which it is attracting.
Her appointment to the Order would be acclaimed.
Sincerely,
Doris McCarthy, C.M. R.C.A., O.S.A. curling edges & tears, wrinkles, pencil

OFFICE OF THE PRINCIPAL
February 3, 1987.
Mrs. Doris Jean McCarthy, 1 Meadowcliff Drive, Scarborough, Ontario. MlM 2X8
Dear Doris:
I was so pleased, indeed delighted, to learn that you have been selected by Governor General Jeanne Sauve to become a member of the Order of Canada. On behalf of all members of the faculty, staff and your fellow students, I would like to extend to you our warmest congratulations.
This must surely be the first time such an honour has been bestowed on one of our students. It is a most fitting recognition of your lengthy list of achievements as an outstanding Canadian artist and teacher, and to which I would add university scholarship winner.
We at Scarborough College feel it would be appropriate to hold a reception in your honour, possibly some time in March or early April, and would like to invite friends both from within the College and your many other areas of interest and involvement. I have asked Doreen Marks to contact you in order to discuss the arrangements.
Once again, our congratulations and best wishes. We are very proud to be able to count you as one of our students.
Sincerely yours,
G.R. Williams Principal.

On behalf of our President, Mrs. Claudette Fortier, and the Board of Governors of the Canadian Conference of the Arts, I would like to congratulate you on your recent nomination to the Order of Canada.
As you may know, the Canadian Conference of the Arts is a national association acting to promote the encouragement and advancement of arts and culture in Canada and to serve the interests of Canadian artists. Established in 19^5, the Conference's membership now includes a spectrum of over 1,200 organizations and individuals in the field of the arts and the cultural industries.

With heartfelt congratulations, I remain,
Sincerely yours,
Michelle d'Auray National Director

August 21, 1992 Dear Miss McCarthy :
Earlier this year, Government House received a request from a Companion of the Order of Canada, Mr. Peter C. Well, I got bored after the first two, and just slowed down at the others. At via Sicilia. I “met” the other car coming from my right. I was wrong, wrong, wrong. I also had a chattering women beside me – in the ‘’death seat’ – and I was sort of concentrating on her conversation when a great white mass of American Ford Council station Wagon came ploughing into me; There was a woman at the wheel. rdf:Description.dc:description: A letter from her mother, Jennie McCarthy, to Doris McCarthy, wishing her a happy 39th birthday while she is on a painting trip to the Gaspe. 2 I was thinking of you. I hope you are spending a very happy day. I had your card this morning written Monday night and you sound so happy in the Gaspe surroundings. I hope you have nice weather that will help to make your stay more enjoyable - Our extreme bad weather broke yesterday and was I ever happy. I don’t think I could have stood it much longer. Its effects my breathing old bones cannot take it. There were several deaths among the aged from exhaustion. Everybody I know is away. Shirly left Monday last for Coopers Falls to be gone 2 weeks she has cousins there and they were coming to Toronto and wanted her to go home with them so off she went. Mrs M Lees is up at her cottage for a month. Then in August Beth and her husband and of course the babe have rented her cottage for August - The Jenkings plan to get away Saturday for Dibgy N.S. but as usual they did not make it. Some landslides on their property so they have to wait upon the someone Council – another delay - Ruth is getting impatient because she is tired and needs the rest. She admits it won’t be restful with her father along and would have preferred to have gone somewhere alone with her canoe. But as she says as long as she has her parents her own wishes must step aside for theirs and he is keen to go to Nova Scotia and the Sea. Douglas only got the jeep Tuesday. He was disappointed but the garage man said you told him you were going away and would not need it so he put it to one side and it was only when they phoned to know when it would be ready that he woke up and made the repairs. rdf:Description.dc:title: Letter to Doris McCarthy's father from her maternal grandfather
rdf:Description.dc:creator: Moffatt, Archie
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Biography; Moffat, Archie;
rdf:Description.dc:description:
A letter from Doris McCarthy's maternal grandfather, Archie Moffatt, sent to her father George A. McCarthy regarding his second proposal to Doris' mother and his consent, sent from Montreal, June 18, 1900. Monday June 18, 1900 Montreal My dear Mr. McCarthy I have to apologize for my apparent neglect in not replying to your letter of the 10th more promptly but the question put is so serious that it must be my excuse for taking time to deliberate and consult – In my mind an engagement is as serious and binding as marriage and the interest of my daughter, for whom my love cannot be expressed in words, demands that it should not be lightly entered upon or without serious reflection. While I really appreciate the honor. you for a second time confer on me I regret you have not taken me more into your confidence respecting your worldly prospects for as I told you six months ago that was the only reason I had in hesitating to give my consent; for while I have the fullest confidence in your honor and good intentions. I know that young people are over sanguine and hopeful and consider the sentimental side of such a question rather than the material which I am sorry to say after all is the most enduring. However to relieve you from suspense, I give my consent, but I hope you will not misunderstand me. If I ask you to write me more fully on the above subject and to regard me always as your friend and wellwisher.
AW Moffatt large folds

The sermon on forgetfullness of every-day incedents was so dry that I bussied myself with finding my favourite passages in the Bible.
Mr and Mrs Hacking were coming for dinner so I changed my dress and put in the time (f)? before our guests arrived with copying my "adventures of Dot and Dimple". At last they came. Mrs. Hacking is a dear. She has light brown hair and wears it short and curly. She had lovely manners and I know mother was pleased with her for afterwards she said "Mrs. Hacking is a nice, wellspoken little girl."
We had goose and apple-sauce and plum pudding for dinner.
Miss Putt was not at Sunday School so we had Catherine Harris for our teacher and the library was closed so I had to bring back my book.
When I got home I started my story about Fluff and wrote till supper was ready.

January 3rd 1922 In the morning Miss Baker the dressmaker came so I had to be fitted and it was not till after two O'clock that I met Marjorie for the first time since the Friday night I slept with her and went skating. My skates worked fine.
Marjorie told me the plot of her story. It was about a little girl, "Sunny of the Alley" she was called who was a little ray of sunshine wherever she went. The other children of the alley loved her so that they made her Portly Pillar Princess, the Portly Pillar being a remnant of the alley's better days. She pointed out some mistakes but they were all in the rythmn and we knew that was very defective.
January 18 Maids of Malvern Meeting. The meeting consisted of the minutes and all the things like that also!!! Song Contest. Our form only having a few representitives gave no song but all others omitting 1E did. The fifth form was the best but as it was for intercollegiate purposes the fourth form got the shield. The club paper was read and after we all took out our chairs a dance developed.
January 19 To-night Marjorie and I went over to the Beach Avenue Methodist Church to a banquet. They served Cold pork Hot Scolloped Potatoes 2 kinds of Jelly Celery Bread and Butter Apple Pie and ice-cream. After we had finished eating we went down to the gym and told stories in verse as mentioned ? my other thing.
Saturday Jan. 21 This afternoon at 2 O'clock I went down to the church and got into an awful mix-up about the play. Miss Vatcher wanted to have it and mother had promised to give it to Miss Graham. As soon as I arrived home Marjorie came up and called for me and together we went down to Miss Grahams and showed the play to her. "I have a little girl only four and a half years old acting" she said. After we came out of there we went to the library and got books out.
February 3, 1922 Lots and lots of things have happened since I wrote in you last little Sundial. Chief among them were 1. Last Sunday Marjorie and I finished copy my that parts of our play out and delivered them to Mrs. Graham. The practise that was to be on Monday was called off I suppose because she was just going to distribute the parts that day. All Wednesday night (I mean tuesday night and early Wednesday morning) I had a very bad ear ache. Although nothing that could not stand it kept me from sleeping and it was dreadful waiting for mother. When she came home she dropped oil in it and by a quarter after two or thereabouts I managed to doze off. I didn't go to school the next day but Thursday I went. I didn't take drill. Then after I had swallowed what was in my mouth I spit to get the (sl?) taste away and mother says I spit all I didn't throw out, away.

She is in a quandry as to what to have for a mystery and also thinks things are going too much for "Marie Eleanor". She thinks M.E. ought to have more trouble at first. Maybe she should. I can't seem to Feb 8 get any decent ideas for "Orphan Gracie". I don't know what to have happen at the haunted house or at the picnic. I have finished the fire, new teacher, and revolution and am just up to where the lawyer is going to arrive on Christmas day. In a while Fluff will be finished but Dot and Dimple is dry as pancakes. I am just writing the part about their visit to the moon.

The coppies of the play arrived to-day. They are peachy.

We read and wrote all this morning and I am now reading ^ or before I started writing I was Period."
Tuesday February 28 Just think little book today is Princess Mary's wedding day. It gives me thrills just think of it. Over here in Canada and in Toronto it is bright clear and oh this day does seem almost sacred in its beauty. By means of wireless you will be able to hear the Wedding Music 500 miles out at sea. There was a picture of her gown worn by another girl in last nights paper. It is marvellous. All cobwebby silky something overskirt and a marvellous satin gown. Jack Biddle (f) left saturday. He has promised to bring me a leaf or something actually from Westminister Abbey where Princess Mary is to be married. Queen Mary is to waken her daughter with a kiss for it is a Royal tradition that every Princess should on her Wedding Day speak first to the Queen her mother. The United States only sent her one gift. It was a candleabra from the New York Police Reserves. They are mostly Irish but isn't it queer that a police force should send her a present? She is to be at the Abbey at 11 O'clock. There is one girl only 14 years of age to be her bridesmaid. Isn't it wonderful? She must by so excited she can hardly speak. I am putting a lot of clippings in you for safe keeping. Pictures and accounts. The 14 year old girl is Lady Diana Bridgman an is my social ideal. (Miss Ra - deleted)) Lady Rachel Cavendish is Marjorie's. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

Enough said of course I have to go all over it correcting changing and modifying but I have finished every incident. This is about my most sacred day. I wonder if it will be acceptable at all. Oh their are so many things that I wonder. Will they ever be satisfied. I thought of something more I had to write just this minute what was it?
Wednesday March 8 I have won the oratorical contest!!!!!! It was this afternoon and I inclose pin that pinned my sheets of composition together. I wore my white silk waist under my school jumper and I know I look nice. I thought I take cotiption fits when Mr. Rogers read my name out. He took an awful long time deciding though and spoke a lot before anouncing it. Mr. Blake was a !!judge!! Miss Simons and Mr. Rogers were too. Afterwards Miss Simons came up to me and said "Let me congratulate you Miss McCarthy." I thought I'd faint and I don't see how I ever managed to say "Thank you." I scurried away as quickly a possible but I bet Babs was glad for she had told me she would chew her hat if I didn't get the prize. I was terribly nervous but it was worth it cause mother is going to give me lobsters for lunch to-morrow. We had a French exam yesterday and I think I did pretty well. Dorothy Bassman says I got 92% (82%?)in Comp but I'm not sure. P.S. I got 45 in Comp - Mr. B was not (double underlined) a judge. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

It is Saturday March 18 but much more important it is the day of my "first" Shakespeare Play. But let me begin at the beginning. I met Marjorie at 1 O'clock at the bottom of Balsam as arranged. There was a blockade in the cars so we walked to the first one and inquired how long it would be. We received the none too satisfactory answer of 2 hours. Just then a little ford coup� drove up and the conductor asked the man if he would give us a lift. The car was crowded so we didn't get in at it. Then a beeauutifuul Hudson limosine drove up with only two men in the front and in we hopped having palpitations of the heart the while.
When we got fairly under way however this left us and it realy was lovely riding in the beautiful easy silent ? prettily lined limosine. The two men in the front talked taxes and said not a word to us except to ask where we wished to be put off. He left us at the corner of Queen and Sherbourne telling us to take a Belt-line car.
We arrived at the Royal Aleck in fine time and read a little of the Girl of the Limberlost before the curtain rose. The play is a never-to-be-forgotten one.

Marjorie give me a very pretty Easter egg. It has white icing around the joint and a very sweet white dove and lily of the valley on the top. We went for a ride yesterday but we are no farther on in our house. I didn't go to Hoods after all for Bobs phoned me to say that Dorothy B. couldn't come. I don't believe I have in that Sir John Eaton died. Well he did on Friday, Apr the 7th. Mrs. Begg down the street died on Easter Sunday. She leaves 5 orphan children. Mrs Turner of Spruce Hill died on Easter Sunday too. Marjorie Whitelaw's mother died ditto.
Saturday April 22 On May 1st the Play is going to be. I saw a rehearsal the other day (day before yesterday) and was much impressed. I have got money for 24 tickets and have sold 53 and have orders for 15 besides a lot of people to "phone." Mother and Mrs. Beer are paying for the program. I went down to the York Chapter Meeting on Thursday. Marjorie gave her speech. It was lots of fun hearing a real meeting and I enjoyed it.
May-day - play day I enclose programme, ticket and Sunday's leaflet. I awoke this morning with a funny feeling that something was going to happen. Then I remembered - the Play - I lay in bed a while, shivering with excitement but finally loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

Mr. Blakely took the nominations and votes for the ID Girls Baseball team. Barbara (Hood) got 15 votes, Dorothy Bassman 2 and Evylen Cross - 3.
We had a practise after school with 1B and had great fun. After playing till four o'clock I went down to Hoods and practised jumping for the field Day (May ?). It was twenty minutes after six when I got home. Mother showed me the flowers she had got for Mrs. Graham. They were pink carnations and beautiful. Then I had supper and went upstairs to dress. At about 7.05 O'clock I was at Beer's for Marjorie. She had gone to deliver some tickets so I went to Whitehams (?) to wait. Marjorie called for me shortly after and we went to the church. Daddy was the only one there at first but the hall filled rapidly and before we knew it we were having trouble in saving seats. Miss Baskervill's friend Miss Brown sat beside Marjorie and I. Mrs. MacWaters and Waters behind us and Mr. MacWaters and Miss Baskervill behind them. Marjorie and Jim and the Andersons (Including Jimmy and Drewy) sat there too. Olive Westerman is fourteen. Next year she is going to drop school and take up music. Now she practices 3 hours a day and stand 5 & 6(?) in class. She played beautifully. The dear darling little page played too and was sweet. Reta Stone's recitations were splendid and mostly pathetic loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

This day is an epoch in my life. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

Captain Trowel (?) called for us and drove up to the depot.
We had barely got inside the shed when the most terrific cyclone huricane thunderstorm downpour and tornado came up. It blew everything to bits and the dust inside that slated sheds! Good-night. A sign was blown down and (?) from the magazine stand and it kept the rest of the party from ariving until later. Therefore we missed our boat. We got on the next and the sun shone all the rest of the time. The storm had served only to clear the air and make it
cooler without even wetting the grass. I was disappointed for not having sense enough to bring a ball but Mr. West a nice, gray haired, old man, bought me a big black india rubber on one and a yellow (?) bat. I played ball most of the time and had great fun. Mrs. spilt tea on her dress and we had a few more screamish accidents. We went home about 1/2 past 8 and Trowel rode us home again. That was the 2nd night I had been up late in one week. With an exam coming to-morrow too. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

July 20 Lots and lots of things have happened. We are all settled now. There is the sweetest island accross from us. Dumbarton its name is but we call it Our Isle of Sunshine.
We have made up a song about it and a Poem, a real poem about a soldiers version of his parting and object. It is called A Solder's Quest.
The Richardsons who own Dunbarton are up with Miss Harryman a Junior in college.
We went to Church last Sunday. Mr. Crossly, Crossly and Hunter, the Evangelists, preached. Mr. Hunter is dead and whenever Mr. Crossly spoke of him he referred to him as Mr. Hunter, My Beloved. Mr. C. is a dear old man with a young face in spite of the fact that his hair is white. His front of his head is bald but he has white fluffy hair and is dear. He preached a dear sermon. More of a talk than anything

Marjorie and I have not done much on our books but with resolutions for the future "put it off".
I got 2 books for my birthday, a wonderfull Ivory mirror (given to me before we left to prevent it being broken), a lovely blue Bird nightgown to match our room (Marjorie has one too, she gave it to me) and a photograph of herself. A box of candies too so I was very lucky. About the third day we were here Doctor Ferrier took us to Bala. We saw Mary who gave us an orange and a piece of her lovely raisin pie each. Marjorie and I have fallen in love with the Doctor.
Eric has developed from a nice quiet gentlemanly little chap into the most boisterous crazy tease. Yes, yes, of course, In other words," says he every minute of the day.
He is awfully funny Marjorie and I have made the acquaintance of Ruth MacKay. She is an awful nuisance. I have given her more than one hint but she's awfully slow at taking them. I don't like her much. She's such a bore.
We have killed a flying squirrel and burried it - ouch - Marjorie and I have established a Post Office, Castle Moss, Post Office. It is a Laura Secord Box in a hole in the loveliest moss covered stump. We drop notes in it from caracters, Killing Girls, Petty & Peggy, Polly & Peter and ?. The Bathing is wonderful. I can swim 6 times the width of the distance between the 2 wharves without touching once. I have done it 2 ? I am learning to dive.
Jim and Marjorie have been visiting us. We enjoyed loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

After we left there we got out into rough water and so great was the spray that we turned back to the millionaire's dock again. The proprietor was out fishing but the maid requested us to make ourselves at home. The Island was covered with paths, walks bordered by birgh logs. It was very pretty but - there was the most wonderful speed launch mahogany - It was beautiful, would carry 20 people without the least crowding. It was named the Carryall. We were all in love with it and out exclamations would have been pleasing I'm sure if they had fallen on the Madam's ears. We took a walk around the island and I got some grass which I braided. I have since lost it. We soon came down to the dock again and shortly after Mr.
Mellon whom I since learned was the nephew of the minister of finance of U.S.A., came in his fishing (mahogany) speed launch the Kumango (?). He had a catch of 18 huge bass some of which he directed the maid to take to some friends. He is the typical millionaire a fat round big red nose, double chin, portly manner, and coloured glasses (also fat). He ordered his chaufeur to bring us home in his Kumango. We were overwhelmed. I'll never, never forget that ride. It was wonderful. I since learned that he has 3 more boats, the Regal? and Sokemall? and the Lorimer? that Dorothy Bassman says is a houseboat. Marjorie and I wish we wern't against each other.

Mar 25 Marjorie and I went out to Mrs. McWaters today, and after looking through her scrap book and talking awhile, decided to burry home for it was storming hard. We got all ready but had to wait some time for a car, and after hearing a whistle which was from the wrong direction, relaxed our viligence and let one get by. Later fearing to miss a second we went out and stood by the tracks in the blizzard. One was just coming when to our surprise not unmixed with dismay a car drove up and offered us a lift, and we hopped in.
A man was driving and in the front a girl sat wedged between him and another man while in the back M & I were sitting with another man and girl. They were singing the awfullest songs (for it was Sunday such as Three O'clock in the morning
Mar 25 which Marjorie and I considered appropriate, Tomorrow, When Francis dances with me, something about "and the wind blows up his trousers" and other similar and even worse things.
Mother was vexed and made me promise never to accept a drive from a stranger again. Last night M & I started our scrap books down at Beers. We had more fun! I stayed for supper and after, we got going and roared and laughed right up to the time I got home.
On March 17 M& I got out our Bicycles and originated the Royal Order of the Bulls.
March 28 We have ? nothing further about the elections except that 4 votes are allowed. Piggy? is away so he hasn't passed the nomination list yet. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

Thursday April 5 Marjorie phoned me up this afternoon and I went down there after supper to stay all night. It was pouring rain but just before I got in it turned to snow which melted as soon as it had fallen.
It was the night of the ex pupils dance and Eleanor was going with Jack. They were waiting down in the dining room for Sig and Ham who, in the end, phoned that they wouldn't call) so M & I decided to have some fun. We went to the corner in the stairs from where E could see us but J could not.
We tormented her for a while and then conceived the brain wave of throwing a note via dart, to her. As we completed it E came upstairs so that plan was off. We had a dart throwing contest in the livingroom then in which we became so engrossed that we didn't hear E and J go away.

Curly - Curly was the one who shot Wendy Twins - M. thought their voices were very shrill but I think they were dear Hook - He was great. His hook was sticking right out of a bit of log which served for an arm. His face was all lined and he was terrible looking. He had a terribly cruel face. I got her to autograph a ticket
afterwards
Sat. April 21 This afternoon mother had just finished washing my hair when M. phoned to say come on down and for a ride. I hurried and we drove away out to Mimico. Much to our distress we dod not see the school or the Ferriers.?

Margaret Dixon came first and second. (They weren't a patch on last year)
Today was the Maids of Malvern meeting. M & I were so excited.
Mary was elected President. We were wildly joyful.

Yvonne Robarts secretary (not so much joy. M & I clutch each other closer.

Thursday 4 (see a page back)

I knew Ken's results were out and I knew Ken had passed.
I ran into the house and it was true. I just ran upstairs and hugged all the comforter and thanked God. Oh it was wonderful I felt so happy I didn't dare believe it. It was that forever blessed Mr. Westman whom Ken had had for supper one night.
All our terrible despairing ? fears that he would fail or have a sup and that we couldn't go to Silver Island were groundless. WE CAN GO.
I phoned up M. but the fudge had forced her to be slightly indisposed and she was sleeping. That news cured her.

I was heart broken to leave the dear old place but ever day brings Silver Island 24 hours nearer.
Wed 20. Marjorie and I so busy planning for Silver Island and stringing beads.

Yesterday M & I went down to Kew to play tennis with Chris and Ray, her friend. M & Chris had a good time. It was a scorching day.

About 9.00 Oliphant came and carted the trunks, bagage, Daddy and Doug away. Then mother and I put in a long 3/4 of an hour waiting for Dr. Beer. Laurie came down to say goodbye before Oliphant came. I made some tags for our umberellas and played Peggy O'neil on the piano until at last, to our overwhelming relief we heard Dr. Beer.
He took us down to 2212 where he dropped Harry who had come for the ride and picked up Marjorie who was very excited and full of parcels. We drove to the station where we met Daddy and Doug and the trunks. M & I hurriedly hunted for some place to weigh ourselves but were not successful in finding one.
We had just time to walk
up and down the platform playing Polly and Peter when a train came in, which, however, proved to be GBR(?) from Chicago. M, after this had gone by dint of writing notes and catching Daddy's eye, managed to convey to him that she was sending the Mail and (?) to Silver Island and there was no need of him to do so also.
At last our train came and then what excitement there was. We were all bustled on and in the confusion M. lost her father and didn't have a proper chance to say goodbye to him. It was deliciously exciting, and confusing and hilarious.
After we were comfortable settled M started to read Christopher and Columbus. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

But we were interrupted by mother who was telling us that the quiet little boy sitting in the seat behind us had turned out to be the boy who was taking Erics place.
Mother had discovered him by admiring his lovely boxes of worms, and after asking him where he was bound for discovered to her surprise that it was for Bala Park.
"What part of Bala Park" she asked and he answered "Silver Island".
M found out where the Ferriers were. We had a happy reunion with them. Miss Irene who was not present was coming up with Chester on Monday.
It took quite a while for us to finish our little reunion and just before we went mother started talking politics and got into quite an argument with Mr. Ferrier whose big booming voice sounded down the car "Well I voted for a Conservative candidate anyway". We were glad to pull mother back to our car.
At last we arrived at Bala Park after having had lobster and Ham sandwhiches for lunch and having, as last year, thrown some silly notes to YOU. Mortimer was at the dock to meet us. The Moors, Ferriers and we were all wanting to be accomodated. Eddie took us and the Moors home. Oh how wonderful it was when we saw Spy Glass. M's eye worried her considerably. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

Fri. June 29 Today we went all around the Island and it was joy to see the dear places again. I love them.
After we came home we helped Doug (?) out the well and had lots of fun doing so especially as we spilt a plentious supply on Doug's nose (he was down in the well). His faces were comical.

There were continual goings back and forth all day and M and I had supper over there at which we were very glad for supplies are fearsomly low over here.

Marjorie and I paddled to Innis Fallen with the others in the row boat and then to Duck from where we came home. Marjorie put her foot through Duck's verandah. Mother finding Mrs Beer didn't have M's watch combed the sand diligently but finally it was found in Mrs. Beer's shoe. Eleanor stayed for supper which we ate on the front verandah where I killed my head on the wall.

The supply boat didnt come, much to our consternation.
July the seventh. My Birthday. Marjorie and I got up fairly early this morning and went down to the docks to see if there was anything on the lines to our mingled joy astonishment and dismay there was a catfish. Claiming him for our own we cleaned him and - well, least said soonest mended. It was awful. After we had it head cut of its tail and fins also(?) off it insides out and it partly skinned it was wiggling.
When we came home breakfast was ready and Oh! Joy, sitting on my chair was a darling little No.2 Brownie. I love it and it was the biggest surprise. It was from Marjorie. After breakfast M & I paddled over to Dunbarton where Mr. MacWaters (naughty man) gave me 2 dollars and Mrs. Beer, ???. I had the happiest birthday. M & I had our Indian spyglass ceremony today and the great mystery of the postcard from ? developed. We also had our grand scramble while Doug was trying to obtain privacy in his bedroom and we locked him in. When we went bathing Doug and May and I had a grand water scramble in which we pushed each other into the water. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

Much to our relief for we were very short of sypply owing to its neglecting us on Friday. We learned from Sir Oracle otherwise called Romsy(?) that it was because the Newminco (?) had broken down that the supply boat ran in the upper lake where they would make more money and not because or Mr Hannah's death. Tennis as per usual.
July 11 Wednesday Mrs. Beer, Mrs MacWaters and May left today for Toronto via Eddie. Dr. Chester Ferrier came plopped at some darling squirrels and sang a bit also went in swimming. I went over to Dunbarton and we started Emmy Lou. Every one came to sleep here.
Thursday July 12 Doug and I played 2 sets of tennis before swimming in the morning and 2 in the afternoon. I discovered my desk in the stone country. After supper I played 6 sets without an intermission 2 with Doug 1 doubles - Miss I.F. and I against Miss A.F. and Doug 2 sets with Miss A.F. 1 set with M and Miss A.F. We got a letter from Henry.
Friday July 13 - It was today we heard from Henry I got mixed. We had some tennis early in the morning and I had some more with Doug later when Marjorie was prevented coming over by the roughness. The supply boat came and Doug brought her over for it.
This evening we reviewed our operas and had lots of fun. Marjorie found a peace pipe and bust the bowl off it (B.B.)
Saturday July 14 We had a game of tennis in the morning and went in swimming shortly after to M's delight for she had missed her bathe on Thursday and Friday. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

After dinner I wrote Miss Baskerville and went over to Dunbarton where we read Emmy Lou and played solitaire. At last we saw Daddy's canoe coming and went home in the row boat. I accidently splashed Marjorie whereupon she moved up into the bow, whereupon I splashed her purposely to make her come back to the result of her arriving soaking wet. After supper we went over to Dunbarton to watch for their arrival which as late.
Sat 14 We posted lanterns and candles on the way up to the house and M and I organized an impromptu dance to greet them.
Daddy brought Bananas, Barney Google backed by I love me and you tell her I stutter.
I hate Barney but the rest are great.
Sunday July 15 Today is mothers birthday. Mr. Ferrier gave us a fish which Marjorie and I cleaned early and we saw the full come down and take the things. My there are cruel looking birds.
We all went over to Innis Fallen to show it to daddy in the morning and we got some nice pictures (or I hope they will be nice) of M & I in the canoe.
I gave mother 3 lbs of Laura's for her birthday.
I painted a number of pictures loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

We were with Eleanor and Mrs MacWaters a lot. Strange to relate Marjorie coaxed me onto the Flyer. Never again! (till next year)
The School (bless it) had a farewell presentation to Miss Symons and gave her a lovely 1/2 doz. sherbert glasses. She looked a dream.
Sep. 6 I got my little sister Kathleen ? today. She's a darling and not very tall.
Mon. Dec.26
I went down to Bobs to listen in on her Radio tonight and when I came home Ken told me that Marjorie had asked me to phone her.
Guess what it was. Small Edwin Charles had been born at nine o'clock. Marjorie was so excited she could hardly speak.
We had our corn roast early in October or late in September. It was a great success. The most romantic moment of my whole life was when I passed the gate of Le chateau des quatre Vends - the loveliest name for a house on a big bluff overlooking the lake I can imagine, and when we were walking down the hundred steps it was dark and silent. A mist hung over the water but the moon shone across it. I seemed to be truly walking on air. I'll never forget the wiers(?) mystery and delight of the moment. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

After supper we played musical chairs and danced. It was quite exciting. Doug saved me from utter mortification by dancing with me.
A few days before Christmas we went up to the school and packed the boxes for our poor families. My girl was 15 years old, Florence Primrose. I have put a sprig of holly left over into my treasure book.
Thursday Dec 27 I went to see A Midsummer Nights dream today. It was awfully pretty. The fairies were dears. In the morning mother and I went uptown to choose me a dress. We met Marjorie and Eleanor and the doctor and had a little family reunion. There was the most desperate sale on.
Dr. Beer is running for board of Education again and it is going to be a stiff fight.
Oct 4 1924 It is almost a year since I wrote in my diary last and so much has happened in that time.
I have been to Silver Island for another summer. Mother was so sick she didn't think she would be able to go so Douglas, Harvey and myself went on Thursday the 3rd. Miss Baskerville joined us on Saturday. The following Saturday Marjorie arrived and on the 18th. Mother and Daddy came up a few days later. Aunt Nell went home and Miss, Mr. and Mrs. Jenkins came. Harvey also left. On the ?th of August Mother, Douglas, Marjorie and I, came home.

For the first time in my life I have been taken out by a boy. It was almost 2 weeks ago Sept. the 22nd to the 5th forms corn roast.
Glen Hoffman phoned me up on Thursday and asked me if I would like to go to the corn roast with Jimmie Cunningham. I scarcely knew what to say I was so flustered and Doug shouted into the phone that I had to be home by ten o'clock to have my bath. I could hear Glen repeat it to Jimmie and I heard them roar and laugh. I shut down the phone I felt so mortified. Doug and Laurie were down and I should like to have canned them. A few minutes afterward the phone rang again and it was Hoffman again. I said no thank you and shut off. I have never felt so queer before. I wanted to go just as badly as could be but I couldn't accept an invitation by proxy. Nearly all that night I lay awake thinking of what I should have said.
I walked home from school with Audrey Mellons and Marjorie and stayed in all Friday afternoon on the hopes that he might phone.
It was Jimmie this time so I told him to phone again in the evening and I would be able to tell him whether I could go or not. We played Mah Jong all evening and I was so excited I could hardly wait. It was about 1/2 past eight when he phoned. The corn roast was to be held on Saturday and can you imagine my feeling when I saw that it was pouring rain. I stayed in the house all day hoping it would clear up but about 7 o'clock Jimmie phoned to say that it was postponed till Monday. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

Because Doris' journal was blank, she could write whenever and however much she wanted to on the pages. Doris also developed the habit of drawing/sketching at the same time as here interest in writing. Although there are some sketches in the journals, she \primarily used other exercise books for drawing. Monday was a gloomy day but better than Sunday. I put on a middie and my new wool crepe blue skirt and borrowed ? pins for my tie. Marjorie was going with Glenn. She wouldn't have been able to go on Saturday so I was awfully glad it had been postponed. I expected to feel rather silly anyway at the fifth form corn roast especially after the way Jimmie had been teased already. He came about about ten past seven. I went to the door. It was thrilling!! I just had to slip on my red sweater. There was rather an awkward pause just at the door. Jimmie didn't seem to want to go or something. He seemed to be waiting for something and I didn't like to push him out or anything. He asked me where Doug was and I thought he wanted to see him but I didn't take the hint. Once we got comfortable out of the house everything went smoothly. To my surprise it had cleared up beautifully and the stars were all shining. It was a nice walk down to Norris's where the corn roast was held and thanks to Marjorie and Audrey due to the fact that Eleanor Beer was at Whitby College the conversation didn't lag. I asked him about the night he and Hoff had taken us home from the Hockey game and he thought it was a great joke. We didn't see any sign of Marjorie on the way down. We walked down the hundred steps and speculated as to how many there really are. I think it is 144. Jimmie said that his idea of earthly bliss used to be to walk up and down those steps and count them. There didn't seem to be any sign of anyone when we got down there but we soon found a bunch of the girls. Do Dodd, ? Watson, Lillian Tattersall(?), Kay Hardy, Jean Martin loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

It was so very dark that they couldn't see us and it was most embarrassing explaining who we were. They all laughed. We were only the second installment of arrivals. We waited around for quite a while and finally Lillian ? and Do Dodd went up the steps again to see what was doing. As they didn't reappear we followed them and finally discovered that nearly everyone had gone through ? and down their steps onto the beach. We went down to. It was thrilling. It was so dark you couldn't see ahead of you and you had to guess where the steps were and there was always the danger of falling. They had brought heaps of wood with them and they started to light the fire when someone discovered that there was no paper so someone climbed up to the house to get some.
The fire was lighted and it was about nine O'clock when Karjorie and Hoffman arrived. We sat around and talked mostly until Doug arrived with the fair Helen (Sanderson). He started some games and we played farmer in his den, in and out window and French Tag. Mr. Blaney was there. Then they brought on the eats. It was glorious to feel you were really and just as much "in it" as everyone else. Neither Marjorie nor I really like Hoffman but Jimmieis as nice as can be. Mary sat and played the uke and sang to us while we ate. She knows lots more camp songs. When we had just about finished our buns and weiners Jimmie and Hoff arrived with bottle of pop. We were terribly thirsty and they did taste good until we got over out thirst. It really was vile. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds
