I spilt as much of it as I could on the sand so that helped.
Not long after we climbed up to the house and went up to Mary's room to get ready for dancing. Marjorie and I emptied our shoes over the balcony and into Do Dodds hair. Then we went downstairs to the livingroom. I was a perfect wall flower. Doug asked me for the tag dance. Ted Sanderson tagged me and kept me for another dance. Otherwise I was a wall-flower. As for Jimmie and Hoffman. They had vanished into thin air. There were quite a few other wallflowers so I didn't mind. Marjorie dances were nearly all taken.
They passed lemonade around in between 2 of the dances then to finish up with we gave three cheers for the ?
Harvey was down but of course did not dance except one dance with Mary who as M says is just like a sister to him.
If it was the noise of the cheers or what, Jimmie and Hoff were on deck when we came down but they didn't say anything about why they had disappeared. I don't suppose they could dance and I guess they decided that would be the simplest way of getting over the difficulty. The four of us stayed together until we left Marjorie at 2212 and then Hoffman left up at the corner of Balsam and Queen.
Jimmie and I parted at the steps. We talked for a few minutes and then I went it. I was so thankful that the front door was open. Mother was still awake and waiting for me. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

Jimmie is back at his old trick of ignoring me in the halls at Malvern. I wonder if he will ask me to anything else.
(Margin: I just made a very mortifying discovery Mrs. ? told Marjorie. When Glenn phoned up the first time he asked me to go with himself and not with Jimmie at all.)
The first rugby game of the season was yesterday at Scarboro against Jarvis.
Douglas is playing Senior this year. His team was beaten 12-20 but we beat their Juniors 28-0.
Oct 22 The 1st, 2nd and third Rugby games are over. We beat Jarvis at Scarborough Park 28-0 and Central Tech at Don flats 60-0. Then we met Oakwood at Scarborough. It was a lovely day but everyone was frightened silly. Did we lose - no my dear friends - we did not lose - we beat them 40-0.
It is my opinion that we'll never have a point scored against us and the last 2 times one of our best players was off at Central Tech Red Moores and at Scarborough Pat Taylor.
I am Discussion Groups on the cabinet this year. I am just getting it organized today.
I have had a class since early last spring (at Sunday school. It is very interesting and I wouldn't miss teachers meeting (Tuesday nights) for anything.
Baby Ben is huge. He is almost 11 months old and is just walking. He can stand up alone wonderfully and Marjorie told me yesterday that he has taken his first step.
His "Marjorie and Eleanor" teeth have been succeeded by many others. He's a perfect darling and I'm so glad that he doesn't make strange with me. loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

I saw one hanging on a tree And O his face was sad to see, - Misery, misery me!
There were berries red upon his head And in his hands and on his feet But when I tried to pick and eat They were his blood and he was dead, - Misery, misery me!
It broke my heart to see him there So lone and sad in his despair The marks of woe were in his hands And through his feet, - oh misery me!
With beak and claws I did my best To loose the nails and set him free, But they were all too strong for me, - Mysery, misery me!
I pushed and pulled and did my best And his red blood stained all my breast I bit the nails, I picked the thorns O never saw I thorns so worn But yet I could not get him free, - Misery, misery me!
And never since have I feared ? But ever I seek him when I can And let him see the wish in me To ease him of his misery.
Physical - water exercise wholesome food sleep, fresh air Intellectual - moderate reader of good books, well up in schoolwork practice, dancing Moral - ernest thoughtful unselfish kind reverent social - kind thoughtful not bold, ready to give ? loose pages, brittle, crumbly, yellowed, tears, folds

On Hallow-e'en Eleanor was home from Whitby. She had a birthday party or rather a Hallow-e'en dance. All the crowd were there. Seymour Wilson was also there. He is a teacher at St. Aidans is in 4B comes into our room for History and has walked home from teachers meeting with me once. A DAY AT THE KNOTHOLE
It is a good morning when I wake in time to see the sun open a red eye above the trees on the eastern shore of the bay. At this hour I can be leisurely about the coffee that I take back to bed, sipping it slowly, and staring between sips. The sky is gradually gaining colour above the heat haze which dims the far shore and the distant islands. A song sparrow flits on to the brush pile beside the stone fireplace on the rocks, and opens beak and throat in a burst of music. I watch a tubular brown mole scud from under the brush across the open rock into the sanctuary of the mossy hollow where the iris and the St. John's wort are in bloom. The gulls that were laughing and screaming at dawn have gone fishing, but a sandpiper lands on their favourite rock island, that lies like a giant half.submerged just off the shore. I watch him bob his way along the water edge up to the giant's head. Is it shad flies he's finding? There goes our resident beaver, a brown head leaving a silver wake as he glides smoothly past, off to work in the beaver meadow beyond the blasted channel, no doubt. He comes back to his home in the Keyhole bay at dusk every evening like a city commuter. I should take the hint and get going myself.
One of the pleasures of life at the cottage is the pine-carpetted path to the privy. Overnight as usual; the spiders have folds, staple holes, rust stains, pencil

Yesterday's sweep-out didn't get rid of the spiders, but I miss the heap of dried leaves and grasses from the shelf inside. For two years a red squirrel lived in that nest, and when surprised at night would lean out with his black button eyes, and then scurry along the top of the door and up over the roof. Now I have only old New Yorkers for company. Through the screen of pines and cedar undergrowth I see the sun sparkling on the bay, beckoning. Back at the cottage,I wrap the big towel around me, slide into my sandals, and pick up face cloth and soap on my way to the place where the rock goes smoothly off into deep water. Holding soap and face cloth high I venture one step into the wet - and slide the rest of the way. It's always comic when I find myself helpless to stop until I have reached deep water or fallen with a great splash beside the ledge that I use to pull myself out with. I soap, rinse and wallow, luxuriating in the sweet cold water At this hour I have the bay to myself. Virginia is probably awake, but never admits it until I am dressed, with my bed made, and she hears the wind chimes on the clothes line ring out, as I jerk them in hanging up my towel.
The cabin is tidied for the day, both beds orderly in their day covers, and the breakfast table inviting when we sit down together. I wait for Virginia's daily "I'm not awake yet", a ritual opening. After that I talk for both of us, reviewing the folds, staple holes, rust stains, pencil

The studio greets me with its familiar smell of sun-baked cedar and turpentine. The big canvas of the Mendenhall Glacier that I was working on yesterday confronts me from the easel. I open up my aluminum arm chair amd make myself comfortable in front of it. Any duck families on the bay this morning? The islands and the far shore are clearing. So how does the glacier look twelve hours later? The composition is still all right. I like the way it pulls your eye from the cloud-hung mountain down at an angle, and twists you again into the foreground. The near hill on the right seems a bit jumpy. Does that mean that the tone contrast is too strong? Let me lighten it. My palette is laid out from yesterday, but I check to be sure that all the colours are in good supply. I reach for a tube of white and start to unscrew the top before I remember gloves. Damn! This recent allergic reaction to turps is a curse! Oh well. Special hand cream first, hands waved in the air to speed drying, rubber gloves that I peeled off last night blown right side out and pulled on, painting apron tied around, and now, at last, the tube of white again. folds, staple holes, rust stains, pencil

The next time I leave the glacier is when the wheeze of the hand pump at the back door and the ring of the pot lid tells me that Ginny has finished in the kitchen and is putting washing to soak in the big pot on the wash stand outside. Half an hour later she is at her own easel beside her own stretch of windows facing the bay. If she comments on my work it is a good sign and I go on with renewed confidence. We are normally supportive of eachother. But if there is silence I look more critically at what I am doing. Sometimes I will ask for a criticism, sometimes set my teeth and press doggedly on. After a bit I realize that I have been whistling the same fragment of something or other all morning. "Sorry," I mutter. "Just change it", she suggests gently, and I do, at least temporarily.
We break to split a beer sometime during the morning. Today it is cool enough to enjoy the sun, so we sit up on the rocks in front of the cottage. The cedar chairs stay out all summer, but last year's stain seems to be holding up well. As outside maintenance man it is my job to keep an eye on such things. Chippie runs out from between two of the fireplace rocks, and sits, hand on heart, observing us. I go in to get some peanuts for him but he is off before I return. We put a few on the coffee table to tempt him back, and settle to enjoy the gulls, the movement of the water against the shore, the launches coming down the channel from Parry Sound, the wind surfers, and any signs of life we can observe around the cottages on the far shore folds, staple holes, rust stains, pencil

By lunch time it is too hot on the rocks. We carry the tray and our chairs to the shade of the grove of pin cherry trees in front of the studio, and watch the barn swallows feeding their young in the nest under the eaves. Those big red mouths! How do the parents keep track of which ones get fed each time?
Our official working day ends at four o'clock when our friends from the other two "holes" join us for tea. The cottages are held in a partnership, which gives their owners a sense of being a family. The largest is called the "Keyhole" after the little back bay which is roughly that shape. Ginny's and mine is known as the "Knothole", because it is not the Keyhole, and it is more rustic. The third cottage, out of sight beyond the big point, is the smallest of the three, and seemed well described as the "Cubbyhole". Ginny's brother named the high place which overlooks the peninsula on which the cottages lie, "Ben Hole". I carry enough chairs and the tea table to the sheltered side of the house. Ginny has the big tray set with everything needed and the kettle almost at the boil as our friends drift in. Tea is welcome and the home-made cookies appreciated, but the real attraction is the hour of reading together afterwards. When the day's chit chat is slowing and the blue china mugs refilled all around, the first reader starts. folds, staple holes, rust stains, pencil

Sayers' "The Mind of the Maker". We have good critical capacities in the group and some experience in thinking theologically and philosophically. Today we are reading and discussing Sayers1 chapter about free will and miracle. It is always too soon that someone remembers the time, and we break for the day, still arguing.
Virginia is chief chef. While I wash up the tea mugs, her head is in the refrigerator, setting in motion her well-organized plans for a good dinner. This is my hour for what I call road work, cutting dead limbs from trees, pruning lower branches to coax a tree to grow higher, shaping and changing. Today I am going to look for a big flat rock to widen the front step at the "Keyhole". I take the precaution of changing from sandals to rubber boots. The rock I find, is a segment cracked loose when the Hydro workers blasted to install our pole. The back of my intended rock is buried in moss and earth that I must scrape away to find its extent. There is a little overhang on one edge which will give me a chance to get a lever under. The wrecking bar won't do, too small, rock too heavy. But this six foot length of two by four, with a rock as a fulcrum, lets me lift it an inch or so. I repeat the process, shoving, putting all my weight on the end of my two by four, getting the rollers under, inch by inch, until I can begin to think of coaxing the big rock to move forward. Enough for today. I drop tools where they are, ready to go on with it tomorrow, peel my sticky clothes off my wet back, wrap the big towel about me and make for the bay. Sweet water! But it takes several duckings and sloshings before I stop tasting the salt. Today I soap my hair too, and lie back in the water feeling the little waves rinsing it for me. Ginny has the pots bubbling and a drink in her hand by the time I am dressed, but there's still time for a quick one for me. We take dinner seriously, the table formally set, the window beside it giving us pine trees for our candles, the ripening grasses and mulleins outside as our floral decoration, but on the table the lovely old blue flowered china that came with the cottage and our own sparkling glasses. The vegetable garden is producing well this year, beet greens and snow peas already, and the first of the tomatoes, red as a harbour buoy. My elderberry wine is a contralto note in the symphony of colour. Ginny pours herself another glass of it while I look after the washing up and carry the bowl of kitchen scraps over to the compost pile beside the garden. The sun is low by now, sending long shadows across the rocks, catching the brilliant white of the gulls riding in the bay, reflecting back from windows on the far island. Tonight, for the first time this season, we can get dry shod to the end of the long point.The gulls fly off screaming as we approach. Purple splotches on the rocks tell us that they have been raiding the blueberry bushes. Having explored the point in detail, we turn inland up through the juniper bushes, past the grove of big pines where my niece pitched her tent last year, up the long spine of glacier-scraped granite that leads to the high place. In the little hollows where dust has gathered and made soil, the tall grasses are ripening, moving in the breeze like the flaxen hair of the goosegirl in the fairy tale. At the top of the hill we settle. I lie on the sun-warmed rock with my head propped on the log of drift wood that we rolled into position up there years ago. Ginny sits beside me on the thickest part of the log, where arthritic knees have less difficulty getting up. We are monarchs surveying our kingdom. Rock by rock, tree by tree, we approve it. Each of the three hydro poles has its own herring gull on top. Good. Joe, our permanent resident ringbill, is patrolling in front of the cottage, screaming protest at any other gull who drifts in, and driving him off. Good. We watch a family of mergansers scramble up on to the Giant and settle into a tight cluster around mother, whose head flicks back and forwards in vigilance before she too settles for the night. When the sun drops out of sight below the woods behind us and Ginny slaps the first mosquito, I take it as a cue. Our return to the cottage is direct, accelerated by our unspoken eagerness for the penultimate chapter of the day. I carry the lamp to the table while Ginny brings the Scrabble box. She lays things out deftly. The poor board is shabby, stained with blood from many mosquitoes, worn with years of use. We set aside the lid in which records of notable scores are preserved, and fish out last night's score paper on which there is still space. "Let's hope I don't have another run of vowels", Ginny murmurs. "None at all is just as bad", I answer. We play sociable Scrabble, each more interested in high scores than in competition. If the board becomes too strangled, or a hand presents insuperable difficulties, the player spreads out the letters and we both study them to find a play. Our satisfaction with the achievement of a full seven letter word is mutual. Tonight is notable because I managed to get the word "eczema" on a triple for the very good score of sixty, and Ginny, who had been holding her breath while I decided where to play, let out a cry fo triumph because "warding", the seven letter wore she had hoped to be able to play, could join with my "a" to become "awarding", an eight letter word that added up to a score of eighty

In this handbook, Doris McCarthy documents the history of the construction of her home Fool's Paradise. HANDBOOK FOR FOOL'S PARADISE 1
This house grew by bits and pieces as I could afford to give myself more needed space. It is therefore unconventional in many ways and will be better enjoyed when its eccentricities are understood.
The first part to be built, in 1940, was a small cottage, in which only one room was finished, the livingroom, which was insulated and lined by the original builder. Walls and ceiling were all of knotty pine, with a meagre half inch of "tentest". a sort of fibre board, as insulation between the pine ceiling and the asphalt shingles of the roof. The house was placed on a foundation of concrete block and brick posts with crawl space below. There is still crawl space below porch, living-room and bedroom. Later, a cellar was excavated beneath the kitchen and bathroom of the original cottage.
The only heat at this time was the fireplace, a "heatilator" which draws cold air into the vents at floor level. That air is warmed in a chamber behind and escapes as warm air from the vents on the mantel piece.

Just after the war it was impossible to find a building contractor so I became my own builder, hiring tradesmen to do technical jobs that were beyond my skills. N.B. The electrician who wired the living-room left it so that all the outlets on the west wall are controlled by a switch in the hall. Those on the east wall are always live.
At some point I installed a pull-down staircase in the hall ceiling, and laid some flooring above the ceiling rafters to create an attic which was accessible. This gave me some storage space. That original pull-down was quick and easy until I fell against it one day and twisted the hinges. It never recovered.
Its successor is neither quick nor easy. To get up into the attic use the rod with a hook in the end (stored at present on the broom cupboard) to get hold of the eye in the trap door. Pull it down very gently. Push the centre of the hinges away from you so that when you pull down the folded section the top part does not start to lift. The light switch for the attic is on a rafter at the top of the ladder. There is very little head room, so navigate cautiously. THE CELLAR
After the war I was able at last to get electricity, to have a furnace in the new cellar, to add a studio and garage beyond the kitchen door, with the stairs to the cellar going down under the workbench in the studio.
I had a small cellar dug and lined with concrete blocks and in one corner had a cistern built, lined with poured concrete into which all rainwater from the roof would be directed. This was because the well which had been dug even before the house was built had proved unsatisfactory. For many years that cistern was my whole water supply, until the township brought water mains down Meadowcliff Drive and I was able to bring township water into the house.
The contractor who excavated the cellar for me and installed floor drains there, had covered them up before they could be inspected. They were a disaster, with T junctions which constantly clogged. At some point I had all drains from the main floor re-routed in pipes along the cellar ceiling. The floor Paper has loss (staple holes).

THE BEDROOM and HALL
The small room beyond the bathroom that I had assumed would be a utility room, was no longer needed for that purpose, now that I had a cellar. I had used it as a bedroom during the cottage days, but now, to make it feel larger, I cut into it the big window that looks toward the ravine. The room was far too small to accommodate clothes closets. But there was a space opposite the bathroom door into which I fitted a cupboard just deep enough for a clothes hanger. When I was building the angled cupboard to connect the clothes closet to the wall of the front hall and had put doors on the top and bottom sections, I recognized the middle as a NICHE and stopped making doors. I knew that some day I would find the perfect figure of some kind to stand there. And I did.
The pipe that runs up through the clothes closet originally served the oil furnace in the cellar. It is no longer funcional.

With electricity now availabe I superannuated the wood stove.I had been using, built pine cabinets and counters and left just enough room for the electric version of a gas refrigerator which is still operating perfectly more than fifty years later. And I was able to locate a stainless steel double sink with one deep side, and place it under the window that looked out at the cherry tree. Because I enjoy seeing my kitchen plates and want them within quick reach I made shallow shelves for them on either side of the sink.
The disposition of each bit of kitchen furnitue was carefully decided after I had made cardboard models to accurate scale and played around with the pieces on the model. My reason for two movable units for the breakfast table was so that it could be an extra counter and I could change its position if the sun was shining in my eyes in the morning. The fuse box up near the ceiling on that wall still serves the wiring in the original section of the house.

PHASE THREE
In 1960 I realized that my original studio was far too small for my increasingly demanding professional career. I was fortunate enough to be able to get the wonderful carpenter who had built the original cottage to come again and add the addition. The cherry tree had long since died and was no longer there to claim that piece of lawn. The fact that my kitchen window now opens into the studio is a real asset. I can look up from the dishwater and see the latest canvas unexpectedly, which gives me a fresh impression of its virtues or failings.
The price I paid for the new studio was the loss of light in the kitchen. But I spend far more time in the studio than in the kitchen and I still have a great view from my breakfast table, and have accepted the second best solution of using the fluorescent lights in the daytime.

We have found that cleaning once a year is worth the time and trouble and that the immersion pump will empty it in about two days. Next are the toads who come to the pond on warm evenings in May and sing all night to attract a mate. They are a wonderful chorus. Soon you will see necklaces of toad eggs criss-crossing the surface of the water. Each bead turns into a tadpole who, during the summer, grows legs and eventually hops away as a tiny toad. The tadpoles attract small children, who often bring a glass jar to catch a few and take them to teacher.
Of course all the wild animals come to the pond to drink and more than one local dog will swim in it. And always it reflects the apple tree and the sky.
The pond is five feet deep in the middle so that it never freezes completely but it is shallow around the edge for safety reasons. For a few years I stocked it with goldfish, but they are bottom-feeders and kept the mud stirred up. I found minnows were better and the coons and herons and king-fishers like them very well.
And after the surface freezes, neighbours will sweep or shovel the snow off to let the small children have a wonderful time on their new skates. Paper has loss (staple holes).

PHASE FOUR
At some point I wanted more space and decided that the garage could be enlarged and converted into a study with a . sleepinng loft over a second bathroom and laundry, and a new garage added on the far side. In the process of digging a foundation for the necessary enlargement, the machine broke the pipe connecting the cellar drain to the grease pit and left the broken end to rely on seepage into the soil to get rid of water from the cellar. This it does well enough except when a heavy thaw or unusually heavy rain saturates the soil around the house and water seeps through the cellar walls and builds up on the cellar floor and cannot be drained away into the water-logged soil. This happens very seldom, but if it does, the way to deal with it is to use the immersion pump in a bucket and bail into the bucket, with the hose from the pump going out the back door and pouring the water towards the ravine. If the water is only an inch or two deep it will usually drain away in a day or two by itself.
The garage which was converted had a concrete floor and so this addition was completed using a concrete pad with a foundation wall down below frost level. It has been uncomplicated, no plumbing, no drains. Its only eccentricities are the vents, the tall narrow screened doors beside each group of windows so that there can be a through passage of air in spite of the windows being fixed. Windows that would open needed so much framing that they would have reduced the light and the views that I demanded.
But of course there was a price, not money, but light in the big studio. I lost a window. That prompted the installation of the three skylights in the north-west ceiling. And they are pure joy, except in the summer when they let in as much heat as light. However the patio doors and the ceiling fan work at keeping it reasonably comfortable.
There are outside electrical outlets, one on the patio, one outside the small door in the garage, and one on a post beside the pond. And in the foundation wall of the big studio there are air vents to prevent dry rot in the beams that support the studio. They should be left open, but screened to keep out animals.

Now I would never sell it, and I hope that it will prove as gracious to live with to the new tenants as I have found it.

These are all things that I cherish because of the love that prompted them.
The angel that is my logo you will find on the welcome mat, on the weather vane, on the mobile above the fireplace, which was originally a Christmas decoration but obviously belonged all year round, and no doubt in other places here and there. The wooden version over the door to the kitchen was the original, made by me in 1940. In 1998 we had an almost tornado that blew her off her mount above the front gable, and sent her sailing to the ground where she lay in pieces. Repaired, but too fragile to put up above the roof again, she is given honourable retirement as you see her. A good neighbour made her replacement in metal and put it back on the gable, although the four points of the compass are no longer accurate.

He has developed an impressive business, with sophisticated machinery, trucks and tractors, and a team of young workers who come in and leave every property trimmed and beautiful. He is there working with them, or alone when the growing season is winding down. In the winter he ploughs the driveways. When pruning or tree removal is necessary he may be able to do the job himself or recommend the person who can.
Gardening is another matter. The beds around the house are mostly in perennials, but to keep out the twitch grass is a never-ending challenge. The garden behind the compost pit is intended for vegetables and cutting flowers. I hope that whoever is the resident caretaker here when I am gone will have a green thumb and able to make the gardens flourish. It is too much to hope that short-term tenants would have either time or will to look after them. Perhaps an interest in gardening should be a requirement of the position.

rdf:Description.dc:creator: McCarthy, Doris 1910-2010
rdf:Description.dc:subject: Fool's Paradise;
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Instructions prepared by Doris McCarthy on changing her home, Fool's Paradise, for different seasons. CHORES TO CHANGE F.P. TO WINTER MODE
STUDY no changes neccessary.
Studio Screen door must be replaced by glass door stored behind easel. Table on north wall should be cleared of boxes underneath and folded small. Then bring in glass iron table from porch and place up against it. Spread cover over both. Replace lamp and other parephenalia and restore cartons to underneath. Before covering, protect glass with plywood sheet stored on east side of filing cabinet. Bring in iron chairs and place ready to be used in living room and studio.
MUD ROOM Remove screen door and replace with glass door. Window screens will be stored for winter at back of coat cupboard. Replace by double windows now in that cupboard. Bedroom, bathroom, and livingroom all change from screens to glass at windows. There is no storm door for entrance, but check its weather stripping.
KITCHEN Equip windows with their doubles. I like the doubles upside down to avoid reducing vision.
HALL No changes
BATHROOM Change screen to glass window.
BEDROOM Same as bathroom.
PORCH Store on floor in north east corner, the fountain, large base upside down, smaller basin on it also upside down, cylindrical separater on top. Leave big wooden chairs but remove cushions and store under cot in study. Shake and sweep well the carpet and store under cot in study. Inspect screening and repair if necessary. Do not store any food on porch where coons or other animals could smell it. Leave small iron and masonite table for use during winter, under kitchen window. Turn off valve in cellar that lets water reach outdoor tap and fountain. If it drips use rubber tape to seal it. Drain the water from that pipe before sealing.
OUTSIDE Clean out eaves and down-drains. Fill wood cupboard beside fireplace in livingroom. Try to use both kindling and larger logs or split pieces. Fill to capacity, after fastening doors to avoid them opening. Replace old rug hanging inside door to minimize draughts. Break off any icicles that form over entrances. rdf:Description.dc:creator: Naylor, David
rdf:Description.dc:subject: McCarthy, Doris, 1910-2010;
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Letter of Condolence from David Naylor, President, University of Toronto to Ms Beth McCarthy, great-neice of Doris McCarthy, dated Nov 30, 2010
UNIVERSITY OF TORONTO Office of the President
November 30, 2010
Ms Beth McCarthy 125 Beverley Street Kingston, ON K7L 3Y7
Dear Ms. McCarthy,
I was very sorry to hear of the passing of your aunt and wanted to extend my personal condolences. Your aunt's tremendous contributions to the arts community and her work as an educator and mentor have made an impact on so many. She will be remembered fondly by all who knew her.
At this difficult time, please know that my colleagues at the University of Toronto have you and your family in our thoughts. We were deeply saddened by Doris's passing and we salute her warm and generous spirit.
With best wishes,
Yours sincerely,
David Naylor President
Simcoe Hall, 27 King's College Circle, Room 206, Toronto ON M5S 1A1 Canada Tel: +1 416 978-4163 • Fax: +1 416 971-1360 • president@utoronto.ca • www.utoronto.ca folds

rdf:Description.dc:description:
Letter of Condolence from Indira V. Samarasekera, O.C. President and Vice-Chancellor or University of Alberta, to the family of Doris McCarthy, dated Dec 8, 2010
UNIVERSITY OF ALBERTA Office of the President
3-1 University Hall www.ualberta.ca Tel: 780.492.3212 Edmonton, Alberta, Canada T6G 2J9 Fax:780.492.9265
8 December 2010
Family of Doris McCarthy 1 Meadowcliff Drive Scarborough, ON Ml M 2X8
To the family of Doris McCarthy,
I was saddened to learn of the passing of Doris McCarthy, C.M.
Doris's legacy as a distinguished Canadian artist will live on through her remarkable artwork and three autobiographies. The University of Alberta is honoured to count her among our distinguished honorary degree holders. I admire her commitment to lifelong learning, evidenced by the Bachelor of Arts degree that she received in 1989 at the age of 76!
On behalf of the University of Alberta, I extend my sympathies for your loss.
Yours sincerely,
Indira V. Samarasekera, O.C. President and Vice-Chancellor

rdf:Description.dc:subject: McCarthy, Doris, 1910-2010;
rdf:Description.dc:description:
Letter of Condolence from David Johnson, the Governor General, to members of the family of Doris McCarthy, dated Dec 8, 2010
THE GOVERNOR GENERAL • LE GOUVERNEUR GENERAL
December 8, 2010
Dear Members of the Family of Doris McCarthy,
My wife and I are deeply saddened to hear of your loss.
Our country has lost an exceptional Canadian and one of our greatest painters with the passing of Doris McCarthy. She will long be remembered for her outstanding contributions to the world of visual arts, and I know she will be deeply missed by all those lives she touched.
Please take comfort in knowing that all the members of the Order of Canada join me in offering you our condolences. May good memories sustain you through this time.
With deepest sympathy,
David Johnston
